thread.title: Heidi Klum to turn Magic Hour into party city for Halloween
thread.title_full: Heidi Klum to turn Magic Hour into party city for Halloween

posts.title: Heidi Klum to turn Magic Hour into party city for Halloween
posts.text:
Trick or treat!
Whether or not Heidi Klum, the “Queen of Halloween,” has decided on her costume for this year we don’t yet know. But she has picked a location for her annual holiday extravaganza.
Confidential has learned that Klum is bringing her 18th annual Halloween bash to the brand new Magic Hour at Moxy Times Square. The venue will be transformed into a haunted graveyard for Klum’s ghoul fest.
“The Tonight Show” bandleader Questlove will deejay the Oct. 31 monster mash and Party City is tending to the décor.
Heidi Klum defends her clone Halloween costume against haters 
Naturally, Klum is keeping details about her disguise under wraps.
“I love to transform into someone or something so drastically different that I’m no longer recognizable,” the super model told a source close to the event. “Halloween is my favorite time of the year and I can't wait to see everyone bring their costume A-game.”
Surely there’s a hint in there somewhere. Any guesses?
We’re told that VIP invites will go out after the weekend. The surefire hostspot is also slated to host a Tuesday night VIP preview, where DJ Cassidy, who spun at both of President Obama's inaugurations, will provide the soundtrack.
Though this hotel was first opened 110 years ago, it relaunched last week after a massive overhaul that's been the all the rage among the design world. The 36th Street inn will also introduce invitees to the hotel's revamped Legasea seafood restaurant during Tuesday night's big bash.
With Brian Niemietz

thread.title: Yankees vs. Twins: Breaking down the position matchups
thread.title_full: Yankees vs. Twins: Breaking down the position matchups

posts.author: Peter Botte
posts.title: Yankees vs. Twins: Breaking down the position matchups
posts.text:
NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 7:00 AM 
The Yankees and the Twins were separated by six wins in the standings and around $90 million in payroll this season. 
Both teams earned wild-card spots in the American League after missing the postseason one year ago, with Minnesota’s quick turnaround from a 103-loss campaign in 2016 perhaps even more impressive than the unexpected return to October ball for the Yanks after they’d failed to qualify in three of the previous four seasons. 
The familiar foes are meeting for the fifth time in postseason play since 2003, but for the first time since back-to-back sweeps in the division series by the Yanks in 2009 and 2010 — and thus, for the first time under the one-and-done format. 
Here is a position-by-position breakdown ahead of Tuesday’s AL wild-card showdown: CATCHER 
Gary Sanchez tied for the ML-lead in passed balls with 16, but his ability to throw out baserunners (38 percent) and his booming bat (33 homers, a team record for catchers) earned him an All-Star berth in his first full season. Twins counterpart Jason Castro, it should be noted, allowed three of the Yankees’ four stolen bases (two while Santana was pitching) on Sept. 18. 
EDGE: Yankees Gary Sanchez gives the Yankees the edge over the Twins when it comes to comparing catchers. (Abbie Parr/Getty Images) FIRST BASE 
Greg Bird, who started the season as the team’s No.3 hitter, finally made it back from a frustrating four months dealing with a nagging ankle injury to post eight homers and 25 RBI in 29 games after Aug. 26. Former AL MVP Joe Mauer only hit seven homers, but he still hit .305 with an .801 OPS. 
EDGE: Twins Joe Mauer gives the Twins an edge at first base. (Bruce Kluckhohn/AP) SECOND BASE 
All-Star Starlin Castro missed a couple of sizable chunks of the season, but he still batted .300 with respectable power numbers (16 HRs, 63 RBI) in a career-low 473 plate appearances, mostly from the 5-hole in the lineup. Minnesota leadoff man Brian Dozier has slugged 76 homers with an average of 96 RBI the past two seasons. 
EDGE: Even SHORTSTOP 
Unlikely cleanup hitter Didi Gregorius no longer is being doubted as Derek Jeter’s replacement, posting a star-turning campaign on both sides of the ball, including 25 homers (breaking Jeter’s team record at the position) with 87 RBI. Jorge Polanco knocked in 74 runs and stole 13 bases but committed twice as many errors (18-9) as Gregorius. 
EDGE: Yankees Didi Gregorius hit 25 home runs this season. (Bill Kostroun/AP) THIRD BASE 
Deadline pickup and Jersey boy Todd Frazier provided some power and a slight defensive upgrade over Chase Headley, hitting 11 of his 27 homers after arriving from the White Sox. Eduardo Escobar filled in ably for injured All-Star Miguel Sano, who is injured and not on Tuesday's roster. 
EDGE: Even LEFT FIELD 
Brett Gardner still provides Gold Glove-caliber defense and veteran leadership with a nice mix of power (career-high 21 homers) and speed (team-best 23 steals). Cleanup hitter Eddie Rosario batted .290 with 27 homers and an .836 OPS for the Twins. 
EDGE: Even CENTER FIELD 
Jacoby Ellsbury, the $153 million signee who was benched for the 2015 wild-card game, reclaimed regular playing time while his replacement Aaron Hicks spent a couple of stints on the DL, batting .293 after Aug. 2. Former No. 2 overall pick Byron Buxton finally broke through as a potential star with 16 home runs and 29 steals. And in the second half of the season, he’s hit .300 with 11 of those home runs. 
EDGE: Twins Byron Buxton (l.) gives the Twins the edge in center field while Brian Dozier (r.) is evenly matched against Starlin Castro at second base. (Brad Penner/USA Today Sports) RIGHT FIELD 
What more can we say about 6-foot-7 Aaron Judge’s astounding rookie season? The AL MVP candidate overcame a lengthy August swoon to put up his best month yet in September, finishing the year with 52 homers, 114 RBI and league bests in runs (128), walks (122) and yes, strikeouts (208). Twins counterpart Max Kepler hit .243 with 19 homers. 
EDGE: Yankees DESIGNATED HITTER 
As of printing, Girardi had yet to reveal his choice, but the switch-hitters, Headley or Hicks, could be used instead of veteran Matt Holliday, who is 5-for-12 lifetime against Santana. Outfielder Robbie Grossman (.246, nine HRs) has been handling much of the DH duties. Sano (28-77) returned from shin problems to take five at-bats the final weekend but the Twins have determined he is unable to play. 
EDGE: Even Luis Severino has emerged as the Yankees' ace. (Kathy Willens/AP) 
Luis Severino emerged as the front-of-the-rotation ace the Yankees thought they’d developed before a one-year derailment saw him go winless as a starter (0-8) in 2016, and spend parts of that season either in the minors or in the bullpen. The 23-year-old righty made his first All-Star team and finished 14-6 with a 2.98 ERA to go along with 230 strikeouts to earn this start over deadline acquisition Sonny Gray and erstwhile ace Masahiro Tanaka. Severino notably lasted only three-plus innings in his first career start against the Twins in late September. Ervin Santana possibly enjoyed the best season of his 13-year career (16-8, 3.28 ERA), but he’s 6-10 with a 5.66 ERA in 20 career starts against the Yanks. 
EDGE: Yankees BULLPEN 
Closer Aroldis Chapman has rebounded from some midseason shakiness, while the deadline additions of David Robertson and the hard-throwing Tommy Kahnle along with the emergence of strikeout machine Chad Green, give the Yanks a six-deep relief corps to shorten games, even if four-time All-Star setup man Dellin Betances has endured an uneven second half. The Twins unloaded All-Star closer Brandon Kintzler before the deadline, leaving manger Paul Molitor to rely mostly on righty Matt Belisle (nine saves), and the unheralded trio of Taylor Rogers (a lefty), Trevor Hildenberg and Alan Busenitz. Starter Jose Berrios (14-8, 3.89) also is available Tuesday in relief, Molitor said, but this category figures to be the Yankees’ biggest edge of all. 
EDGE: Yankees PREDICTION 
We all know anything can happen in a one-game scenario, but the Yankees' history of success against Santana and the overwhelming bullpen disparity should be enough to advance them into the AL division series against Cleveland. Tags:

thread.title: Authorities no closer to finding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
thread.title_full: Authorities no closer to finding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370

posts.author: The Associated Press
posts.title: Authorities no closer to finding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
posts.text:
After years of searching, authorities concede they're no closer to finding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Authorities no closer to finding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 THE ASSOCIATED PRESS Updated:  39 AM 
SYDNEY — A report on the almost three-year search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 said Tuesday the continuing mystery over the fate of the plane and the 239 people on board is "almost inconceivable." 
But the Australian Transport Safety Bureau's final report on the search, which was abandoned in January, concedes that authorities are no closer to knowing the reasons for the plane's disappearance, or its exact location. This is despite last year's narrowing down of its most likely resting place to a 25,000-square kilometer (9,650-square mile) patch of the southern Indian Ocean. 
The Boeing 777 carrying 227 passengers and 12 crew disappeared soon into its flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing on March 8, 2014. 
A 52-day surface search covered an area of several million square kilometers (square miles) in the Indian Ocean west of Australia, before an underwater search mapped 710,000 square kilometers (274,000 square miles) of seabed at depths of up to 6,000 meters (20,000 feet). They were the largest aviation searches of their kind in history, the bureau said. 
Despite other methods such as studying satellite imagery and investigating ocean drifts after debris from the plane washed ashore on islands in the eastern Indian Ocean and the east coast of Africa, the 1,046-day search was called off by the governments of Malaysia, China and Australia on Jan. 17. 
"The reasons for the loss of MH370 cannot be established with certainty until the aircraft is found," the bureau, which coordinated the search, said in the 440-page report. 
"It is almost inconceivable and certainly societally unacceptable in the modern aviation era with 10 million passengers boarding commercial aircraft every day, for a large commercial aircraft to be missing and for the world not to know with certainty what became of the aircraft and those on board," it said. 
"The ATSB expresses our deepest sympathies to the families of the passengers and crew on board MH370. We share your profound and prolonged grief, and deeply regret that we have not been able to locate the aircraft, nor those 239 souls on board that remain missing." 
However, the report said the understanding of where the plane may be is "better now than it has ever been," partly as a result of studying debris that washed ashore in 2015 and 2016 which showed the plane was "not configured for a ditching at the end-of-flight," meaning it had run out of fuel. Remembering the missing Malaysia Airlines flight 370 
The search team also looked back at satellite imagery which showed objects in the ocean that may have been MH370 debris. The report said this analysis complemented work detailed in a 2016 review and identified an area of less than 25,000 square kilometers (9,650 square miles) — roughly the size of the U.S. state of Vermont — that "has the highest likelihood of containing MH370." 
The bureau noted the Malaysian government is "continuing work on their investigation of the facts and circumstances surrounding the loss of MH370." 
The search was extremely difficult because no transmissions were received from the aircraft after its first 38 minutes of flight. Systems designed to automatically transmit the flight's position failed to work after this point, the report said. 
Subsequent analysis of radar and satellite communication data revealed the aircraft had continued to fly for seven hours. Its last positively known position was fixed at the northern tip of Sumatra by surveillance systems operating that night, six hours before it ended its flight in the southern Indian Ocean. 
The bureau said the search had at least led to some important gains in the field of locating missing aircraft on flights over deep ocean areas, with improvements made to systems for tracking aircraft. 
"Steps are being taken to advance other aircraft systems including emergency locator transponders and flight recorder locator beacons," the report said. 
ATSB Chief Commissioner Greg Hood praised the commitment of everyone involved in the search. 
"This was an unprecedented endeavor and there has been an extraordinary response from the global community," he said in a statement. Tags:

thread.title: Luis Severino thriving after making changes with Pedro Martinez
thread.title_full: Luis Severino thriving after making changes with Pedro Martinez

posts.author: Peter Botte
posts.title: Luis Severino thriving after making changes with Pedro Martinez
posts.text:
Luis Severino thriving after making offseason adjustments with former Yankees nemesis Pedro Martinez Luis Severino thriving after making changes with Pedro Martinez NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   7:30 AM 
Fans at Yankee Stadium used to infamously serenade Pedro Martinez at this time of year with chants of “Who’s Your Daddy?” 
The longtime Boston ace once tossed beloved Yankees coach Don Zimmer to the ground in an ugly October bench-clearer with the Red Sox, but Pedro is among those deserving of credit for the extreme transformation Luis Severino made this season on his way to becoming the easiest of choices to start Tuesday’s wild-card game against Minnesota. 
Coming off a horrendous second act in the Bronx last year following a promising debut late in the 2015 season, Severino sought and worked out with the three-time Cy Young winner in their native Dominican Republic last winter. 
Cause and effect isn’t an exact science, mind you, but the end results have been staggering for Severino, who has gone from 0-8 as a starter one year ago to 14-6 with a 2.98 ERA, good for the third in the American League, the next. 
“I think that was the change that I did for this season,” Severino said, referring to his offseason workouts with Martinez. “He told me that if I change my mechanics a little bit, I’ll be more consistent in my strike zone. That’s what I did, that’s how that worked out and helped me.” 
Now a first-time All-Star, the 23-year-old Severino clearly is the right choice to take the ball Tuesday night in this do-or-die game against the Twins. He has been the Yankees’ most effective starter all season, with barely a few blips, even if one of those was a three-inning stint against the Twins on Sept. 20, his lone start against them in his career. 
Just as homegrown star Aaron Judge emphatically expunged any bad taste lingering from his underwhelming debut late last summer, Severino came back from a lengthy trip to the minors and a stint as a one-inning reliever upon returning to not only reclaim his role in the starting rotation this spring, but to zoom to the top of it by tweaking his delivery and relying more on his changeup as a complementary pitch to his high-90s heat. 
If a first-ballot Hall of Famer you idolized as a child suggests that you make those changes, you make them, right? 
Now several months later, we will see if Pedro’s pupil can vault the Yanks past the upstart Twins and advance to the AL division series against Cleveland. Luis Severino has become the Yankees' ace after an offseason full of adjustments under the tutelage of Pedro Martinez. (Kathy Willens/AP) 
“I feel very confident. I’m not nervous,” Severino said. “We have a great team, great bullpen, great guys over there. Our team is going to be good. 
“It means a lot to me (to start this game)…They trust me, they gave me more confidence to go over there, okay, that’s my team. So I have to do everything I can to get us to the next step.” 
The next step would be such a significant one for Severino, Judge, Gary Sanchez and rest of the young core of a franchise that for decades has solely based its definition of success by wins in October and championship rings. 
It starts, as these things always tend to do, with the man with the ball in his hand. 
“Just what he’s done all year,” Judge replied when asked what he expects to see Tuesday night from his ace teammate. “He’s been dominant. He’s attacking hitters. He’s always getting in the good counts. Every time I look up there, it’s always 0-1, 0-2. He’s never falling behind a lot of hitters. 
“When you’ve got his repertoire, and his stuff and you’re getting ahead of guys like that, good things will happen.” 
So many impressive and encouraging things have happened where Severino is concerned throughout 2017. 
And he hardly seems intimidated by his matchup with veteran Ervin Santana, another countryman he got to know when they were All-Star teammates earlier this summer. Pedro Martinez used to be one of the Yankees' biggest rivals, but now fans should be thanking him. (Adam Glanzman/Getty Images) 
Joe Girardi certainly isn’t surprised after watching how Severino responded to starts toward the end of the season against the likes of Cleveland ace Corey Kluber and Boston ace Chris Sale, perhaps the only two pitchers ahead of him for AL Cy Young consideration this season. 
“I think the month of September, there are moments of anxiety, and I think he’s pitched well down the stretch,” Girardi said. 
Indeed, Severino went 3-0 with a 2.10 ERA over his final five starts, even if the lone shaky outing came against Minnesota on Sept. 20 at the Stadium. 
“Obviously, it’s a one-game playoff, and you’re going to come with your best. He’s the best on their team, and we’re looking forward to it,” Twins star Joe Mauer said. “We know what he’s got. He’s got good stuff, and we know it will be a tough day.” 
So tough that Minnesota skipper Paul Molitor even invoked an apt Hall of Fame-level comparison. 
“I don’t think you can go up there trying to hit all three of his pitches, because that’s usually not a good mix,” Molitor said. “A guy that was comparable for me in his prime was Pedro.” 
Who’s your daddy? Perhaps “Thank you, Pedro” should be the new chant at the Stadium if Severino pitches to form on Tuesday night. Join the Conversation:

thread.title: SEE IT: Look inside Stephen Paddock’s room shows guns, shells
thread.title_full: SEE IT: Look inside Stephen Paddock’s room shows guns, shells

posts.author: TERENCE CULLEN
posts.title: SEE IT: Look inside Stephen Paddock’s room shows guns, shells
posts.text:
NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated:   9:34 PM 
The Las Vegas hotel room of gunman Stephen Paddock, who killed 58 people and wounded more than 500 at a country music concert, was littered with assault rifles and bullet shells, photos of the room show. 
A Boston 25 News reporter tweeted a photo of Paddock’s room that shows a hammer along with dozens of casings on the floor and a bullet magazine. Among the casings is an assault rifle fixed with a scope and bipod. 
A second photo showed another long assault rifle with a long magazine and handle at the front of the stock. 
Clark County Undersheriff Kevin McMahill confirmed Tuesday evening that the images were of Paddock’s hotel room at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, and that an internal investigation is searching for the source of the leaked photos. A photo of Paddock’s room that shows a hammer along with bullet casings, a magazine and an assault rifle fixed with a scope and bipod. A second photo showed a long assault rifle with a magazine. (Boston 25 News) 
The room looked down 1,200 feet at the Route 91 Harvest festival, where about 22,000 people attended a Jason Aldean concert. 
They found 23 firearms inside the 32nd floor room, where Paddock had killed himself before cops arrived. A handgun and 16 assault rifles were part of his horrifying arsenal, authorities said Monday. They believe he snuck them into the room a suitcase. 
At one point, Paddock fired 280 rounds at the crowd in the course of 31 seconds. 
Survivors of Las Vegas shooting back Second Amendment 
Paddock had been staying in the palatial suite since Thursday, police said. 
Jeff Bridges of Charlotte, N.C. posted a video of the room from when he stayed there a year ago. 
“The video ironically ends with a view down on the concert area,” he wrote in the post. “Again, we would like to send our thoughts and prayers to everyone impacted by this tragedy!” 
Bridge’s nearly five-minute recording shows what he says is an 1,800-square-foot suite with sweeping views of the Las Vegas Strip. 
Hotel guest doors down from mass shooter relives the horror 
“It’s incredible at night,” he says, looking out the window. 
The room featured a large sitting area with floor-to-ceiling windows, an open sitting area and a TV screen built into the bathroom mirror. 
“I wasn’t sure places like this even existed,” Bridges said in a now eerie message. “But evidently they do. and we’re lucky enough to stay here for a few days.”

thread.title: Chuck Low, who played Morrie in ‘Goodfellas,’ dead at 89
thread.title_full: Chuck Low, who played Morrie in ‘Goodfellas,’ dead at 89

posts.author: NICOLE BITETTE
posts.title: Chuck Low, who played Morrie in ‘Goodfellas,’ dead at 89
posts.text:
Charles (Chuck) Low, who played Morris (Morrie) Kesseler in the famous flick “Goodfellas” alongside his good friend Robert De Niro died on Sept. 18.
He was 89.
Low — a New York City real estate developer — got into the acting business after De Niro became one of his tenants in a Tribeca loft. Their friendship later blossomed into Low’s most exciting role as an actor, in which he starred alongside De Niro in “Goodfellas.”
Chuck Low starred in "Goodfellas" with his pal Robert De Niro.  He also landed roles in “The Mission,” “King of Comedy,” “Once Upon a Time in America,” “Scent of a Woman” and “The Sopranos,” according to his obituary published in the New York Times .
25 things you didn’t know about ‘Goodfellas’ 
The late actor was first and foremost a military veteran. He served 30 years as a reserve in the U.S. military and four years on active duty.
'Goodfellas': Where are they now? Low then spent eight years in the National Guard before entering the family business — developing and manufacturing all lines of marine instruments.
In the 1960s he decided to get his brokerage license and began converting industrial buildings in Tribeca into lofts.
Actor Chuck Low at the 2015 Tribeca Film Festival. (Mike Coppola/Getty Images for the 2015 Tribec) His final acting role was in the 2003 film “Kill the Poor.”
‘The Sopranos’ and 'Goodfellas' actor Frank Vincent dead at 80 
But his best-known performance is certainly as Morrie, a wig salesman, who faced an unfortunate whacking at the hands of Joe Pesci's character Tommy DeVito with a screwdriver to the back of the head in Martin Scorsese’s classic movie.
Low, a New York native, passed away in his sleep at Allendale Nursing Home in New Jersey. A private funeral with full military honors was held two days later.

thread.title: Ask the Detroit Lions how much it costs to kneel
thread.title_full: Ask the Detroit Lions how much it costs to kneel

posts.author: Carron J. Phillips
posts.title: Ask the Detroit Lions how much it costs to kneel
posts.text:
How much does it cost to kneel during the national anthem? Ask the Detroit Lions Ask the Detroit Lions how much it costs to kneel Members of the Lions kneel during the anthem prior to their game against the Falcons on Sept. 24. (Duane Burleson/AP) Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 7:59 AM 
The Detroit Lions are 3-1, and currently in first place in the NFC North. 
ESPN even listed the Lions as one of the biggest surprises of the season due to their defense forcing almost as many turnovers (11) in the first four games of this season than they had all last year (14). 
But, something else is also going on in The Motor City. 
According to the Detroit Free Press , team owner Martha Ford asked her players not to kneel during the national anthem during a team meeting last week. 
Ford's request, however, isn't what's most interesting here. It's the backstory to this situation and her motives that are the most intriguing. 
According to Lions officials, before Donald Trump's remarks about the NFL and national anthem protest, no player on the roster had taken part in any kind of anthem protest all last year. But on Sept. 24, the Sunday after Trump's tweets in which he called those kneeling sons of b----es, eight players took a knee during the anthem, while Ford stood on the sidelines with her arms linked with the rest of the team, in a show of unity and solidarity. 
That Sunday was also when Rico LaVelle sang the anthem in Detroit and took a knee while raising his fist in the Black Power salute as he belted out the final note. 
That was the backstory. 
Here's the motive. 
Money. 
Ford told her players that she was willing to cut a check and donate her name and money to any of the community issues that were at the core of the player's cause for kneeling. 
With that news, only two players decided to kneel this past Sunday. One of them was Steve Longa, whose father was struck by a car and killed last week. 
There's also the case of Akeem Spence, who was one of the players who kneeled before the Falcons game, but then decided to stand on Sunday. Martha Ford reportedly asked Lions players to stand for the anthem. (Jose Juarez/AP) 
Spence's father lost a contract job over his decision to kneel. 
Money matters. 
And that's the complicated thing about this entire situation. If Ford does live up to her word, then her dollars could be put to good use, because what community program or non-profit doesn't need more cash? 
However, words also matter. 
And Ford used some words that make her gesture seem phony. 
"I don't think it's a cure-all kind of thing, but it's a step in the right direction and then for somebody as powerful as her to say to come in and say she'll stand up and she'll back and put her name on whatever it is that we want to do, whatever it is that we want to attack, try to bring some real change about for the issues, to me that's big," said Lions defensive end Cornelius Washington. 
Pay attention to when Washington said, "put her name on whatever." 
"We do dance around the topic a lot and Mrs. Ford has come forward and said that as long as we compromise as a team and unify and make a unified demonstration, she'll back us financially. So I'm definitely going to hold her to her word," said Lions running back Ameer Abdullah, who took a knee for the anthem before the Falcons game. Abdullah stood last Sunday. 
Compromise. 
If Ford really wants to make a difference by donating to causes to address police brutality, systemic racism, and inequality, then why does her name have to be "all over it?" 
And why do people of color always have to compromise their voice when they want to address their concerns for humanity and equality? 
Martha Ford doesn't want to help, she wants to hush. Lions players stand and link arms during the anthem prior to a game against the Vikings. (Brad Rempel/USA Today Sports) 
According to CNN , the Department of Defense spent $6.8 million on "paid patriotism" between 2012 and 2015 amongst 50 teams from the NBA, NFL, MLB, MLS, and NASCAR. 
Mind you, besides 9/11 and the Super Bowl, teams in the NFL weren't mandated to be on the field for the national anthem until 2009. 
Money is in play, yet again. 
Check this out from an article on ThinkProgress.com. 
"Overall, the Defense Department spent at least $10.4 million on 'marketing and advertising contracts with professional sports teams' across the board between 2012 and 2015, although, the report noted, the department '[could not] accurately account' for the full number of contracts and payouts it had awarded. 'It only reported 62 percent (76 of 122) of its contracts and 70 percent ($7.3 million) of its spending in its response to our inquiry," wrote Arizona Senators Jeff Flake(R) and John McCain (R). 
"Even with that disclosure, it is hard to understand how a team accepting taxpayer funds to sponsor a military appreciation game, or to recognize wounded warriors or returning troops, can be construed as anything other than paid patriotism." 
I never knew patriotism had a dollar amount. 
But wait, there's more. 
The article goes on to say that the NFL announced in May 2016 that it would refund $724,000 of the Defense Department payouts, which had been awarded for military "appreciate activities." 
The NFL has shown once again that money is its motive, and that they'd rather cut a check to be a patriot, then to do the actual work of one. 
Now, players inside of the Lions locker room, and as I suspect, others from around the league, are now being forced to answer some serious internal questions. 
How much is taking a knee worth? 
And is that price high enough to allow you to sleep at night? Tags:

thread.title: VIDEO: Man wanted for robbing Manhattan liquor store at gunpoint
thread.title_full: VIDEO: Man wanted for robbing Manhattan liquor store at gunpoint - NY Daily News

posts.author: Thomas Tracy
posts.title: VIDEO: Man wanted for robbing Manhattan liquor store at gunpoint
posts.text:
Cops are searching for a gun-toting bandit who held up a Hell’s Kitchen liquor store.
Police released video of the brazen suspect Tuesday in the hope that someone recognizes the man who pulled a gun on a woman behind the counter of Cellar 53 Liquor Store on 10th Ave. near W. 53rd St. about 2:45 p.m. Thursday and ordered her to empty the till.
Video shows the man aiming a gun at a cashier at the Hell’s Kitchen liquor store. (DCPI) The harrowing video shows the man aiming the gun at his victim and threatening her before she takes a bag and empties the proceeds of the cash register into it.
The thief ran off with $780, cops said.
He’s believed to be between 45 and 50 years old, about 5-foot-5 and between 175 and 190 pounds.
The suspect is described as 5-foot-5 and between 175 and 190 pounds. (DCPI) The suspect was last seen wearing a blue fleece pullover and a gray cap, cops said.
Anyone with information regarding this incident is urged to call NYPD CrimeStoppers at (800) 577-TIPS.

thread.title: ‘Star Wars: From a Certain Point of View’ offers new perspectives
thread.title_full: ‘Star Wars: From a Certain Point of View’ offers new perspectives

posts.author: SEAN KEANE
posts.title: ‘Star Wars: From a Certain Point of View’ offers new perspectives
posts.text:
So what they told you was true ...
"Star Wars: From a Certain Point of View" is a little different to most recent novels set in a galaxy far, far away.
As a celebration of the 40th anniversary of "A New Hope," it tells that movie's iconic story from the perspectives of secondary and background characters, jumping between them as the main narrative plays out. In total, there are 40 stories — one for each year since the movie's 1977 release — from a total of 43 authors.
Many longtime "Star Wars" readers will see this as the new version of the classic "Tales from the Mos Eisley Cantina" collection of short stories. While it does include stories from several cantina characters, this book is much more ambitious in that it follows the events of "A New Hope" from the final moments of "Rogue One" right to the throne room celebration following the Battle of Yavin.
'Star Wars: Phasma' author Delilah S. Dawson talks love of Ewoks 
“Star Wars: From a Certain Point of View” is clever celebration of the original movie’s 40th anniversary. (Penguin Random House) With each story comes a new tone and a fresh writing style, mirroring the many shades of the "Star Wars" franchise. There are plenty of bold stylistic choices, so readers will continually be surprised as they jump between rebels, Imperials and a wide variety of characters on the periphery of the main conflict.
Of course, some stories are stronger and more memorable; standouts include those written by Gary Whitta, Claudia Gray, Pablo Hidalgo, Madeleine Roux, Alexander Freed, Gary D. Schmidt, Cavan Scott and Charles Soule.
The biggest joy of this collection is turning the page to a new story and realizing which character they'll be jumping to next. Readers who go in knowing as little as possible about the book's contents will have the best experience.
Star Wars: WATN? Fans who know "A New Hope" by heart and those who've been keeping up with the comics and novels of recent years will be delighted by some of the inclusions — many of the stories feature side characters that have been quoted endlessly for four decades.
‘Star Wars Battlefront II: Inferno Squad’: book review 
However, the collection isn't without its problems. There are a few too many stories set on Tatooine and the tales focusing on the rebel pilots assaulting the Death Star occasionally become repetitive, since they are centered on similar narrative beats. The latter issue can be offset by taking breaks between stories.
Overall, this collection makes great use of the rich side characters of "A New Hope," strengthening the links between the original "Star Wars" movie and many of the stories told in the decades since.
Fans who attend the 40th anniversary panel at New York Comic Con or the Del Rey Booth on the convention floor can get a special edition of the book, with exclusive cover art by Chris Trevis. (Penguin Random House) Whatever truth you cling to, there are plenty of stories for you to enjoy here.
"Star Wars: From a Certain Point of View," published by Penguin Random House, is available Oct. 3. 
Tags: star wars star wars: from a certain point of view books book reviews Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: Tarek El Moussa left Las Vegas festival early before shooting
thread.title_full: Tarek El Moussa left Las Vegas festival early before shooting

posts.author: PETER SBLENDORIO
posts.title: Tarek El Moussa left Las Vegas festival early before shooting
posts.text:
"Flip or Flop" star Tarek El Moussa went to the Route 91 Harvest in Las Vegas on Sunday, but had already left the music festival when a gunman opened fire on the crowd.
The HGTV star offered his condolences for those affected by the horrific tragedy in an Instagram post hours after at least 59 people were killed , and over 500 others were injured.
"I was there last night at the Route 91 Harvest Country Music Festival in #Vegas. My friend Robert wanted to come home early which we did," he wrote. "My heart goes out to everyone who has been affected by this tragedy."
Tarek El Moussa is the star of HGTV’s “Flip or Flop.” (Jerod Harris/Getty Images for Lakewood Center) "It's times like this that remind us we need to treat everyday with the importance it deserves," El Moussa continued. "Give your family and friends a hug today and let them know they are safe and loved."
SEE IT: Look inside Stephen Paddock’s room shows guns, shells 
The horrific attack was carried out by a shooter, Stephen Paddock, perched inside a 32nd-floor hotel room at the nearby Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino. Jason Aldean was performing onstage when the gunman opened fire on the audience of more than 22,000 people.
Mass shooting at Mandalay Bay Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas It’s the deadliest mass shooting in modern American history.
Paddock shot and killed himself before authorities arrived to his room, officials say.

thread.title: Ex-con accused of killing mechanic wanted refund for BMW repairs - NY Daily News
thread.title_full: Ex-con accused of killing mechanic wanted refund for BMW repairs - NY Daily News

posts.author: Rocco Parascandola
posts.title: Ex-con accused of killing mechanic wanted refund for BMW repairs - NY Daily News
posts.text:
An ex-con charged with fatally shooting a Brooklyn mechanic was enraged over a $1,500 refund he wanted for shoddy car repair work, police sources said.
Richard Essor, 33, is accused of shooting 51-year-old Dexton Simpson at the East Flatbush auto body shop where Simpson worked.
Essor, who is charged with murder and weapon possession, had been steaming for months because he thought Simpson had caused an electrical fire in his BMW, police sources said.
On Friday night, Essor pulled up to Total Auto Care Shop on E. 98th St. near Ditmas Ave. in a different car, a Honda, sources said.
The two men argued, and the fight turned deadly, with Essor firing a gun three times, hitting Simpson in the chest and neck, sources said.
Essor then calmly walked to his car and drove off, sources said. Police soon learned he had booked a flight to Jamaica, and arrested him as he tried to board at Kennedy Airport, sources said.
Essor, who has been arrested 11 times, was sentenced to two years in prison on a 2007 attempted weapon possession conviction.
He’s been held without bail, and is due back in court on Friday.
Family members gathered Monday outside Simpson’s home in St. Albans.
"This isn't a time for talking right now," one relative said, pointing to another loved one. "Just thinking about him, look, she has tears in her eyes. It is a terrible tragedy."
With Dale Eisinger 
Tags: east flatbush gun violence new york murders

thread.title: Man hailed as hero in Vegas massacre has bullet lodged in neck
thread.title_full: Man hailed as hero in Vegas massacre has bullet lodged in neck

posts.author: DAVID BOROFF
posts.title: Man hailed as hero in Vegas massacre has bullet lodged in neck
posts.text:
Jonathan Smith, hailed as hero for helping dozens escape Las Vegas massacre, has bullet lodged in neck Man hailed as hero in Vegas massacre has bullet lodged in neck NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 9:33 AM 
A 30-year-old man who helped dozens escape harm during the Las Vegas massacre that left 59 dead may have a bullet lodged in his neck for the rest of his life. 
Jonathan Smith had come from California to attend the Harvest Country Music Festival to help his brother celebrate a birthday, according to the Washington Post . Several of his family members were in attendance Sunday night, and they were close to performer Jason Aldean and the stage when shots rang out. 
Smith was focused on finding relatives, but ended up helping countless strangers instead. He formed a human chain to get people to safety. Jonathan Smith was wounded helping other concertgoers in Las Vegas (GMA) 
"Active shooter, active shooter, let’s go! We have to run," he instructed to panicked people around him, according to the Washington Post. 
"I ran back towards the shooting and there was one lady that was on the ground," Smith recalled to ABC's "Good Morning America" on Tuesday. "I basically helped her up and just told her just to run. I basically just told her we got to go." Remembering the victims of the Las Vegas mass shooting 
Smith continued to help people as the shots rang out. He was wounded while helping young girls, telling them to get on the ground, according to the Washington Post. 
He believes that an off-duty California police officer probably saved his life by trying to stop the bleeding from Smith's wound, according to the newspaper. Mass shooting at Mandalay Bay Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas 
Smith was hailed on social media as a hero after a photo of him went viral. 
"I don’t see myself that way," he told the Washington Post. "I would want someone to do the same for me. No one deserves to lose a life coming to a country festival." 
He was thankful that all his relatives escaped safely. Tags:

thread.title_full: Conan O’Brien had this question to ask after Vegas shooting

posts.author: NICOLE BITETTE
posts.title: Conan O’Brien had this question to ask after Vegas shooting
posts.text:
Late night host Conan O'Brien had several questions in the wake of the deadliest shooting in modern U.S. history.
The normally funnyman took a somber note when addressing his audience Monday night — and was open about how his staff approached the news of the Las Vegas shooting before he went on air.
When O'Brien walked into his office on Monday morning, a head writer for "Conan" presented the star with the remarks he gave after Sandy Hook and the Pulse nightclub shootings in order for him to prepare what he would say in the wake of the latest tragedy.
Conan O'Brien addresses the Las Vegas mass shooting on Oct. 2, 2017. (TBS) "How could there be a file of mass shooting remarks for a late-night host?" he began questioning. "When did that become normal? When did this become a ritual? And what does it say about us that it has?"
These are the victims of the Las Vegas massacre 
The fact the words were even on file left the host dumbfounded.
Mass shooting at Mandalay Bay Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas The father of two found it unfathomable that the United States of America — which he called the most affluent and influential country in the world — could fall victim to such mass attacks.
"I don't think it should be so easy for one demented person to kill so many people so quickly," he said.
"The sounds of those automatic weapons last night are grotesquely out of place in a civilized society. It makes no sense to me as a reasonable human being and a father," he continued. "Something needs to change."

thread.title: Trump hints gun laws talks will come soon after Vegas shooting
thread.title_full: Trump hints gun laws talks will come soon after Vegas shooting

posts.author: JASON SILVERSTEIN
posts.title: Trump hints gun laws talks will come soon after Vegas shooting
posts.text:
Mass shooting at Mandalay Bay Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas 
Trump made no explicit mention of Paddock or gun violence in his early statements about the massacre. White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders told reporters it was too soon to judge Paddock’s motives or to start talks about gun policy. 
Trump’s hesitance stands in stark contrast to his reaction to recent attacks, domestically and abroad, that were committed by radical Islamic killers. Trump has habitually publicized unconfirmed information about the suspects and pushed some of his favored policies, such as his travel ban on majority-Muslim countries, only hours after other massacres. 
Trump vowed as a candidate and President to fight any serious restrictions on the Second Amendment, and there is little reason so far to believe the Las Vegas rampage will change his mind. 
Trump took in more than $30 million in campaign donations from the NRA and told the gun lobby at its national conference in April that he would end the left-wing “assault” on gun rights. People run for cover during the shooting at the Route 91 Harvest country music festival Sunday night. (David Becker/Getty Images) 
More than 20 sources close to Trump told Axios that the President is unlikely to yield on guns because it would upset his voting white, blue-collar voting base. 
“Base would go insane and he knows it,” former Trump adviser Roger Stone told Axios. 
Steve Bannon, Trump’s former chief strategist and campaign manager, said a firearms pivot from Trump would be “impossible.” Tags:

thread.title: N.Y. sent D.C. $41B more than state received in services in 2016
thread.title_full: N.Y. sent D.C. $41B more than state received in services in 2016

posts.author: KENNETH LOVETT
posts.title: N.Y. sent D.C. $41B more than state received in services in 2016
posts.text:
ALBANY — With President Trump and Congress considering tax and health care reforms that some say would hurt New York, a new report says the gap between what New Yorkers send Washington in taxes and what it receives back in federal services has doubled in just three years.
The report by state Controller Thomas DiNapoli found that New York in 2016 received 84 cents in services for every $1 it sent to Washington.
The state sent nearly $41 billion more to Washington than it received back in federal spending, DiNapoli said.
That's more than double the $19.9 billion gap in 2013.
GOP won't promise middle class help or Trump info for tax reform 
Nationally, the average return for all states in 2016 was $1.18 per tax dollar sent to D.C.
"While the Empire State fares well in some areas, in total it receives significantly less per tax dollar than the vast majority of states," he said. "Federal decision makers should consider this imbalance as they debate proposed budget and policy changes that could significantly impact New York and other states."
The tax reform plan unveiled last week by President Trump and Republican congressional leaders includes a provision that would eliminate the federal deduction of state and local taxes, a move that would hurt high-tax states like New York, New Jersey and California.
The state is also facing a multi-billion dollar cut in health care funding that could grow worse if the push to repeal and replace Obamacare eventually succeeds.
DiNapoli's report says that the federal government in 2016 spent more than $3.8 trillion and brought in approximately $3.3 trillion, with a budget deficit of $585 billion.
The tax reform plan unveiled last week by President Trump includes a provision that would hurt high-tax states like New York, New Jersey and California. (Pool/Getty Images) New York generated 8.3% of federal tax payments, while representing just 6.1% of the American population.
New York's per capita contribution to the feds in 2016 was $12,914, which was 36% above the national average, DiNapoli said. At the same time, the state received $10,844 in per capita federal spending, slightly below the national average of $11,183.
New Jersey, North Dakota and Connecticut are the only states that had a worse per capita deficit than New York's $2,070, he said.
The DiNapoli report shows federal spending in New York in 2016 included $55 billion in Social Security payments, $47 billion for Medicare and more than $46 billion for Medicaid and other safety net grants.
In addition, there are billions of dollars from Washington to help support other programs like education and transportation.
Meanwhile, New Yorkers paid a combined $145 billion in 2016 in personal income tax payments, which was 9.4% of the total received by the feds.
The $7,361 per capital payment from New York was 54% higher than the national average and ranked third among states. Connecticut was first at $9,515.
Tags: taxes and spending thomas dinapoli north dakota connecticut donald trump

thread.title: Man strangled ex-girlfriend day after leaving Rikers: prosecutors
thread.title_full: Man strangled ex-girlfriend day after leaving Rikers: prosecutors

posts.author: THOMAS TRACY
posts.title: Man strangled ex-girlfriend day after leaving Rikers: prosecutors
posts.text:
A 52-year-old man killed his ex-girlfriend a day after being released from Rikers Island, Queens prosecutors said Tuesday.
Jerome Rivers, a registered sex offender, is now back at Rikers Island, charged with strangling Gia Pender inside her home on Centerville St. near Rockaway Blvd. in Ozone Park early Friday.
Pender, 49, feared that Rivers was going to harm her and gave her wallet, credit cards and ID to a friend in case “anything happens,” prosecutors said.
“Jerome is coming over,” she told the friend.
Manhattan slumlord Steve Croman gets one year at Rikers 
“If anything happens to me, give this to my mother,” she said, according to court documents.
“This was a senseless killing,” Queens District Attorney Richard Brown said in a statement. “Despite the defendant having an order of protection barring him from communicating with the victim, the man allegedly called her numerous times from jail and then asked to stay with her upon his release.”
Rivers, of Brooklyn, faces up to 25 years in prison for Pender’s death.
“(This) woman feared for her safety and actually gave a neighbor her wallet and other personal items to pass on to her mother, if something happened to her,” Brown said. “Domestic violence is a plague in our society and must end. The defendant now faces the prospect of spending the rest of his life in prison.”
De Blasio eyes 'ideal' Queens site for new jail as Rikers closes 
Cops arrested Rivers on July 29, for assaulting Pender, police sources said. At his arraignment, a judge approved an order of protection barring contact.
Despite this, Rivers, after completing his two-month sentence for the assault, called Rivers on Thursday and asked to stay with her.
Jerome Rivers, 52, of Brooklyn, was sent back to Rikers Island after his ex-girlfriend's death. Prosecutors say he strangled her the day after he finished a jail sentence for assaulting her. (Police Photo) On Friday at about 6 a.m. Rivers called 911, claiming that he heard a thump and found Pender on the floor. He told police that the 911 operator instructed him to do chest compressions, but, when he did so, he “heard a pop,” he said.
Pender died at the scene.
Queens pols support site for new jail in their borough 
Once an autopsy showed that Pender was strangled, cops on Saturday arrested Rivers and charged him with murder and disobeying an order of protection, cops said.
Rivers claimed he and Pender hadn’t argued since he had been back and he had no reason to kill her. Then, in a bizarre statement, he gave police all the reasons he would harm her, claiming that Pender had taken checks meant for him, had him locked up on what he claimed were trumped-up domestic violence charges and had disrespected his mother.
A Queens criminal court judge ordered him held without bail during a brief arraignment on Sunday.
Rivers, who was added to the New York State Sex Offender Registry after he sexually assaulted a woman in 2013, has an extensive criminal record with 109 arrests stretching back to 1983, police sources said.
Tags: rikers island ozone park richard brown domestic violence new york murders

thread.title: New York sending another round of medical supplies to Puerto Rico
thread.title_full: New York sending another round of medical supplies to Puerto Rico

posts.author: KENNETH LOVETT
posts.title: New York sending another round of medical supplies to Puerto Rico
posts.text:
New York sending another round of medical supplies, equipment to Puerto Rico New York sending another round of medical supplies to Puerto Rico NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 9:50 AM 
ALBANY — New York on Tuesday morning was sending the latest round of medical supplies and equipment to hurricane-ravaged Puerto Rico. 
In announcing the shipment, which was being delivered by a plane leaving from Westchester County Airport, Gov. Cuomo said that many of the island's hospitals are operating on generators running short on supplies. 
The state medical community on Tuesday was shipping out about $500,000 worth of equipment and supplies like bandages, Cuomo said. 
In addition, they are readying to deploy about 100 doctors and 200 nurses to the island to offer assistance. 
"For the hospital and the medical community to be making this gesture now is really significant, because the medical community itself is under a lot of pressure," Cuomo said, citing a series of proposed and enacted federal funding cuts. "Even in the midst of this, you see this show of tremendous generosity." 
Cuomo said Puerto Rico Gov. Ricardo Rossello requested the medical supplies and personnel. 
The UJA was providing the transportation and the unions representing nurses and other health care personnel were putting together the people who will be going down, the governor said. Hurricane Maria strikes Puerto Rico after pummeling Caribbean 
New York previously sent state troopers and other emergency personnel to Puerto Rico in the wake of the storm that left the island without power, phones or running water. 
Cuomo said the biggest impediment once the supplies reach the island is distributing them because of washed out and blocked roads and the need for personnel who know the layout of the island. 
Tuesday’s shipments from New York come the same day President Trump was scheduled to visit Puerto Rico for the first time since it was hit by Hurricane Maria. 
Cuomo, who has been mentioned as a possible Democratic presidential candidate in 2020, criticized Trump for waiting too long. Cuomo traveled to Puerto Rico on Sept. 22, 
"I think it's good that he's going there now, but I think it would have better if he had gone there earlier," Cuomo said Tuesday. "My first rule is show up. Show up because there's a human dynamic to this ... People are frightened and they're alone and they're anxious and they're wondering what's going to happen." 
Cuomo said had Trump gone earlier, he could have avoided the political fights that have occurred. Trump got into a dispute with the mayor of San Juan over the federal relief efforts. Cuomo said Puerto Rico Gov. Ricardo Rossello requested the medical supplies and personnel. (Gerald Herbert/AP) 
"Showing up when you're in a position of power — you're President of the United States — would give such a reassurance to the community. Don't worry, you're not alone. We're here. We're going to work with you every step of the way," Cuomo said. "That is a powerful gift that office gives you." 
Cuomo also chastised the Federal Emergency Management Agency for not being better prepared in advance of the storm. 
"I don't believe that FEMA understood the issue that they were going to be faced with in Puerto Rico and I believe they made an operational error in not pre-deploying sufficient resources," Cuomo said. 
Unlike dealing with storms that hit Texas, Florida or even New York, Cuomo said the Puerto Rican government is basically insolvent and doesn't have the sophisticated infrastructure or depth of governmental personnel needed for emergency relief. 
"That's what (FEMA) had to anticipate so the next morning they would be ready to do," Cuomo said. Tags:

thread.title: Stunning ‘Blade Runner 2049’ is anything but robotic — review
thread.title_full: Stunning ‘Blade Runner 2049’ is anything but robotic — review

posts.author: ETHAN SACKS
posts.title: Stunning ‘Blade Runner 2049’ is anything but robotic — review
posts.text:
For a bleak dystopian future, it sure is a beautiful place to visit.
Director Denis Villeneuve has managed a miracle of creation worthy of the themes of “Blade Runner 2049.” He’s turned the long-gestating sequel to the beloved 1982 sci-fi film into a visual experience that transcends the original.
Set, appropriately enough, 35 years after the first movie, the new film stars Ryan Gosling as K, one of those blade runners roaming Los Angeles who specialize in hunting down older models of replicants — bioengineered human slaves — that can’t match the newer versions that keep Earth running.
Letter perfect: Ryan Gosling is K in "Blade Runner 2049." (Stephen Vaughan/Alcon Entertainment, LLC) Not that there’s much left worth running, as the most privileged humans jettisoned this environmentally-ravaged planet for space. The unfortunates left behind can at least lord over the “skin-jobs” who serve them.
Shows, premieres canceled after Las Vegas shooting 
And no one does more lording than Jared Leto as the head of the corporation at the top of the new world order. There are few flaws to be found in this sci-fi-high, but putting the Oscar winner in a one-note role is sadly one of them.
Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford, who reprises the role of Rick Deckard from the 1982 "Blade Runner." (Stephen Vaughan/Alcon Entertainment, LLC) Between cases, K lives a lonely existence, with only a Siri-like hologram girlfriend (Ana De Armas) for company...until he discovers a secret on a cold case that threatens their “world built on a wall separated by kind.”
That sets him off on a quest to find answers — and the one man who can provide them, former blade runner Rick Deckard, with Harrison Ford reprising his role from the original.
K (Ryan Gosling, right) lives a lonely existence, with only a Siri-like hologram for a girlfriend (Ana De Armas). (Courtesy of Alcon Entertainment) While it’s truly special to accompany Ford on his trip down memory lane — Han Solo in “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” and his whip-cracking archeologist in “Indiana Jones V” whenever that starts filming — he has ceded leading man status to Gosling. And the younger actor earns every bit of his screen time with an understated performance and solid action chops.
But the real heroes of the film are behind the camera. Villeneuve, who proved his flair for genre grandeur with last year’s “Arrival,” and director of photography Roger A. Deakins have crafted a masterpiece to watch — whether in the cyan neon bathed streets of Los Angeles or in an orange bathed dusty desert wasteland. And like all of the French-Canadian director’s films, it sounds great.
Jared Leto plays the head of the corporation at the top of the new world order. (Stephen Vaughan) With original “Blade Runner” producer Ridley Scott attached, there are homages to the first film without being overly reverential. Good thing. Because this sequel eclipses that adaptation of Philip K. Dick’s novel, “Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?” — which suffered from compromises made for the studio at the time.
The screenplay by Hampton Fancher (who co-wrote the original) and Michael Green give plenty of class war themes to chew on over the film’s two-hour and 43-minute running time. That might have been a little too long considering how over-baked the sequel’s third act feels towards the end. But that’s a small price to pay for the rest of the movie.
Do androids dream of electric sheep? Maybe. But science fiction-loving cinephiles have definitely been dreaming of a movie like “Blade Runner 2049” for years.
Tags: ryan gosling denis villeneuve blade runner 2049 harrison ford Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

posts.title: Staten Island cop arrested for allegedly threatening ex-wife
posts.text:
Police arrested an off-duty Staten Island cop for making a drive-by threat against his ex-wife, authorities said Tuesday.
Police Officer John Gamba, 39, was charged with criminal contempt and harassment, after he allegedly drove past his ex-wife’s car on Slosson Ave. in Staten Island’s North Shore about 9:40 p.m. Monday.
During the brief encounter, he gave his ex the middle finger, police sources said.
He then stuck out his pointer finger and thumb like a gun, and aimed it at his former wife as if he was shooting her, the sources said.
Gamba’s ex-wife called police, who charged him with criminal contempt and harassment.
His arraignment was pending Tuesday.

thread.title: 'Hopeless' Knicks greet NYC subway riders due to FS1 ad campaign
thread.title_full: 'Hopeless' Knicks greet NYC subway riders due to FS1 ad campaign

posts.author: BRETT BODNER
posts.title: 'Hopeless' Knicks greet NYC subway riders due to FS1 ad campaign
posts.text:
SEE IT: FS1 ad campaign asking subway riders to ‘pick a side’ about ‘hopeless’ or 'hopeful' Knicks being shut down 'Hopeless' Knicks greet NYC subway riders due to FS1 ad campaign NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated:   5:47 PM 
Subway riders are now reminded of the negativity that comes with being a Knicks fan on the same day the team's preseason starts. 
A Fox Sports 1 ad campaign is asking riders to "pick a side" on the Times Square to Grand Central shuttle: Are the Knicks hopeful or hopeless? 
But the ad wrap, which went up Monday, is now being shut down at FS1's request, according to a spokesperson for the MTA's advertising partner Outfront Media. 
Half of the train has a negative ad on the outside, referring to the franchise as "hopeless" alongside photos of Joakim Noah and Tim Hardaway Jr. It's never too early for Knicks fans to start feeling negative about the franchise, apparently. (Jake Becker/New York Daily News) 
Noah signed a four-year, $72 million contract last year and has been widely viewed as a bust for the franchise so far. Hardaway Jr. turned several heads this offseason when the Knicks signed him to a huge four-year, $71 million deal. 
On the inside of the subway car, even the seats are filled with negative quotes. Knicks fans asked to 'pick a side' with FS1's subway ad campaign 
Side by side are seats with "Sit here if you blame Phil,""Sit here if you blame Melo," and "Sit here if you blame Dolan." 
But it wasn't all negative — the other side of the car featured "hopeful" along with a picture of star Kristaps Porzingis. 
Kristaps Porzingis ready to live up to expectations with Knicks 
Still, the campaign apparently ruffled some feathers at nearby Madison Square Garden. The Knicks were not initially aware of the ads, ESPN reported . 
Another car included similar messaging but instead took aim at Giants QB Eli Manning and Yankees star rookie Aaron Judge. Pick a seat, Knicks fans. (Jake Becker/New York Daily News) 
"Swings hard, misses often," read one seat critical of Judge, while one on the other side read, "He can be the LeBron of baseball." 
Multiple attempts to reach Brian Strong, who is FS1's Senior VP of Brand Communications, went unanswered. 
Aaron Judge also earned some real estate on the shuttle. 
The Knicks face the Nets at the Garden at 7:30 p.m. Tuesday.

thread.title: Mets dump pitching coach Dan Warthen, head trainer Ray Ramirez
thread.title_full: Mets dump pitching coach Dan Warthen, head trainer Ray Ramirez

posts.author: KRISTIE ACKERT
posts.title: Mets dump pitching coach Dan Warthen, head trainer Ray Ramirez
posts.text:
The Mets continued the shakeup of their major-league staff Tuesday, firing pitching coach Dan Warthen and head trainer Ray Ramirez. They will reorganize their medical/training staff and minor-league staff as well, Sandy Alderson said in a conference call with reporters.
The Mets GM added that Kevin Long will get "strong consideration" in an interview to replace Terry Collins as manager. Alderson said the Mets are in the process of gathering other candidates as well.
"Kevin Long has expressed an interest in interviewing for the manager's position and that will certainly be given strong consideration," Alderson said. "I do believe that ultimately, depending on the managerial choice, that both (Long and assistant hitting coach Pat Roessler) will be back.
"As far as managerial candidates are concerned, we do not have a final list. We have a preliminary list," Alderson said. " We will be fine-tuning that over the next few days and commence the process."
That list includes Alderson allies Bob Geren, who served as Mets bench coach before leaving in 2016 to take the same job with the Dodgers, and Chip Hale, the current A's third base coach who lost out on the job to Collins in 2010.
But Alderson was emphatic that he does not have to be familiar with the candidate.
"No, my familiarity with the candidate is not necessary," Alderson said. "In fact, I am intrigued by some of the names that have come up whom I've never met."
METS 2017 KEEP 'EM or DUMP 'em: VOTE NOW 
Dan Warthen, Mets pitching coach since 2008, will not return to the organization. (David Zalubowski/AP) The list also includes former Met and White Sox manager Robin Ventura, former Met and current White Sox bench coach Joe McEwing and former Met and current Astros bench coach Alex Cora.
That new manager will have "input," but will not necessarily make the decision on the new pitching coach. Alderson cited Warthen's friendship with Collins as well as the poor pitching — starters and bullpen — this year.
Warthen ends a 10-year run in that position that included guiding R.A. Dickey to a Cy Young, Jacob deGrom to a 2014 Rookie of the Year award and a staff of young arms to the World Series in 2015 and back to the playoffs in 2016.
He has been offered another position in the organization, but Alderson said Warthen had not yet told him if he accepted the still-undefined role in the organization.
That offer may be an attempt to ease the concern of pitchers like Jacob deGrom, who said he saw "no reason to change," and Noah Syndergaard, who ended the 2017 season with a parting shot to the front office.
"As far as pitching coach situation, I think it's pretty much b-lls--t with Dan. He's taking the blame for all the injuries we've had this year," Syndergaard said Sunday.
The injuries were overwhelming, so it's not surprising Ramirez took the fall.
Ray Ramirez (right) has also been sacked. (Drew Hallowell/Getty Images) Alderson said that moves made "midseason" already started the restructuring of the team’s medical/training staff. The Mets will add some staff and work to improve the communication between them, the front office and field staff.
"Adding personnel also means reorganizing areas of responsibility and reporting all toward the view of making sure the front office and the baseball staff have current meaningful information," Alderson said. "And that the players are getting the best possible care."
Alderson doubled down on controversial trainer Mike Barwis, saying he is an asset to the organization who is not involved in the day-to-day maintenance of players.
"Barwis is a consultant, he's a tremendously knowledgeable about physiology, anatomy and performance therapy and performance conditioning," Alderson said. "He doesn't dictate to players what they are going to do or not do."
Besides injuries, the Mets’ other main issue is that they do not have a stockpile of good young players. They were not happy with how shortstop prospect Amed Rosario, first base Dominic Smith and some young pitchers came up to the majors looking unprepared.
"I was disappointed with how some of our young players performed over the course of a few weeks. I am glad we got a look at them, but in some cases there is work to be done," Alderson said. "There are going to be changes at our Triple-A affiliate, in fact, I think major changes. We're taking a hard look at the rest of our player development system as well."
Alderson sees Collins, who stepped down as manager after Sunday's season finale, as someone who can help get the minor-league system in order. He has the title of special assistant to the GM.  
Tags: new york mets mlb dan warthen ray ramirez tom goodwin ricky bones Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: Three dead in double murder-suicide in Florida
thread.title_full: Three dead in double murder-suicide in Florida - NY Daily News

posts.author: David Boroff
posts.title: Three dead in double murder-suicide in Florida
posts.text:
NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 10:08 AM 
Three people are dead from apparent gunshot wounds and another was critically wounded in a double murder-suicide in Florida late Monday night. 
Deputies were called to the scene in Nokomis just after 11 p.m. and found five people, according to the Sarasota County Sheriff's Office. The fifth person suffered minor injuries. 
Investigators believe that a male suspect fatally shot a man and a woman before taking his own life. 
Another woman was hospitalized in critical condition after being wounded. The victim who suffered minor injuries was not shot, the sheriff's office said. Authorities at the scene of Monday night's double murder-suicide in Florida. (Sarasota County Sheriff's Office) 
Authorities are looking over several crime scenes and said that aggravated battery took place across the street from the shootings, according to ABC Action News . 
Public information officer Kaitlyn Perez said during a press briefing that there is definitely "a second element" to what transpired. 
All five people knew each other, according to the sheriff's office. Tags:

thread.title: Remains found in Aruba do not belong to Natalee Holloway
thread.title_full: Remains found in Aruba do not belong to Natalee Holloway - NY Daily News

posts.author: Minyvonne Burke
posts.title: Remains found in Aruba do not belong to Natalee Holloway
posts.text:
Remains found in Aruba do not belong to Natalee Holloway Remains found in Aruba do not belong to Natalee Holloway NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 10:50 AM 
The disappearance of Natalee Holloway remains an unsettling mystery after it was revealed that the skeletal remains found in Aruba do not belong to the Alabama teen. 
Dr. Jason Kolowski, a forensic scientist who led the testing of the bone fragments, announced Monday that the results came back negative. Natalee Holloway has been missing since 2005. (AP) 
"The mitochondrial DNA bone sample was not a match to [mother] Beth Holloway," he told Oxygen . "And so it was ruled out as being Natalee Holloway." 
Kolowski said out of the four bone samples discovered earlier this year by Natalee's father Dave Holloway and private investor T.J. Ward, only one was human. 
Natalee Holloway missing for 10 years as family awaits news 
According to Dr. Kolowski, the identity of the person whose DNA was tested remains unknown. 
"We don't know if the person is male or female," he said. "We don't know how old that person is. We don't know how long that person has been dead." The mysterious disappearance of Natalee Holloway in Aruba 
In August, Holloway and Ward announced on NBC that an 18-month investigation had led to the discovery of remains buried behind a home in Aruba. 
Holloway said that an informant, only identified as "Gabriel," claimed to know someone who had direct knowledge of Natalee's disappearance. 
Remains found in Natalee Holloway case are of 'Caucasian' descent 
"We've chased a lot of leads and this one is by far the most credible lead I've seen in the last 12 years," Holloway said. "We have a person who states he was directly involved with Joran van der Sloot in disposing of Natalee's remains. I thought, you know, there may be something to this." 
Natalee was 18 when she vanished during a trip with friends to Aruba in 2005 to celebrate graduating high school. Joran van der Sloot has long been the prime suspect in the Alabama teen’s disappearance. (Karel Navarro/AP) 
The teen was last seen with Joran van der Sloot outside a tourist bar. 
Van der Sloot has long been the prime suspect but has never been charged in Natalee's disappearance due to a lack of evidence. He's currently serving a 28-year sentence in Peru for the murder of business student Stephany Flores. Tags:

thread.title: Las Vegas shooting survivor reunited with man who saved him
thread.title_full: Las Vegas shooting survivor reunited with man who saved him - NY Daily News

posts.author: Caitlyn Hitt
posts.title: Las Vegas shooting survivor reunited with man who saved him
posts.text:
From darkness comes a little bit of light.
After surviving the latest, deadliest mass shooting in United States history, which left at least 59 attendees of the Route 91 Harvest Festival dead and more than 500 injured, Tom McIntosh was reunited with the stranger he credits with saving his life on the " Today Show ."
"I wouldn't have (made it)," McIntosh, who was shot in the leg, told host Savannah Guthrie. "By the time I got over the wall, my pants were soaked and my shoes were full of blood. So I wouldn't have made it."
"I know I wouldn't have, so I'm very thankful that James was there to help me."
These are the victims of the Las Vegas massacre 
“Today Show” host Savannah Guthrie helped to reunite a Las Vegas shooting survivor with the man he says saved his life. (Today Show) The pair shared a tearful hug on air.
Ahead of their big meeting, McIntosh recalled the moments before he encountered James Lawson, telling Guthrie he was helping his wife and others over a wall when he was shot in the leg.
The wound immediately began bleeding and he was certain he was going to die.
Lawson used his belt as a tourniquet, stabilizing the bleeding until the pair were able to get to a vehicle and head for the hospital.
Hotel guest doors down from mass shooter relives the horror 
During his "Today Show" interview, McIntosh said he'd wanted to thank Lawson for all he'd done, but never got the chance.
Lawson credited his military training with helping him keep a level head during an otherwise chaotic situation.
Remembering the victims of the Las Vegas mass shooting "I've been in the Army Reserves for over 10 years now. We go through numerous combat lifesaver trainings," he said.
"I got EMT certified a while back and never did anything with it until the other night. I didn't go through all that semester for nothing."
Man hailed as hero in Vegas massacre has bullet lodged in neck 
The humble hero told Guthrie and those tuning into the "Today Show" after the attack that he was just one of many Route 91 Festival attendees lending a helping hand to others in need.
"There was dozens and dozens of other concert goers doing the same thing," he said.

posts.author: Manish Mehta
posts.title: Week 4 NFL Power Rankings: Undefeated Chiefs move to top
posts.text:
The upside-down edition of the power rankings includes a fourth No. 1 team in as many weeks, four newcomers, a team on the verge of disaster and a rookie quarterback making waves.
Week 4 Power Rankings:
Quarterback Alex Smith leaps toward Chiefs teammate Jordan Devey after a one-yard touchdown run in the third quarter against Washington. (Peter Aiken/Getty Images) 
1. Chiefs (4-0); Last week: 3 The league’s only undefeated team deserves the coveted top spot in our rankings. Alex Smith made some damn impressive throws in crunch time in a Monday night win over Washington. A primetime showdown against Deshaun Watson & Co. awaits in Houston.
2. Broncos (3-1); Last Week: 6 Another AFC West team? Yessir. Vance Joseph’s boys climb four spots and will enjoy their bye after beating the hated Raiders. Kansas City has overshadowed Denver’s hot start.
3. Packers (3-1); Last Week 5 Aaron Rodgers & Co. inch up a couple spots after dismantling the Bears Thursday night. A fun game in Big D is on the horizon.
4. Lions (3-1); Last Week 9 Detroit rockets up five spots into the Top 5 thanks to a gritty divisional win against the Vikings. If not for a last-second controversial video-replay induced heartbreaker a couple weeks ago, Matthew Stafford’s crew might be undefeated.
5. Steelers (3-1); Last Week: 8 Mike Tomlin’s team cracks the Top 5 after crushing the Ravens. They’re all alone atop the AFC North and ready to explode.
6. Falcons (3-1); Last week: 1 Matt Ryan’s crew tumbles out of the top spot with plenty of questions to answer during the bye week. Remember: Dan Quinn’s team came within a whisker of losing to the Bears in the season opener.

Panthers running back Fozzy Whittaker tries to elude Patriots linebacker Elandon Roberts. (Steven Senne/AP) 
7. Patriots (2-2); Last Week: 2 Tom Brady is still an ageless wonder, but can a 40-year-old Superman overcome this incredibly horrific defense? The Hoodie will have a short week to figure out how to plug all of New England’s defensive leaks.
8. Raiders (2-2); Last Week: 4 It seems like ages ago that Marshawn Lynch was getting jiggy with it on the sideline during a blowout win against the Jets. Oakland has gone backward since its hot start. Now, Derek Carr is out for 2-4 weeks with a broken bone in his back. Jack Del Rio better be careful or things could unravel quickly.
9. Eagles (3-1); Last Week 11 Well, well, well. America’s Team is not even the best team in the NFC East. That honor belongs to Carson Wentz & Co. (for now).
10. Buccaneers (2-1); Last Week: 10 The good news: Tampa Bay beat the Giants on a last-second field goal.
The bad news: Beating the hapless Giants doesn’t help you move up in our rankings.
11. Rams (3-1); Last Week: Unranked Los Angeles is all alone the NFC West just like everyone predicted. Or something like that. It’s amazing how Todd Gurley can be when he’s used in the right scheme.
12. Cowboys (2-2); Last Week: 7 How ‘bout them Cowboys?! Jerry Jones must be flummoxed at his boys after losing to the Rams at home. Aaron Rodgers is up next. Good luck, Jerrah.
13. Panthers (3-1); Last week: Unranked Yes, Carolina beat the Patriots. No, I’m still not sold. Let’s see how Cam Newton & Co. do in Detroit this week.

Bills defensive end Jerry Hughes walks off the field after beating the Falcons. (John Bazemore/AP) 
14. Bills (3-1); Last week: Unranked Could Sean McDermott’s club actually dethrone the Patriots in the AFC East? Uh, no. But give them credit for beating the Falcons on the road.
15. Texans (2-2); Last week: Unranked Could Deshaun Watson be for real? I need to see more.
* * *
NOTES: The Titans, Vikings, Jaguars and Washington dropped out of the Top 15.

posts.title: No Miguel Sano for Twins in wild-card showdown vs. Yankees
posts.text:
Slugger Miguel Sano, who had just returned late in the year after missing 38 games with a stress reaction in his left shin, is not on the Twins roster for Tuesday's AL wild-card game.
Sano hit 28 homers for Minnesota in 114 games during the regular season.
He struggled upon returning from the injury, going 1-for-8 with three strikeouts in the final three games of the year.
For the Yankees, the only move of note on the wild-card roster was having CC Sabathia over Jaime Garcia. Sabathia just pitched Saturday, but the Yankees could potentially use him to get one out or if there is an long, extra-innings game.

posts.text:
Country singer Jason Aldean spoke out against violence and called for Americans to come together a day after a gunman opened fire on the crowd during his performance at a Las Vegas music festival.
Las Vegas Shooting Victims 
The artist, 40, released a thorough second statement late Monday night expressing his devastation after at least 59 people were killed and more than 500 others were injured in the attack at the Route 91 Harvest in what was the deadliest mass shooting in modern American history.
"Over the last 24 hrs I have gone through lots of emotions," Aldean began in the statement, which he published on Instagram . "Scared, Anger, Heartache, Compassion and many others. I truely dont understand why a person would want to take the life of another."
