thread.title: Injured twin sisters recall how they survived Las Vegas shooting
thread.title_full: Injured twin sisters recall how they survived Las Vegas shooting

posts.author: Jessica Schladebeck
posts.title: Injured twin sisters recall how they survived Las Vegas shooting
posts.text:
Twin sisters both shot at Las Vegas music festival recall how they survived deadly mass shooting Injured twin sisters recall how they survived Las Vegas shooting NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 12:07 PM 
A pair of identical twin sisters held hands and prayed in the seconds before they were both shot by a lone gunman, who rained bullets down on an outdoor country music festival in Las Vegas. 
Gianna and Natalia Baca, both 17, told ABC News they initially thought the commotion was fireworks, set off during Jason Aldean’s set on the third day of the 91 Harvest Music Festival. Moments later, they were on the ground taking cover as “people just fell on top of each other ... there was blood everywhere,” Gianna recalled. Twin sisters Natalia and Gianna Baca were hit by gunfire during the Las Vegas shooting and were saved by off-duty firefighter Dean McAuley who happened to be attending the musical festival, Oct. 1, 2017. (GMA) 
When she was shot in the hip, her boyfriend helped her off the ground and pushed her to fight for survival — but she became separated from her sister. 
“We were just holding our heads, just praying and holding hands, and then I got hit,” Natalia told ABC. 
Vegas gunman possibly used add-on to make rifle almost automatic 
Her friend, Riley, stripped off his shirt and used it to apply pressure to the gunshot wound on her shoulder. They were able to make their way to a triage tent, where the came across Dean McAuley, an off-duty firefighter from Washington. 
He evaluated her injury as she started to go into shock and remained with her throughout the night. Mourners pay tribute to victims of Las Vegas massacre 
“He could have not acknowledged me in that tent. He was just a volunteer that was taking his time out of that night and saving people’s lives, and he didn’t have to but he is a very strong man and his family should be very proud of what he’s doing,” Natalia said. 
She’s currently in stable condition, but the bullet shattered inside her body and punctured her lung, according to the news station. She’ll likely need surgery. Her sister was hospitalized and is back home after being released on Monday. 
30 concertgoers hid in freezer during Las Vegas shooting 
McAuley recorded a video message to Natalia, sending her well wishes and praising her bravery in the face of chaos. 
“I am very proud of you and your strength and your ability to stay calm,” he told her. “I hope someday we can reconnect and I can give you a big hug.” Off-duty firefighter Dean McAuley helped the twins survive the deadly shooting. (GMA) 
The teens are among more than 500 injured in Sunday’s deadly shooting , which also left another 59 dead. The gunman has been identified as Stephen Paddock, a 64-year-old retired accountant who’d been living in a Nevada retirement community. 
Authorities said he died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound. Tags:

thread.title: Tom Petty wished he hadn't used Confederate flag on 1985 tour
thread.title_full: Tom Petty wished he hadn't used Confederate flag on 1985 tour

posts.author: PETER SBLENDORIO
posts.title: Tom Petty wished he hadn't used Confederate flag on 1985 tour
posts.text:
Tom Petty wished he hadn't used Confederate flag on 1985 tour: 'It was a downright stupid thing to do' Tom Petty wished he hadn't used Confederate flag on 1985 tour Tom Petty died Monday at 66. (Rob Grabowski/Rob Grabowski/Invision/AP) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 12:21 PM 
Late rock icon Tom Petty once admitted he wished he hadn't featured a Confederate flag at past concerts — 30 years after he prominently displayed the controversial Southern symbol throughout his 1985 tour. 
The Gainesville, Fla., native — who died Monday at 66, a day after going into cardiac arrest — told Rolling Stone in 2015 that he regretted using the flag during shows on his "Southern Accents" tour, contending he was "ignorant" about its true meaning. 
Some look at the flag, which was flown by the South during the Civil War, as a symbol of racism. 
"The Confederate flag was the wallpaper of the South when I was a kid growing up in Gainesville, Florida. I always knew it had to do with the Civil War, but the South had adopted it as its logo," he told the music outlet shortly after South Carolina officials opted to remove the flag from their statehouse. 
Tom Petty’s death draws attention to dangers of cardiac arrest 
"I was pretty ignorant of what it actually meant. It was on a flagpole in front of the courthouse and I often saw it in Western movies," he continued. "I just honestly didn't give it much thought, though I should have." 
Petty, who supported South Carolina's decision to take down the Confederate flag, said he used the flag as a marketing tool for the tour since it was meant to accompany his album about the South, also called "Southern Accents." Tom Petty wears a Confederate flag hat in the “Southern Accents” documentary in 1985. (youtube) 
He explained that a song on the album titled "Rebels" was about a Southerner who had adopted views from his forefathers. Petty felt at the time, he said, that the Confederate flag served as a representation of that created character. 
"I wish I had given it more thought," he said of using the flag on the tour. "It was a downright stupid thing to do." 
Tom Petty dead at 66 after going into cardiac arrest 
Petty also told the outlet that in 1987 he asked audience members to stop wearing Confederate garb to his concerts. 
"I noticed people in the audience wearing Confederate flag bandanas and things like that. One night, someone threw one onstage. I stopped everything and gave a speech about it. I said, 'Look, this was to illustrate a character. This is not who we are. Having gone through this, I would prefer it if no one would ever bring a Confederate flag to our shows again because this isn't who we are.'" Remembering the iconic life and career of Tom Petty 
He said he never saw a Confederate flag in his audience again. 
Petty's longtime manager confirmed his death on Monday night. The Rock and Roll Hall of Famer racked up three Grammy wins and 18 total nominations over the course of his legendary career. Tags:

thread.title: LUPICA: America can't wait for shootings to stop to talk guns
thread.title_full: LUPICA: America can't wait for shootings to stop to talk guns

posts.author: Mike Lupica
posts.title: LUPICA: America can't wait for shootings to stop to talk guns
posts.text:
In the aftermath of the worst mass shooting in modern U.S. history, we once again witness the phony rhetoric of death, so much of it from politicians who never do anything to make gun laws more sane in a country lousy and insane with guns. It was all as predictable as hearing that Monday wasn't the day to talk about guns, and that Tuesday probably wouldn't be such a good day, either, so close to what had just happened in Las Vegas.
But if you play out this kind of cockeyed thinking, from all those in Congress who genuflect in front of the National Rifle Association, from politicians and members of their pep squads who have pimped out the honorable and original intent of a Second Amendment originally written for muskets, there would never be a good day to have a gun debate in America. When would we find the time? We’ve averaged a mass shooting — one in which at least four people are shot — a day since Adam Lanza walked into Sandy Hook Elementary in Newtown, Conn. and murdered 20 children and six adults on Dec. 14, 2012.
We can’t wait for the gunfire to stop, because it doesn’t. Maybe we could have the conversation while the next active shooter is reloading.
America has averaged one mass shooting a day since Adam Lanza walked into Sandy Hook Elementary in Newtown and murdered 20 children and six adults in 2012. (Craig Warga/New York Daily News) Now it is Stephen Paddock in Las Vegas who kills more than twice as many as Lanza did, this time from the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, with enough weaponry in his hotel room to invade California. This Paddock reminds you of Jimmy Breslin’s description of Lee Harvey Oswald and his “scrambled egg brain” and the cheap rifle Oswald used to assassinate President John F. Kennedy. The difference, of course, between Oswald and Paddock is that the weaponry has become more expensive and sophisticated as our country has become this kind of killing field, at Sandy Hook Elementary and the Pulse nightclub in Orlando and Virginia Tech University and now an outdoor concert in Las Vegas where 59 are assassinated and more than 500 are injured.
Vegas gunman possibly used add-on to make rifle almost automatic 
And what we are once again supposed to believe, especially from members of Congress for whom any moment of silence at a terrible American moment like this is full of unintended irony and symbolism, that the answer is for them to do what they did after Sandy Hook and Virginia Tech and Orlando and all the others. It means hide under their desks.

thread.title: Decorated Navy SEAL dies in skydiving accident
thread.title_full: Decorated Navy SEAL dies in skydiving accident

posts.author: DAVID BOROFF
posts.title: Decorated Navy SEAL dies in skydiving accident
posts.text:
Decorated Navy SEAL dies in skydiving accident after jumping out of hot air balloon Decorated Navy SEAL dies in skydiving accident Navy SEAL Seth Stone earned two Silver Stars. He was killed in a skydiving accident on Saturday. (MC3 Michelle L. Kapica/U.S. Navy) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 11:36 AM 
A decorated Navy SEAL was killed in a recreational skydiving accident when his parachute failed to open properly after he jumped out of a hot air balloon, officials say. 
Cmdr. Seth Stone earned two Silver Stars, including one for leading wounded SEALs to safety following a firefight in Iraq in 2006. He also earned a Bronze Star and the Navy Marine Corps Commendation Medal. 
Rear Adm. Tim Szymanski, commander of the Naval Special Warfare Command, called Stone "one of our best." 
"Seth's absence will be sorely felt across the staff, command and the entire special operations community," Szymanski said. "NSW is a close-knit family and our primary focus is to provide care and support for Cmdr. Stone’s family." 
Navy ships honor new war heroes 
The tragic accident took place in the California city of Perris on Saturday while the 41-year-old Stone was off-duty. The FAA is investigating Stone's death. 
In 2006, Stone led his team against a "numerically superior enemy force" during the Battle of Ramadi in Iraq, according to the Naval Special Warfare Command. 
"As a Navy SEAL Cmdr. Stone epitomized the warrior ethos, risking his life on many occasions in combating our nations' enemies," according to the NSWC. "He saved countless U.S. service members, and helped bring stability to embattled regions of the world." 
At Ramadi, Stone led reinforcements while "simultaneously providing cover fire and dragging a critically wounded comrade to safety." 
Hillary Clinton urges Trump to send Navy to aid in Puerto Rico 
Another SEAL at Ramadi, Petty Officer Second-Class Michael Monsoor, sacrificed himself by throwing his body over a grenade and was posthumously awarded the Medal of Honor. 
Stone would later say that Monsoor's actions inspired him to later reenlist, according to the San Diego Union-Tribune . Stone died exactly 10 years and one day after Monsoor was killed. 
With News Wire Services

thread.title: ESPN staffer fired for Jeremy Lin headline now Catholic priest
thread.title_full: ESPN staffer fired for Jeremy Lin headline now Catholic priest

posts.author: EVAN GROSSMAN
posts.title: ESPN staffer fired for Jeremy Lin headline now Catholic priest
posts.text:
ESPN staffer fired for offensive Jeremy Lin headline now a Catholic priest ESPN staffer fired for Jeremy Lin headline now Catholic priest An offensive headline about Jeremy Lin during his time with the Knicks cost an ESPN staffer his job. (Mike Ehrmann) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 12:20 PM 
It was part of God's plan. At least that’s what Anthony Federico thinks may have happened. 
Federico, 33, the headline writer who was fired from ESPN in 2012 for making an offensive pun about former Knick Jeremy Lin has been born again as a Catholic priest. 
“Looking back, I think God allowed this to happen to me to put me on a path to being a priest, a path that I was avoiding,” Federico told the Washington Post . “I’ve never been happier.” 
Five years ago, Federico penned the headline “Chink in the Armor” atop a column about Lin. He claims it was an honest mistake, never meant to offend anyone, and realized soon after the story published the awful error he committed. 
Lin has lunch with fired ESPN headline writer 
ESPN received almost immediate blowback for the lapse in judgement. 
“I went to the bathroom and vomited,” Federico said of when he discovered his mistake . ESPN fired him soon after. 
Federico and Lin, who now plays for Brooklyn, had lunch after the incident and reportedly spoke mostly about religion. Lin is a Christian. The meeting set Federico on a completely different path, diverting far from sports journalism. For the last five years, he has been studying at Theological College, the seminary at Catholic University in Washington, D.C. He is on the verge of becoming a priest. 
Ironically, Federico had to go through hell to get there. 
Dedes goes unpunished at MSG Network 
“Everyone thinking of me as a bad person, an evil person — it was the worst 30 days of my life,” Federico said. “To think I could be in a place now where I’m genuinely happy with my life and excited about serving the people of God — if you told me that then, I wouldn’t have believed it. I think the thing that Jesus does best is second chances.” 
Federico regularly tells his story to parishioners in the hope they can find some inspiration or guidance in his own, twisting journey. 
“I do know that I want to be a Catholic priest more than anything in the world,” he said. “If being fired is what it took. … I can look back years later and say, ‘Thank you, God, for that.’” Tags:

thread.title: Parents say pole fell and struck infant while at NFL game
thread.title_full: Parents say pole fell and struck infant while at NFL game

posts.author: BRETT BODNER
posts.title: Parents say pole fell and struck infant while at NFL game
posts.text:
Parents want refund from Cardinals after a pole allegedly fell, struck their baby in the head Parents say pole fell and struck infant while at NFL game NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 11:35 AM 
A family tried to take their baby to his first football game, but instead ended up taking their infant to the hospital. 
Richard and Monique Trujillo, a family from Albuquerque, tried to take their three-month-old Julian to the Cardinals-49ers game Sunday in Arizona, but instead their baby had to be rushed to the hospital after a pole allegedly fell and struck the infant's head, ABC 15 reports . 
A metal pole was being torn down in a kids area before kick-off and ended up striking the baby on the side of the head, Richard told ABC 15. Julian had to spend five hours in the hospital. 
The couple claimed the University of Phoenix Stadium staff was not helpful. Richard said the workers seemed more concerned with getting their tickets scanned than providing aid to the infant, who was screaming and crying. 
Yanks mum on netting in first home game since girl hit by liner 
He said the stadium staff at first told him the family would be the ones financially responsible for the injury. 
"They [stadium] also told us it would not be covered and this would be on our hands and we'd have to cover it, but it was not our fault," Richard said. The Trujillos are not happy with the response of the staff at University of Phoenix Stadium after their baby was alledgedly struck with a pole at the Cardinals-49ers game Sunday. (ABC 15 Arizona) 
The father later spoke to the person in charge of stadium operations, who offered to pay for the medical expenses. Richard is also hoping the staff pays for the tickets to the game, hotel costs and the family's flight from Albuquerque. 
"To get him to his first game was a big thing. We were hoping to remember this for all the right reasons, not all the wrong reasons," Richard said. 
Cardinals spokesman Mark Dalton released a statement to ABC 15 following the incident. 
"We are obviously very concerned and feel terrible what happened to the Trujillo family during their visit to University of Phoenix Stadium. We are in the process of gathering the reports and other information from the individuals involved to understand exactly what took place," Dalton said. "We communicated with the family both Sunday and today to again express our concern and to let us know of any medical expenses as well as others incurred from missing the game so that we can reimburse them." Tags:

thread.title: Tyra Banks, Erik Asla call it quits after five years together
thread.title_full: Tyra Banks, Erik Asla call it quits after five years together

posts.author: CAITLYN HITT
posts.title: Tyra Banks, Erik Asla call it quits after five years together
posts.text:
Tyra Banks, Erik Asla call it quits after five years together Tyra Banks, Erik Asla call it quits after five years together Tyra Banks and longtime boyfriend Erik Asla have ended their relationship after five years together. (Michael Buckner/Getty Images for August Getty At) Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 11:50 AM 
We were rooting for you… 
Tyra Banks and Erik Asla have decided to go their separate ways, according to Us Weekly . Sources tell the publication there's not bad blood between the pair, who dated for five years. 
"She and Erik are friends. The break up was drama-free," the source told Us. 
Banks, 43, and Asla has been raising a baby boy together, whom they welcomed via surrogate in January 2016. 
It's unclear how the duo intend to co-parent in the wake of their alleged split. Us Weekly's source did, however, note that the "America's Next Top Model" host "loves being a mom and is very hands on." 
It does not appear parenting played a role in their decision to call it quits. 
Banks, who is notoriously private about both her son and her love life, opened up about son York Banks Asla's arrival in a heartfelt Instagram post shortly after his birth. 
She called their surrogate an "angel of a woman," revealing details about which features her little bundle of joy had inherited from which parent. 
Tyra Banks returns for ‘Life-Size’ sequel at Freeform 
"The best present we worked and prayed so hard for is finally here. He's got my fingers and big eyes and his daddy Erik's mouth and chin. As we thank the angel of a woman that carried our miracle baby boy for us, we pray for everyone who struggles to reach this joyous milestone," she wrote. 
"York Banks Asla, welcome to the world." 
Banks and her longtime beau met on the set of the Norwegian version of "Americas Next Top Model." Tags:

thread.title: First rifts emerge in Palestinian reconciliation talks - New York Daily News
thread.title_full: First rifts emerge in Palestinian reconciliation talks - New York Daily News

posts.title: First rifts emerge in Palestinian reconciliation talks - New York Daily News
posts.text:
First rifts emerge in Palestinian reconciliation talks First rifts emerge in Palestinian reconciliation talks facebook Palestinian Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah, center, chairs a reconciliation government cabinet meeting in Gaza City Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2017. The Palestinian prime minister has held the first government meeting in Gaza as part of a major reconciliation effort to end the 10-year rift between Fatah and the militant Hamas group. (Mohammed Abed/Pool Photo via AP) THE ASSOCIATED PRESS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 10:48 AM 
GAZA CITY, Gaza Strip (AP) — A new round of Palestinian reconciliation talks experienced its first sign of trouble on Tuesday as the Hamas militant group said it would not give up its vast weapons arsenal, putting it at odds with both the rival Fatah movement and Israel. 
The tough comments by Hamas' supreme leader, Ismail Haniyeh, provided a reminder of the long road that lies ahead after this week's launch of talks with President Mahmoud Abbas' Fatah movement. 
Abbas' prime minister, Rami Hamdallah, is in Gaza, where he has received a warm welcome in what is by far the most ambitious attempt by the Palestinian rivals to end a 10-year rift. But Hamdallah's visit is largely symbolic, and the negotiations on key sticking points, including the future of Hamas' military force, only start next week in Egypt. 
In a TV interview, Haniyeh said his group, which has fought three wars with Israel, would never give up its armed struggle against the Jewish state. 
"As long as there is occupation on the ground, our people have the right to possess weapons and resist the occupation with all forms of resistance," he told the private On TV station. 
In a gesture to Abbas, he said Hamas will not go back to war against Israel unilaterally. "We are ready to negotiate with the Palestinian factions and Fatah on unifying the decision of peace and war," he said. 
Such concessions are unlikely to satisfy Abbas, who issued his own tough statement late Monday saying "everything must be in the hands of the Palestinian Authority." 
He said specifically he would not agree to reproduce the "Hezbollah model" of Lebanon, where the armed militant group acts freely under the watch of a weak central government. 
Israel's prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, meanwhile, said his government will not accept a reconciliation deal between rival Palestinian factions that puts Israel at risk. Palestinian Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah waves to the media as he arrives to head the Cabinet session in Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas' former official resident in Gaza City, Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2017. Hamdallah has held the first government meeting in the Gaza Strip as part of a major reconciliation effort to end the 10-year rift between Fatah and Hamas. (AP Photo/ Khalil Hamra) 
He said any deal must include recognizing Israel, disbanding Hamas' military wing and cutting ties with Hamas' patron Iran. 
"We are not prepared to accept bogus reconciliations" in which the Palestinians reconcile "at the expense of our existence," he said. 
A day after his festive arrival, Hamdallah held his first Cabinet meeting in Gaza on Tuesday in another symbolic step toward reconciliation. His Cabinet ministers were then to head to their local offices to meet with staffers. 
Hamas, an Islamic militant group that seeks Israel's destruction, seized control of Gaza from Abbas' forces in 2007, leaving the Palestinians divided between rival governments in territories located on opposite sides of Israel. The division has been a major obstacle to Palestinian hopes of establishing an independent state. 
While previous reconciliation attempts have failed, years of international isolation and steadily worsening conditions in Gaza have pushed Hamas toward compromise. 
The real work begins next week in Cairo, where Egyptian mediators will host talks between the Palestinian rivals. There was no set time frame for the negotiations. 
Egyptian intelligence chief Khaled Fawzy arrived in Gaza on Tuesday to deliver a boost of support. It was the highest ranking Egyptian official to visit Gaza since 2007. 
"I'm convinced that you are able to implement your promises for the benefit of your people," he said. "I'm waiting for you in Cairo, your home, and you will do it and succeed. History will register that you have unified your people." Palestinian Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah, center, chairs a reconciliation government cabinet meeting in Gaza City Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2017. The Palestinian prime minister has held the first government meeting in Gaza as part of a major reconciliation effort to end the 10-year rift between Fatah and the militant Hamas group. (Mohammed Abed/Pool Photo via AP) 
Several factors appear to be working in favor of reconciliation. 
Under Hamas' watch, Gaza has fallen deeper into poverty, battered by a joint Israeli-Egyptian blockade and three devastating wars with Israel. Unemployment is estimated at over 40 percent, Gaza's 2 million residents are virtually barred from traveling abroad, and residents have electricity for only a few hours a day. 
Hamas' newly elected leadership has said it prefers to return to the group's roots as a "resistance" movement battling Israel. 
And perhaps most critically, Hamas has improved relations with Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi, who is poised to play a critical role as mediator. El-Sissi also has good ties with Israel and the U.S. and could help sell any deal to Netanyahu. 
In a videotaped speech delivered by his intelligence chief, el-Sissi called the reconciliation efforts "a historic day" and praised the "determination" of the sides to reach an agreement. 
"I sent the intelligence head to attend this occasion to emphasize that Egypt is eager to present all kinds of aid to accomplish the mission," he added. 
The question now is whether that Egyptian offer of help will be enough to get the sides to soften their positions.

thread.title: Tom Petty’s death draws attention to dangers of cardiac arrest
thread.title_full: Tom Petty’s death draws attention to dangers of cardiac arrest - NY Daily News

posts.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
posts.title: Tom Petty’s death draws attention to dangers of cardiac arrest
posts.text:
Tom Petty died Monday at age 66 in Los Angeles after going into cardiac arrest.
A form of heart disease — which kills around 630,000 Americans every year according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention — cardiac arrest occurs suddenly and often without notice.
“Cardiac arrest occurs when your heart abruptly stops beating due to a malfunction in the body’s electrical system,” says George Welch, M.D., a cardiologist with Manhattan Cardiology .
Tom Petty died Monday at age 66 in Los Angeles after going into cardiac arrest. (Owen Sweeney/Owen Sweeney/Invision/AP) “When the heart abruptly stops functioning you lose consciousness very quickly because blood is no longer pumped through the body,” Welch tells the Daily News. “With no blood flow to the brain, you collapse.”
Tom Petty dead at 66 after going into cardiac arrest 
The condition is different from a heart attack, which is caused by a blockage that stops blood flow to the heart. A heart attack — or myocardial infarction — refers to the “death of heart muscle tissue due to the loss of blood supply, which is irreversible,” says Welch. But it doesn’t necessarily result in the death of the heart attack victim.
Heeding heart health and risk factors can help prevent cardiac arrest. (stockcam/Getty Images/iStockphoto) The same factors that put someone at risk for heart disease increase the odds of cardiac arrest. The top five, says Welch, include high blood pressure, high cholesterol, family history of heart disease, diabetes and smoking.
Americans had more than 350,000 out-of-hospital cardiac arrests each year — and nearly 90% are fatal. Hugh Hefner died last week after suffering cardiac arrest and experiencing respiratory failure, according to a death certificate.
Remembering the iconic life and career of Tom Petty But with emergency medical attention, cardiac arrest can be reversed . When used within a few minutes, a defibrillator can shock the heart back into a normal rhythm.

"Big George" added that he's "put this out there for a while" and he's "not trolling," while also clarifying it would be strictly hand to hand, "no weapons."
Rep disputes Steven Seagal has agreed to take free Russian land 
A look at some of the most disappointing and overrated sports matchups over the years Showing that it wasn't just a passing thought, Foreman again reiterated Tuesday morning that he's serious about fighting "The Glimmer Man," saying, "This is true! I'm fighting just once more."
Meanwhile, there's been no word from the martial arts and goatee aficionado as to whether he's made an "Executive Decision" on the fight.
It's unknown what exactly prompted the brouhaha between the boxer and the "Belly of the Beast" star -- Foreman has only said his would-be opponent would be a "true fight" and there is "no anger involved" -- but the two at least have some common ground in their support of President Trump as well as their criticism of athletes who kneel in protest of police brutality.

thread.title: De Blasio officially names Cynthia Brann head of city jails
thread.title_full: De Blasio officially names Cynthia Brann head of city jails - NY Daily News

posts.author: Reuven Blau
posts.title: De Blasio officially names Cynthia Brann head of city jails
posts.text:
A controversial long shot has landed the top spot at the city’s Department of Correction — angering advocates pressing for the closure of Rikers Island.
Mayor de Blasio on Tuesday officially named Cynthia Brann commissioner of the department.
Brann, who spent 26 years in the Maine Department of Corrections, has been serving as acting commissioner ever since her old boss, Joseph Ponte, stepped down on May 12.
Ponte announced his resignation days after city investigators concluded he used his city-owned vehicle to drive to his home state of Maine, spending 90 days there last year.
Rikers inmate indicted for sexually assaulting two women in jail 
Brann and other top jail brass also got caught up in the scandal.
Probers said she used her city-issued car to make 18 trips to malls in New York and New Jersey last year, according to the Department of Investigations.
Brann was considered a longshot for the new job.
City Hall spokeswoman Natalie Grybauskas repeatedly denied Brann would even be named acting commissioner when Ponte resigned.
Correction officer attacked by four Bloods gang members at Rikers 
Brann — who worked in various leadership positions in the Maine correction system — beat out several applicants for the job.
Over the past few months, City Hall officials interviewed Dan Pacholke, a former prison boss from Washington State, as well as Vincent Schiraldi, a former city probation commissioner with close ties to the de Blasio administration.
“We looked far and wide, and there was nobody with the experience, knowledge, and commitment to reform that matched Commissioner Brann’s,” de Blasio said in a statement. “She’s been on the front lines enacting reform, adding rehabilitative programming, and ensuring the safety of staff and inmates. Under her steady leadership, I’m absolutely confident we will be able to build on the progress we’ve made.”
Glenn Martin, who has led the charge to shut down Rikers, blasted Brann’s promotion, saying it shows de Blasio is not serious about closing the scandal-scarred jails.
Rikers inmate knocks out guard with cell door, breaks his jaw 
Glenn Martin has led the charge to shut down Rikers. (Astrid Stawiarz/Getty Images) “De Blasio needed to pick someone outside of the Department of Corrections, someone willing to challenge the status quo,” Martin said in a statement. “Instead, he chose the acting commissioner, an insider who has spent the past several years trying to prop up a dying institution and placate the guard union.”
The union representing city correction officers has a good relationship with Brann.
Elias Husamudeen, president of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association, has touted her leadership since she took over.
“It is our hope that she has learned from (Ponte’s) failures and moving forward, will listen to the concerns and recommendations of the men and women who serve on the front lines of the city’s jails,” he said in a statement. “Meaningful jail reform can happen, but it won’t be successful without first demonstrating a commitment to making the jails safer for everyone.”
Daily News photo renews drone feud between L.I. teen, Rikers big 
Still, inmate advocates are furious.
Grace Price, a member of the Jails Action Coalition, pointed out that Brann has been in charge of the department’s move to come into compliance with the federal rules for the Prison Rape Elimination Act (PREA).
“She’s blown through multiple deadlines,” Price said. “There’s no reason she should be promoted for allowing people to continue to be raped on Rikers Island.”
During Brann’s tenure, the number of city inmates alleging sexual abuse and harassment by correction officers has more than quadrupled, records show.
Jail watchdog rips teens’ special housing as ‘terrible unit’ 
Complaints filed by detainees against jail staffers have surged to 772 in 2016, up from 163 in 2014, according to the city’s Board of Correction. There have been 418 similar allegations of assault filed this year.
Most of the cases are still being reviewed, records show.
The increase is in part tied to inmates now being allowed to make free calls to the city’s 311 complaint line, according to jail insiders.
But the department has failed to install cameras on buses or set up a screening system based for new detainees based on risk levels.
Cynthia Bran, who misused city car, to fill in as jails commish 
Jail officials say the screening system has been delayed by challenges tied to the creation of a “centralized, automated” computer system to input the data.
Without that system in place, someone who identifies as a woman can still be placed in a men’s housing unit, inmate advocates say.
“Their safety should not depend upon the fortuity of them finding Legal Aid or other advocates to catch DOC’s mistakes,” Legal Aid supervising attorney Dori Lewis told the city’s Board of Correction during a September meeting.
The board, which has oversight over the department, has repeatedly criticized jail officials for failing to conform to the federal standards despite years of promises.
Mayor says correction boss Ponte 'retired' after city car misuse 
During Brann’s tenure as a top boss, the department has experienced a major spike in violence despite millions of dollars spent on additional staff and inmate programs. The number of stabbing and slashings jumped by 26% in fiscal year 2017, from 131 in 2016 to 165 in 2017, records show. That’s the highest count in more than two decades, records show.
On Tuesday, de Blasio said he had no concerns about appointing someone caught up in the same car debacle as Ponte, saying it had nothing to do with the former jails boss’s departure.
“Commissioner Ponte had gotten to point where after years of service to the city and many, many years before that elsewhere that it was time for him to retire,” the mayor said.
Tags: bill de blasio rikers island cynthia brann Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: Political journalist Ross Barkan announces bid for state Senate
thread.title_full: Political journalist Ross Barkan announces bid for state Senate - NY Daily News

posts.author: Kenneth Lovett
posts.title: Political journalist Ross Barkan announces bid for state Senate
posts.text:
ALBANY - City political journalist Ross Barkan has decided to see politics from the other side — announcing Tuesday he will be running for state Senate against veteran Brooklyn Republican incumbent Martin Golden.
Barkan, 27, is a liberal Democrat who has written scathing pieces for the Village Voice, Observer and other publications about such political notables as Gov. Cuomo and a breakaway group of independent state Senate Democrats who are aligned with the chamber's Republicans.
"I've thought about it for a number of months," the Bay Ridge native told the Daily News. "Obviously I've been writing about state politics for a while and how it intersects with New York City in particular. I see just how much of our day-to-day existence is affected by what happens in the state Legislature."
He made the announcement that he is running against Golden on medium.com, saying he will focus on issues like health care, education, tenant protections and government reform.
Brooklyn state Sen. Martin Golden takes aim at illegal weapons 
"What I'm finding is, you can only try to hold the system accountable for so long from the outside," Barkan wrote. "Sometimes, you have to break in and do it from the inside. I know how to hold power to account. I understand why politicians do what they do, and why they fail. I know why most of them are cowardly."
In his interview with The News, Barkan said he hopes to continue his columns while campaigning.
"You'll see a campaign based on my values and vision, but I also want to do it as a way to show regular people what the political process looks like from the inside," he said. "I want to shine a light on the political process for my readers. We cover, but we don't really understand what it's like to be a candidate day to day. To be asking people for money, to knock on doors, to go to political clubs, to do the drudgery."
Barkan said he was not approached by any groups about running nor has he yet to speak to the state Senate Democratic Campaign Committee about backing or financing.
Pol's 'How to be a lady' class sparks furor 
He insists his run is real and not a publicity stunt. The late Jimmy Breslin once ran for City Council speaker while a Daily News columnist.
"I am serious about winning," Barkan said. "I think of this is a Jimmy Breslin move, but serious. Jimmy Breslin did not run to win."
He said Golden's district, while long represented by a Republican, has a Democratic registration advantage. And he said there is a lot of energy on the left because of President Trump and anger with the breakaway Senate Dems.
Barkan promised a non-traditional campaign, recognizing that he won't have hundreds of thousands of dollars to spend on consultants and mailings.
Pols: Cuff kid porn watchers 
Reached by phone, Golden, who in July reported having $457,172 in his campaign account, said it's too early in the process to be concerned about a Barkan run.
"There's nothing to say," Golden said. "Nobody knows him. You have to have some commitment to a community. They wouldn't know him if he was walking down the street. He has no presence in the community whatsoever."
Tags: new york state legislature martin golden ross barkan

posts.title: Las Vegas gunman sent $100G to Philippines days before massacre
posts.text:
Las Vegas gunman Stephen Paddock set up cameras to watch law enforcement approach his room Las Vegas gunman set up cameras to watch cops approach room NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated: Wednesday, October 4, 2017, 12:13 PM 
Las Vegas gunman Stephen Paddock’s hotel room held 23 lethal weapons, endless rounds of ammunition — and a video camera that he mounted on the door. 
The 64-year-old killer placed cameras inside and outside the 32nd-floor suite where he fired for nine minutes at 22,000 helpless concert attendees, officials said Tuesday. 
A pair of cameras was hidden on a room service cart from the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino left in the hallway. Another was attached to a peephole. 
“There were two cameras located in the hallway so that the suspect could watch as law enforcement or security approached his room,” said Clark County Undersheriff Kevin McMahill. “And there was another camera placed inside the hotel room door peephole so that he could see down the hallway.” 
MAP: Mass shootings in the United States since 2013 
Paddock executed at least 58 victims before killing himself. Officials said 527 people were injured. 
The mass shooter apparently placed most of the cameras in the hallway to detect any approaching cops or FBI agents. 
“There were cameras outside of the room and inside of the room, along with the firearms,” said Lombardo at an afternoon briefing. “I anticipate he was looking for anybody coming to take him into custody.” Marilou Danley (l.) is being sought for questioning in regards to the investigation into the Las Vegas mass shooter, Stephen Paddock (r.). (Las Vegas Metropolitan Police De) 
The early-warning system installed by Paddock apparently alerted him to the presence of a hotel security guard who was shot in the leg when Paddock fired at him through the door. 
Here are the stories of those victims gunned down in the Las Vegas massacre 
Two days after the massive carnage at the Route 91 Harvest Festival, police had yet to uncover a motive for the premeditated massacre. 
Lombardo remained certain that investigators will uncover what sent Paddock on the 80-mile ride from Mesquite, Nev., into Las Vegas with a small arsenal. 
“I expect a substantial amount of information to come in over the next 48 hours,” he added. 
One fellow gambler at a casino near Paddock’s home recounted a bizarre incident from a few months back when he shared a blackjack table with the shooter.

thread.title: Woman orders yoga mat, receives $400K worth of drugs instead

posts.title: Woman orders yoga mat, receives $400K worth of drugs instead
posts.text:
Woman orders yoga mat, receives box containing $400K worth of drugs instead Woman orders yoga mat, receives $400K worth of drugs instead Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 12:26 PM 
That's not what she ordered. 
A South Carolina woman was shocked when she opened up a package she received in the mail to find it contained a large bag of illegal drugs. 
The Rock Hill woman, who wanted to remain anonymous, said she met her mail carrier outside her home expecting to receive the yoga mat she had ordered. 
Instead, the woman was handed a heavy box and a bag of pills, which had spilled out of the package, ABC reports . 
According to WSOCTV , the box contained roughly 20,000 oxycodone pills worth an estimated $400,000. 
The woman said she immediately called police. A South Carolina accidentally received $400,000 worth of drugs in the mail. (WSOC-TV) 
York County drug agents told the outlet that the box was shipped from Newport Beach, California. 
Drug unit commander Marvin Brown said that the drugs are usually shipped to "vacant apartments [and] homes where people have gone to work for the day." 
Police seize 677 pounds of drugs after domestic disturbance call 
He said the pickup person waits outside the home to accept the package. 
Brown said he thinks whoever mailed the box most likely meant to send it to the woman's old address because no one is living there. 
However, the street was misspelled on the package so the post office found the woman's current address and forwarded it to her. 
"The dealers weren't as intelligent as they thought they were," he said. 
The pills have all been taken into evidence by the Rock Hill Police Department. The narcotics team said it will try and trace the package to find out who sent it and who was supposed to receive it. Tags:

Florida man fatally shoots 22-year-old son while cleaning weapon after visit to gun range Florida man fatally shoots son while cleaning gun NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 3:00 PM 
A Florida man fatally shot his 22-year-old son while cleaning a gun on Saturday, authorities say. 
Joshua Jordan's father was cleaning his .45-caliber handgun at a Port Charlotte home after returning from a local gun range when the firearm discharged and struck Jordan. Joshua Jordan was fatally shot by his father on Saturday in what authorities are calling an accident. (Facebook) 
Cops arrived on the scene to find the Joshua Jordan lying on his back in a "pool of blood" while John and Jennifer Jordan were performing CPR. 
Joshua Jordan was taken to a nearby hospital, where he was pronounced dead. 
Girl, 2, accidentally shot by father cleaning gun 
The Charlotte County Sheriff's Office says the shooting was an accident, and no charges were immediately filed. 
A weapons expert told local TV station Fox 4 that he has seen this tragedy play out too many times, and offered a series of tips. The scene of Saturday's shooting in Florida. (WFTX) 
"Number one, treat every firearm as if it’s loaded," John Dezendorf told the station. "Number two, do not point it in the direction that you are not willing to destroy. Number 3, don’t you put your finger on that trigger until you have acquired your target and you want to shoot your firearm."

thread.title: MTA expanding E train car capacity to fit 10 more straphangers
thread.title_full: MTA expanding E train car capacity to fit 10 more straphangers - NY Daily News

posts.author: Dan Rivoli
posts.title: MTA expanding E train car capacity to fit 10 more straphangers
posts.text:
E train riders are about to have more company on their commute — but there will also be more room.
Remodeled train cars that hit the E line Tuesday could pack in up to 10 more people apiece, now that the MTA removed seating from each end of the car.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority sent out two sets of 10-car trains made up of the reconfigured R160 model as part of agency chairman Joe Lhota’s $836 million plan to stabilize the subway. By the end of the month, 100 cars will be rolling along the E line, which runs on the second-busiest subway corridor on Queens Blvd. into Eighth Ave. in Manhattan.
Among the other changes that’ll catch commuters’ eyes — floor-to-ceiling art, digital screens and more poles to grab on the inside. The exterior got a paint job with gold, silver, blue and black stripes.
MTA may cut $836M subway repair work if de Blasio doesn’t pay up 
“Providing a safe and reliable ride is what our customers demand and what the MTA is determined to deliver through our subway action plan,” Lhota said in a statement. “We do not have time to waste when it comes to improving the customer experience and service for our riders.
“This pilot goes directly to the heart of that goal by attacking a significant cause of failures on these cars and making a fast, targeted improvement. We also know that getting more passengers onto trains, in a more efficient manner, is absolutely essential — which is why we’re piloting the removal of select number of seats.”
Lhota, in unveiling his plan to fix the subway in July, raised the possibility of taking out seats on some cars on the L line and the 42nd St. shuttle.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority sent out two sets of 10-car trains made up of the reconfigured R160 model as part of agency chairman Joe Lhota’s $836 million plan to stabilize the subway. (MTA) Among the other changes that’ll catch commuters’ eyes — floor-to-ceiling art, LCD lights and screens and more poles to grab on the inside. (MTA) Among the other changes that’ll catch commuters’ eyes — floor-to-ceiling art, LCD lights and screens and more poles to grab on the inside.
As the MTA remodeled the cars, crews replaced the train’s controllers, the accelerating and braking equipment that had been breaking down the most on this model.
Transit watchdogs urge state, city to fix lousy MTA bus service 
“It would fail to control the speed, acceleration or braking of the car,” Phil Eng, the MTA’s chief operating officer, told the Daily News. “So we would have to then take them out of service.”
The R160 model that debuted in 2006 — made by Kawasaki and Alstom — rolls on 10 lines and travels more than 232,000 miles on average before a breakdown. That’s down 24% from a year ago.
Eng said the MTA added crews to its maintenance yards, from five days to seven days a week, three shifts a day.
“All the fleets that we have we’ve identified the components that have failed most frequently,” Eng said.
MTA to launch dashboard for riders to track subway performance 
Officials would not disclose how much the remodeling cost, saying Lhota plans to detail his subway spending later this month to the MTA board.
Tags: mta

thread.title: Vegas gunman possibly used add-on to make rifle almost automatic
thread.title_full: Vegas gunman possibly used add-on to make rifle almost automatic - NY Daily News

posts.author: Terence Cullen
posts.title: Vegas gunman possibly used add-on to make rifle almost automatic
posts.text:
NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated: Wednesday, October 4, 2017, 1:39 AM 
A gadget costing as little as $100 — readily available and entirely legal — turned a rumpled former accountant into a hyperefficient killing machine on the Las Vegas Strip. 
Stephen Paddock used at least 12 of the so-called bump or slider stocks to turn semiautomatic rifles into supremely more deadly weapons by sharply boosting their rate of fire, officials said. 
From his perch on the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, Paddock unleashed nine bullets per second on the crowd below, slaughtering at least 58 people. Bullets flew close to the rate of a machine gun, and much faster than the already lethal power of a semiautomatic rifle. 
Although federal laws bar automatic weapons, gun dealers are free to peddle the stocks despite their potential use for mass murder. 
Here are the stories of those victims gunned down in the Las Vegas massacre 
The federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives approved the devices in 2010 even though one manufacturer, Texas-based Slide Fire Inc. claimed the purpose of the stocks was to assist “people with limited mobility of the hands,” records show. 
“Obviously, they know better. When it comes down to it, everything is about money,” said Billy King, 38, who was shot in the back Sunday night in Sin City while shielding his wife. “The more they can get it sold, of course they’re going to sell it.” 
“It’s like smoke shops. They carry certain glassware and say it’s used for tobacco, but everyone knows most of the sales are for marijuana,” said the married father of four from Las Vegas who is still hospitalized. A bump or slider stock is pictured attached to this firearm. The device allows a semi-automatic weapon to fire at a rate similar to an automatic. (Allen Breed/AP) 
He was one of 527 people injured — either shot, or hurt in the ensuing chaos — as 22,000 people scurried for safety at a country music concert. 
MAP: Mass shootings in the United States since 2013 
Ari Freilich, the staff attorney for the Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence, scoffed at Slide Fire’s claim, saying the device has no redeeming qualities. 
“It has no defensive purpose or hunting utility,” he said. “Its purpose is purely offensive: to shoot as many bullets and kill as many people as possible in a short amount of time.” 
Paddock pumped the bullets from his suite about 1,200 feet from the concert floor. 
The shooter, who owned dozens of guns, apparently “preplanned extensively” for the attack, Clark County Sheriff Joe Lombardo said. 
Paddock owned at least 47 guns purchased in four states. He had at least 23 weapons in his hotel room, mostly rifles, officials said. Las Vegas shooter Stephen Paddock used a bump to turn into a killing machine. (John Raoux/AP) 
To put it in context, Omar Mateen, the gunman who killed 49 people at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando last year, fired 24 shots in nine seconds from a semiautomatic rifle. 
Paddock, using the bump stock, fired 90 shots in a 10-second period, close to the rate of a machine gun, which is 98 shots in seven seconds. 
Bump stocks replace the factory stock on different types of rifles, including the AR-15- and AK-47-style guns used by Paddock, and function using the recoil of the rifles to accelerate the rate of fire. 
SEE IT: Look inside Stephen Paddock’s room shows guns, shells 
The shooter puts his or her finger just in front of the trigger while constantly pushing the rifle forward with the other hand. 
The gun recoils after the first round goes off, literally bumping back into the stock, and then moves forward again from the pressure. 
Online listings show the attachments typically sell for $100 to $300. Paddock fired onto a concert crowd from a window on the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino. 
Slide Fire calls its products a “game changer,” and boasts, “The command and control behind the Slide Fire stock will create an exhilarating experience that keeps you smiling for days.” 
GoFundMe for Las Vegas massacre victims raises more than $3.2M 
It’s not clear which company Paddock bought his stocks from. 
In a 2010 letter written by a Justice Department lawyer, the Slide Fire bump stock, designed by Jeremiah Cottle, was approved for use. The lawyer, John Spencer, assigned to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, said in the letter that the company claimed its purpose was “to assist persons whose hands have limited mobility.” 
Six years later, however, Cottle gave a whole different description for the purpose of the device. “Some people like drag racing, some people like skiing and some people, like me, love full auto,” he told the Ammoland website. 
“Slide Fire brings shooters the same full auto experience but without having to take out a second mortgage on their home.” 
Cottle has insisted over the years his device — despite the rapid fire it generates — does not create machine guns. Cops are investigating whether Paddock used the bump stock rifles in the massacre. (John Locher/AP) 
“It is not automatic. Nothing is automatic,” he told GunsAmerica in 2011 . 
“You actively fire every round, and if you stop pushing forward or you take your finger off the trigger, the gun stops firing. It just helps you fire the gun in semiautomatic very fast.” 
The ATF, meanwhile, has repeatedly taken the position that the device requires more than one trigger pull, so it is not an automatic weapon. 
Jason Aldean calls for unity after Las Vegas massacre 
Automatic weapons and silencers have been illegal for civilian use since 1986, and the mechanics of a semiautomatic can’t be altered to increase the speed of fire. 
“The (bureau) is interpreting the federal definition of a machine gun. Of course, they could change their interpretation,” Freilich said. “In practice, it’s essentially the same thing.” 
Bump stocks could have become illegal under the proposed 2013 ban on assault weapons in the wake of the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre.

thread.title: Trump arrives in a Puerto Rico still struggling for survival
thread.title_full: Trump arrives in a Puerto Rico still struggling for survival - NY Daily News

posts.author: Jason Silverstein
posts.title: Trump arrives in a Puerto Rico still struggling for survival
posts.text:
President Trump arrives in a Puerto Rico still struggling for survival and basic resources Trump arrives in a Puerto Rico still struggling for survival NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 2:20 PM 
As President Trump complains about Puerto Rico’s recovery costs, the island is still struggling for basic survival. 
Trump on Tuesday touched down in the U.S. territory nearly two weeks after Hurricane Maria hit, leaving the island with a trail of death and destruction like none it has ever seen. Much of the worst of the damage still lingered by the time Trump arrived. Destroyed communities in Toa Alta. (Gerald Herbert/AP) 
Trump came to an island where 95% of electricity customers still do not have power — including several hospitals. Puerto Rico at one point lost 100% of its power. According to data from Puerto Rico Gov. Ricardo Rosselló, only about 15% of the island's cell towers are functional. 
Less than half of Puerto Rico’s 3.4 million citizens have running water, and food and supplies remain scarce for homes and hospitals alike. Nearly one-third of its 1,100 gas stations are closed, as are almost half of its 456 grocery stores. Only 50% of the major roadways have been cleared. 
Trump blames Puerto Rico for throwing budget ‘out of whack’ 
At least 16 people have died due to the storm. Trump on Tuesday said Puerto Rico should be “very proud” of that death toll, since it is much lower than the number of casualties from Hurricane Katrina, which killed more than 1,800 people in 2006. 
The Trump administration has deployed about 4,500 U.S. troops on the ground in Puerto Rico, which another 1,400 National Guard members arriving. 
Congress has not approved a recovery package for Puerto Rico and a final estimate for the damages has not been determined. Tags:

thread.title: Nevada's machine gun ranges show how much the state loves guns
thread.title_full: Nevada's machine gun ranges show how much the state loves guns - NY Daily News

posts.author: Terence Cullen
posts.title: Nevada's machine gun ranges show how much the state loves guns
posts.text:
Nevada's machine gun ranges show how much the state loves its guns Nevada's machine gun ranges show how much the state loves guns NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 1:22 PM 
Machine gun ranges have become just as much a grab on the Las Vegas Strip as gambling, fine dining and concerts. 
Several established ranges are based on the strip, offering visitors the opportunity to fire World War II-era, belt-fed machine guns or from a moving helicopter. 
But after gunman Stephen Paddock killed 59 concertgoers this Sunday on the Stip — the deadliest mass shooting in modern U.S. history — at least one shooting range closed its doors in support of the victims. 
Machine Gun Vegas, a range on the Strip, decided not to open Monday and Tuesday “in respect for the injured, lives lost and families affected by this senseless act.” Machine Guns Vegas, which allows customers to shoot from a helicopter, closed Monday and Tuesday out of respect for the mass shooting. (Machine Gun Vegas via YouTube) 
“There were many factors contributing to this tragic event, but there is no doubt that the shooter's ability to inflict so many casualties was heavily due to the types of weapons he had access to,” reads a press release from Machine Gun Vegas. 
“We believe that responsible gun ownership is attainable through the application of common sense, more stringent vetting and background checks, dramatically increased mandatory sentencing for gun offences and increased testing standards for gun owners.” 
Among the experiences Machine Gun Vegas offers is an indoor SEAL Team 6 package that allows users to shoot like members of the elite Navy unit. Another package allows a party of three or less to fire 300 rounds from a helicopter for $2,999. 
Mean Girls Day brings cast together to support Las Vegas victims 
Highlighting its arsenal is an M-134, better known as a mini-gun, which can fire 4,000 rounds per minute. 
The range says it has the only one of its kind for public use in “Sin City,” with the 100 rounds costing $199. At least 59 people were killed and more than 500 wounded during Sunday night's carnage. (STEVE MARCUS/REUTERS) 
“Battlefield Vegas has no comment at this time regarding the events or anything of the following,” a representative told the Daily News. 
Another attraction is “Bullets and Burgers,” which is open to customers age 12 and up. Like the competitors, it offers a wide arsenal of firearms able to shoot out in the Nevada desert. Once the shooting is done, guests are treated to burgers, fries and a soda. 
Its arsenal includes the AK-47 — one of the most popular guns in the world — along with a Barret .50-caliber rifle commonly used by military snipers. Machine Guns Vegas' Machine Gun Helicopter experience starts at $2,999. (Machine Gun Vegas via YouTube) 
Bullets and Burgers was closed Monday, a spokesperson told USA Today , but declined to say if the closure was in connection with the shooting. The range didn't immediately comment on Tuesday. 
It's unclear how Paddock attained the 42 firearms recovered from his hotel room and Nevada home. But Sunday's carnage is likely to spark a new debate about gun control throughout the U.S. 
Nevada had a firearm death rate of 14.9 — 446 fatalities — in 2015, the most recent year data is available from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. That’s nearly four points higher than the national average, which was 11.1 for all 50 states in 2015. 
The state is also the eight-most armed in the union, according to data compiled by CBS News. There are 54,436 registered guns for the state's population of 2,790,136. Tags:

thread.title: Manning and Rivers, forever linked, to meet in ‘The 0-4 Bowl'
thread.title_full: Manning and Rivers, forever linked, to meet in ‘The 0-4 Bowl' - NY Daily News

posts.author: Pat Leonard
posts.title: Manning and Rivers, forever linked, to meet in ‘The 0-4 Bowl'
posts.text:
The Giants drafted Philip Rivers fourth overall in 2004 and traded him to the Chargers for first overall pick Eli Manning, and now all these years later Rivers and Manning will meet in “The 0-4 Bowl” on Sunday at MetLife Stadium.
The 0-4 Giants and 0-4 L.A. Chargers are among the NFL’s four current 0-4 teams. Manning and Rivers already were linked forever by the number four due to their dramatic ’04 draft day swap, but they would rather dodge this connection with the digit:
Sunday’s game will mark the first meeting of two NFL teams 0-4 or worse since — you guessed it — 2004, per Elias Sports Bureau, when the 0-4 Bills defeated the 0-5 Dolphins, 20-13, on Oct. 17 in Buffalo.
The trade of Manning for Rivers, of course, changed the course of NFL history and occurred — when else — not on the 23rd or 25th but the 24th of April 2004. And the drama and theater that played out at The Theater at Madison Square Garden, not far from the bright lights of Broadway, was unforgettable and changed the courses of two franchises.
Giants Insider: Marshall hasn't looked capable during 0-4 start 
In 2004, Manning had told the Chargers he didn’t want to play for them and would sit out the season if they picked him first overall. Chargers GM A.J. Smith drafted Manning anyway, already aware the Giants wanted Manning, having discussed a possible trade with Giants GM Ernie Accorsi the night before. And the Chargers liked the idea of drafting and dealing Manning because they didn’t want him falling to the rival Raiders.
Accorsi knew the Chargers liked Rivers, but he still entered draft day convinced he wasn’t getting Manning because on Friday night, when he offered the Chargers a No. 1 pick swap and the Giants’ No. 3 in 2004 No. 2 in 2005, Smith responded with demands that Accorsi called “way too steep”: the Giants’ No. 1, 2 and 3 picks that Saturday, plus their No. 1 the following year and defensive end Osi Umenyiora.
Eli Manning holds a San Diego Chargers jersey after they selected him No. 1 overall in the 2004 NFL draft. (John Marshall Mantel/AP) A game of high-stakes chicken followed over the next 18 hours.
Accorsi wouldn’t call Smith back on the unreasonable counter-offer and didn’t get a call from Smith until the Giants were on the clock fourth overall, after Manning (Chargers), Iowa tackle Robert Gallery (Raiders) and Larry Fitzgerald (Cardinals) came off the board.
Giants coach Ben McAdoo says team ‘can’t go numb' 
When the Chargers took Manning, he still walked on stage, shook hands with NFL commissioner Paul Tagliabue and held up a blue Chargers No. 1 jersey. Two minutes later Manning was saying he wanted the Chargers to trade him, only to find out from a random kid in a hallway that the Giants had traded for him shortly after.
Manning was a San Diego Charger for one hour and thankful for the trade to New York.
“I am happy,” Manning said of joining the Giants. “I never expected it to happen.”
The Giants ended up getting Manning for Rivers, their No. 3 pick that year and their No. 1 and 5 picks in 2005. They protected Umenyiora and their 2004 second-round pick that became guard Chris Snee.
Giants need to fire GM Jerry Reese 
They also had entertained an offer from the Browns, however, looking to move up from No. 7. Cleveland later gave up a second-rounder to the Lions to move up one spot and take tight end Kellen Winslow.
The Giants would have moved down and taken Miami (Ohio) QB Ben Roethlisberger at No. 7. But they liked Roethlisberger and they loved Manning. And the rest is history.
Eli Manning: The many faces of the Giants quarterback Manning took the Giants’ reins in Week 11 of his 2004 rookie year and has started every game since. That includes an NFL-high 203 consecutive regular season starts among active players. He is even closing in on his older brother Peyton (208 straight for the Colts, 1998-2010), while Brett Favre’s 287-game streak for the Packers, Jets and Vikings (1992-2010) remains the gold standard.
It took Rivers until his third NFL season of 2006 — after Brees’ signing with New Orleans in free agency — to assume the starter’s role. But since, Rivers also has been the example of durability, making 180 consecutive regular season starts for the Chargers.
There’s plenty of blame to go around for Giants’ 0-4 start 
Manning, who turns 37 in January, has thrown for 49,327 career yards, 326 TDs and 219 INTs with a career 83.9 QB rating. Rivers, who turns 36 in December, has thrown for 46,940 career yards, 320 TDs and 160 INTs with a career 94.6 QB rating.
Manning is winless against the Chargers in his three career meetings with the franchise that once drafted him first overall despite a respectable 96.7 passer rating, with 69 completions on 106 attempts (65% completion), five TD passes, two interceptions against them. He was of course booed lustily in his first trip to San Diego on Sept. 25, 2005, when he threw for 352 yards, two TDs and no INTs but the Giants were thumped, 45-23.
Eli Manning holds up his new Giants jersey as he poses with then-coach Tom Coughlin and then-GM Ernie Accorsi. (BILL KOSTROUN/AP) Rivers and Manning have met head-to-head only twice, though, with Rivers an undefeated 2-0, because Brees was still the Chargers’ quarterback for that 2005 meeting.
On Nov. 8, 2009, Rivers (24-of-36, 209 yards, 3 TDs, 2 INTs) threw a game-winning TD pass to Vincent Jackson with 21 seconds remaining to beat Manning (25-of-33, 215 yards, 2 TD) and the host Giants, 21-20. On Dec. 8, 2013, Rivers (21-of-28, 249 yards, 3 TDs) and the host Chargers beat Manning (20-of-32, 259 yards, 1 TD, 2 INT) and the Giants, 37-14.
Giants' Olivier Vernon kneels during national anthem 
But of course, Manning holds the two trump cards: He has brought the Giants two Super Bowls in 2007 and 2011, while the Chargers are still looking for one with Rivers.
Now on Sunday, they will battle for a new Bowl: “The 0-4 Bowl” at MetLife Stadium. And in what likely could be their final head-to-head meeting, neither Manning nor Rivers wants to make history this time around.
Tags: nfl new york giants eli manning los angeles chargers philip rivers nfl draft Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: New Yorkers pay the second highest ATM fees in the country
thread.title_full: New Yorkers pay the second highest ATM fees in the country - NY Daily News

posts.author: Constance Gibbs
posts.title: New Yorkers pay the second highest ATM fees in the country
posts.text:
Americans are getting robbed by their own ATMs.
ATM fees have reached an 11-year record high, and New Yorkers are paying the second highest rates, says Bankrate’s annual Checking Account Survey for 2017 .
The site surveyed 10 banks and savings and loans associations in each of 25 large U.S. markets from July to August 2017 and found that bank fees are up 2.6% from the previous year.
The national average ATM fee is $4.69, equaling the average ATM surcharge of $2.97 plus the average out-of-network fee your main bank charges of $1.72.
Senator wants banks to post signs warning on illegal ATM skimmers 
Cities whose fees top over $5 include Pittsburgh ($5.19), New York ($5.14), Washington, D.C. ($5.11), Cleveland ($5.11) and Atlanta ($5.05).
Even the lowest fees still don’t drop below $4 with Milwaukee at $4.19 and Dallas at $4.07.
ATM fees are flying through the roof and there are few regulations to stop them from going higher. (simonkr/Getty Images) Overall, ATM withdrawal fees have risen by 55% over the last ten years and there is little to curb this growth. According to CNBC , “there is no regulatory limit on what banks can charge for service fees on deposit accounts.”
Bankrate suggests using cashback options on debit purchases where you can find it. Some banks have no out-of-network fees but charge a monthly ATM surcharge every month, and that doesn’t exclude you from paying the ATM’s fee. Bankrate also suggests that those who are moving to areas with low saturation of their bank may want to reach out to the bank to see if they will waive its fee.
Man trapped behind ATM sends pleas for help through receipt slot 
Bank ATM and overdraft fees are reaching record highs. (Filippo Bacci) Customers are also facing increased overdraft fees, with the national average being $33.38, up from just over $20 twenty years ago.
Bankrate suggests to opt out of overdraft protection, so instead of being charged a fee when you’re out of money, your card is simply declined. Bankrate also says that if it’s a one-time deal, try calling the bank to see if they’ll waive it.
“Most banks will waive (an overdraft fee) once a year,” Andrea Woroch, a personal finance expert who is working with Marcus, Goldman Sachs’ online lender, told Bankrate.
The ATM just celebrated its 50th anniversary — aside from a few preliminary machines in Japan and New York, the first official cash machine was installed in Enfield London in June of 1967.

thread.title: We can thank early humans for the modern-day genital herpes virus
thread.title_full: We can thank early humans for the modern-day genital herpes virus - NY Daily News

posts.author: Ariel Scotti
posts.title: We can thank early humans for the modern-day genital herpes virus
posts.text:
facebook The oral herpes virus (HSV-1) was passed onto humans from the ancient chimpanzees that we evolved from when our lineage split and we possibly would have missed out on genital herpes (HSV-2) if it wasn't for an encounter between our ancient ancestors. (Print Collector/Print Collector/Getty Images) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated: Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 1:49 PM 
The oral herpes virus (HSV-1) was passed onto humans from the ancient chimpanzees we evolved from when our lineage split, and we possibly would have missed out on genital herpes (HSV-2) if it wasn't for an encounter between our ancient ancestors. 
Between 1.4 million and 3 million years ago in Africa, ancient chimpanzees, Homo erectus and an early human species of evolution between the two, Paranthropus boisei, all lived at the same time, according to a new study published in the journal Virus Evolution . 
The transfer of the dreaded virus had to happen through a one-off, chance exchange of fluids, the study said, — first, through bites or scratches from the original culprit, the chimpanzee, then by sexual intercourse between the two human species, Homo erectus eating boisei, or both. 
"We can 'blame' our ancestors for eating other hominins/great apes, this has been the source of other primate-to-human infections such as HIV," the study's senior author Charlotte Houldcroft told CNN . "Eating other species closely related to oneself has risks, because pathogens adapted to species genetically similar to us will find it easier to jump the species barrier." 
Jim Carrey says ex used bad wax job to blame him for herpes 
Data of ancient climates, fossils and herpes DNA were studied by a team of virologists, engineers and human evolution researchers to create a model — called a Bayesian network — that determines the likelihood of HSV-2's transmission from apes to humans. The transfer of the dreaded virus had to happen through a one-off, chance exchange of fluids, the study said, - first, through bites or scratches from the original culprit, the chimpanzee, then by sexual intercourse between the two human species, Homo erectus eating boisei, or both. (BSIP/UIG via Getty Images) 
"We can use data from diseases to reconstruct events that are completely invisible to the archaeological and fossil records," Houldcroft told the news site . "The signals in the HSV-2 virus are records of direct contact between the ancestors of us and chimps that we can tangibly now 'see' and gives us direct insight into the daily lives of our ancestors." 
Today, the World Health Organization estimates that about two-thirds or adults under 50-years-old are infected with oral herpes and one in six have the genital strain. There are more than 100 different kinds of herpes and eight of them can infect humans and cause diseases like chickenpox and mononucleosis, but the oral and genital types are incurable and almost always sexually transmitted. 
Genetically, the most diverse strains of genital herpes comes out of Africa, so the researchers said that a migration out of the continent is responsible for the world-wide effect the virus has on our current population. 
Usher accuser responds to claim she 'assumed the risk of harm' 
"Essentially, when humans migrated out of Africa, they already carried HSV-2, and wherever humans went, their viruses went too," Houldcroft said. "HSV-2 infects for life and can be passed from mother to baby or between sexual partners, which made sure it successfully spread wherever humans did." 
"They're writing the history," infectious disease expert and evolutionary biologist Joel Wertheim told the Washington Post . "Understanding where these ancient pathogens came from and how they got into humans can help us understand where our future pandemics will likely arise." Tags:

thread.title: This restaurant serves up boxes for your phone while you eat
thread.title_full: This restaurant serves up boxes for your phone while you eat - NY Daily News

posts.author: Ariel Scotti
posts.title: This restaurant serves up boxes for your phone while you eat
posts.text:
This restaurant serves up boxes to deposit your phone while you eat This restaurant serves up boxes for your phone while you eat "If there's one time in the 24 hours in your day that's a time to engage with the person you're with, it makes sense to me that it's around the dinner table," the chef said. (PeopleImages/Getty Images) Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 12:59 PM 
Disconnecting from your phone while dinning at Hearth is completely up to you. 
The 13-year-old Lower East Side restaurant Hearth now matches its linens and glassware to old-fashioned cigar boxes adorned with "Open Me!" signs that invite guests to deposit their phones during meals. The boxes are the restaurant's James Beard award-winning chef's, Marco Canora, solution to modern technology's disruption of the dining experience. 
"If there's one time in the 24 hours in your day that's a time to engage with the person you're with, it makes sense to me that it's around the dinner table," Canora told Eater. 
Canora told the foodie site that he, personally, doesn't mind if people pull out their devices while eating at his restaurant but after tracking his own usage via an app, he was alarmed by how many hours he spent staring at a screen and decided to offer his customers a way to unplug. Unlike other eateries that have established phone bans or offer discounts to voluntary cord-cutters, Hearth's phone boxes are merely a suggestion. 
"The hope is that you sit down, you get your menus, and then you're like, 'What is this box?'" Canora said . "And then you open the box and there's this very simple note. If you want to do it you can do it, if you don't want to do it, don't. It's just a box on the table that's there if you want it." 
And the note reads, "We'd like to invite you to unplug during your meal here at Hearth. Feel free to use this box, put your phone away, and connect with your fellow diners." 
Canora said that his staff mentioned that if people didn't have their phones in-hand then they were less likely to post social media snaps of their meals, negating that source of free advertising that has become so important to restaurants. A post shared by LP (@laupicarde) on Aug 26, 2017 at 7:56pm PDT 
"We are all willing to sacrifice that," he said . "I feel that this is remarkable, and they'll hopefully talk about the box and talk about their food post meal." 
But, the chef also said that since the addition of the phone boxes, he's noticed that "six out of 10 times," people are utilizing the boxes. "I think people are digging it," he said. 
"We've been here for 13 years. We want people to have an experience that is calm, and this is the way to help get there." Tags:

thread.title: SEE IT: Security video emerges of Las Vegas gunman's 2011 mishap
thread.title_full: SEE IT: Security video emerges of Las Vegas gunman's 2011 mishap - NY Daily News

posts.author: Nancy Dillon
posts.title: SEE IT: Security video emerges of Las Vegas gunman's 2011 mishap
posts.text:
Video emerged Tuesday showing the mishap that lead Stephen Paddock to file an unsuccessful slip-and-fall lawsuit against a casino — years before he became the most lethal mass killer in U.S. history.
Paddock, 64, fell to the floor as he walked through the Cosmopolitan Hotel on Oct. 30, 2011, surveillance video shows. He was going from a hotel store to a high-roller area in the casino.
Paddock claimed to have slipped on a puddle of liquid that hotel staff failed to clean up and asked for $100,000 in compensation.
The former accountant — who was a frequent visitor to Las Vegas — tore a hamstring. He incurred more than $32,000 in medical bills, records show.
MAP: Mass shootings in the United States since 2013 
An undated photo of the Las Vegas gunman Stephen Paddock. (John Raoux/AP) The case went to arbitration in 2014. But the arbitrator dismissed it after officials at the hotel successfully argued their cleaning staff didn’t have notice about the liquid spill that caused Paddock to fall.
Video surveillance shows a custodian going past the spot roughly a minute before Paddock’s fall, the arbitrator pointed out. The custodian and approximately 20 other hotel customers walked past the area and no one “noticed anything on the floor (or) tried to avoid a wet area,” the arbitrator ruled.
Mass shooting at Mandalay Bay Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas Paddock accepted the final judgement and wasn’t “unhinged” over it, a source who knew Paddock at the time of the lawsuit said.
“I don’t think (the loss) had anything to do with (the shooting),” the source said. “I was as shocked as everyone. I am puzzled.”
Las Vegas gunman sent $100G to Philippines days before massacre 
The hotel’s lawyer, Marty Kravitz, said Paddock was “unkempt,” “slovenly and careless” and “bizarre.”
“You wonder what a guy like this is doing at the Cosmo,” Kravitz told NBC after the shooting.
Video surveillance shows a custodian going past the spot roughly a minute before Paddock’s fall, the arbitrator pointed out. (Kravitz, Schnitzer, & Johnson via NBC News) The lawyer noted Paddock “was wearing crappy flip-flops with a beverage in a bag in his hand” when he fell.
On Sunday night, Paddock, from his room in the Mandalay Bay, opened fire on a crowd of country music lovers, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
