thread.title: Two workers injured after falling from scaffolding in Bronx
thread.title_full: Two workers injured after falling from scaffolding in Bronx - NY Daily News

posts.author: Thomas Tracy
posts.title: Two workers injured after falling from scaffolding in Bronx
posts.text:
Two workers at a Bronx construction site were seriously injured Tuesday when they plummeted down 20 feet through shoddy scaffolding, authorities said.
The two men were working on a 12-story apartment building on Third Ave. near E. 167th St. in Morrisania when they fell at about 1:30 p.m.
Both men suffered head and neck injuries, and one was in critical condition, an FDNY spokesman said.
Mohamed Sinera, 28, who works on the site, said he saw the two men on the ground, one of them bleeding from the head.
Man who took fatal fall told family NYC needs better safety rules 
“They fell through the opening in the scaffolding,” Sinera said.
The men worked for Ideal Masonry, and were installing stone slabs on the building’s facade.
Three wooden planks were missing from the scaffolding, and they fell through the gap, according to witnesses and the site’s safety coordinator.
The Buildings Department issued a partial stop work order, after an inspection revealed the scaffolding lacked end railings, was “not fully planked” and workers couldn’t produce scaffolding training cards.
Ideal Masonry owner Pajazit Vrlaku told the Daily News that his 56-year-old brother, Rakip, and another co-worker, were injured.
“All three boards, they came down at the same time,” he said. Rakip is expected to survive but remains in the hospital, while the other man was released on crutches, he said.
When asked who built the scaffolding, he said, “My workers but they’re all qualified.”
Altin Shafferi, a safety coordinator for the general contractor, the Great Neck-based Real Builders, confirmed as much, telling the Daily News, “The guys built that themselves... It’s safe. I was up there myself.”
Attempts to reach Real Builders for further comment were unsuccessful Tuesday.
Hours after the accident, a city Buildings Department inspector asked the coordinator, “How do you let guys walk on this? How do you keep guys from falling through the gap? This is not up to code."
The inspector then opined, loudly, "It's set up weird. I don't know where they found this scaffolding."
In May, the city slapped Real Builders with a violation for failing to cover up holes on floors eight through 12. That violation is still pending.
Tags: new york construction morrisania fdny

This soccer team's new sponsor is for mature audiences only. 
German amateur team SV Oberwürzbach will wear the words "Lena Nitro" on its jerseys, with LenaNitro.xxx below in smaller print. The sponsorship is for Nitro, who is a German adult film star. 
The club's sporting director, Torsten Nelz, told Bild the team was looking for a "crazy" sponsor. They then decided to reach out to the porn star who was thrilled with the idea.

thread.title: Alex Morgan among Orlando City players kicked out of Disney
thread.title_full: Alex Morgan among Orlando City players kicked out of Disney - NY Daily News

posts.author: Zachary Ripple
posts.title: Alex Morgan among Orlando City players kicked out of Disney
posts.text:
U.S. women’s national soccer team star Alex Morgan was one of four people asked to leave Epcot Center at Disney World on Sunday, according to a TMZ report .
According to the report, Morgan and three others in her party - including MLS players Giles Barnes and Donny Toia of Orlando City - were tossed from the park after things got too rowdy at a bar between Morgan’s group and another.
“The Orlando City SC organization is aware of a situation that occurred at Walt Disney World’s Epcot theme park earlier this week and is awaiting official communication from Disney or the Orange County Police Department,” the club said in a statement to the Orlando Sentinel on Tuesday. “The club will address the matter internally when there is a full understanding of what occurred.”
A second TMZ report says Morgan and her group were "highly impaired" and yelling at employees before being removed from the park, including Morgan loudly telling cops that she knew the Orlando SWAT team — as if that would protect her somehow.
Alex Morgan joins Lyon in quest to be ‘best player in the world’ 
Alex Morgan was one of four people kicked out of a Disney World theme park over the weekend. (David Dermer/AP) According to the Orlando Sentinel, an incident report had not been written yet, although the Orange County Sheriff’s Department requested one, which will be a public record upon completion.
Morgan is a forward for the Orlando Pride of the NWSL and a star of the United States women's national soccer team. She was the youngest member of the 2011 team that earned silver in that year's World Cup and was a key contributor to the World Cup-winning team in 2015.

thread.title: Giants owner againpart of NFL meetings on 'social activism'
thread.title_full: Giants owner againpart of NFL meetings on 'social activism' - NY Daily News

posts.author: Pat Leonard
posts.title: Giants owner againpart of NFL meetings on 'social activism'
posts.text:
Giants owner John Mara again part of NFL meetings to discuss ‘social activism’ by players Giants owner againpart of NFL meetings on 'social activism' Damon Harrison and Landon Collins of the Giants raise their right fists during the national anthem Sunday as league-wide protests against social injustice continue. (Brian Blanco/Getty Images) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated:  01 PM 
Giants co-owner John Mara attended a second NFL meeting in two weeks related to player "activism" on Tuesday, this time with NFL Players' Association leaders and Giants linebacker Mark Herzlich in attendance. 
Mara and linebacker Jonathan Casillas had attended a meeting last Tuesday night at NFL headquarters between 10 owners, eight players from five teams and executive league personnel to discuss the recent national anthem protests and reactions to the social media ambush from President Donald Trump. 
Tuesday, a joint NFL/NFLPA statement said commissioner Roger Goodell, NFLPA executive director DeMaurice Smith, NFLPA president Eric Winston, Patriots owner Robert Kraft, Steelers owner Art Rooney, Mara and "other player leaders engaged in a productive conversation." 
ESPN reported that Herzlich, Washington QB Kirk Cousins and Jets LB Demario Davis were among the players at the meeting. Most NFL teams have off on Tuesdays but the Giants do not under head coach Ben McAdoo, so Casillas wasn't available to go. But Herzlich is on injured reserve and also on the NFLPA executive committee. 
"We are all committed to an ongoing dialogue," the joint statement read. THE MAGIC MAN 
Eli Manning said his message to his 0-4 Giants includes a reminder "there's not a magic trick to get a win." 
"We have to play the next game," Manning said Tuesday. "That's all we can do. There's not going to be — there's not a magic trick to get a win. There's not any outside help. It's you keep working hard, you keep preparing and you go out there and you make plays on Sunday that will give (us) a chance to win." UNFAMILIAR TERRITORY 
Corner Eli Apple said he only has been on a winless team once in his life: in Pee-Wee. 
"My first year playing football," Apple said Tuesday of his running back days in South Jersey. "0-8. GVA Vikings 105." 
Rookie tight end Evan Engram, a two-time captain at Ole Miss, more recently was on a disappointing 5-7 Rebels 2016 team that failed to meet high expectations, but he said the Giants' character is strong. 
"I don't think that team was as resilient as we are and we're gonna be," Engram said. ROSAS ARE BLUE 
Rookie kicker Aldrick Rosas missed a 43-yard field goal way wide right early in Sunday's fourth quarter that would have extended the Giants' one-point lead to 20-16. 
"It's my job to extend the lead when we get the chance to," Rosas said. 
Rosas is 6-of-6 in extra points and that was his first miss in five field goal tries, but it was a big one. The Giants lost by two, 25-23, when the Bucs offense only needed a field goal on the game-winning drive. 
"Great snap, great hold, great protection, I just pushed it," Rosas said. WHEELS UP 
Undrafted rookie Chad Wheeler jumped in for two snaps at right tackle on Sunday when Justin Pugh had the wind knocked out of him and hurt his back, and Wheeler acquitted himself well. The USC product picked up a stunt to set up an 11-yard Manning completion to Brandon Marshall and then powered his man backward on a Shane Vereen run, though pressure from the opposite side stopped the play and forced a Rosas field goal. Pugh returned to the game on the next drive. Tags:

thread.title: House will not consider bill allowing easier gun silence purchases after Las Vegas massacre - New York Daily News
thread.title_full: House will not consider bill allowing easier gun silence purchases after Las Vegas massacre - New York Daily News

posts.title: House will not consider bill allowing easier gun silence purchases after Las Vegas massacre - New York Daily News
posts.text:
House will not consider bill allowing easier gun silencer purchases after Las Vegas massacre House won't consider gun silencer bill after Vegas shooting House Speaker Paul Ryan on Tuesday. (Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 3:35 PM 
The House’s plans to pass a bill this week allowing easier access to gun silencers will be suppressed indefinitely after the mass shooting in Las Vegas , House Republicans said Tuesday. 
“That bill is not scheduled now, I don’t know when it’s going to be scheduled,” House Speaker Paul Ryan of Wisconsin said. 
“Right now we’re focused on passing our budget.” 
Rep. Chris Collins of New York told reporters he didn’t think there was “any support to bring it up.” Remembering the victims of the Las Vegas mass shooting 
The GOP-controlled House had been poised to pass the SHARE Act, a sweeping revision of firearms laws that included a provision easing restrictions on silencers. 
The bill, which had already passed the House Natural Resources Committee on a party-line vote last month, came under renewed scrutiny following the massacre in Las Vegas, where a sniper in a hotel room shot nearly 600 people at a country music concert, killing 59. 
Democratic lawmakers claimed the bill’s silencer provision would make a mass attack like the Vegas rampage even deadlier by making it harder to find the source of gunfire. 
NRA silent following Las Vegas shooting 
Rep. Jeff Duncan (R-S.C.) argued that silencers would have had minimal or no effect on the Las Vegas shooting, since gunman Stephen Paddock stockpiled nearly 20 weapons and appeared to have acquired some of them illegally. People for run safety at the Route 91 Harvest country music festival, where a sniper shot nearly 600 people. (David Becker/Getty Images) 
But videos from the scene showed terrified concertgoers running and cowering in blind panic, unable to pinpoint the source of the hail of bullets. A silencer would have likely made it even harder for patrons and law enforcement to trace the location of the rounds. 
Police have not revealed whether Paddock owned or at any point used a silencer. 
The SHARE Act would take away the waiting period and registration requirements for buying silencers and also refunded the $200 transfer tax on silencers to anyone who bought one since October 2015. Duncan argued that silencers were essential for hunters and recreational shooters to avoid hearing loss. 
The act would also weaken restrictions on transportation firearms across state lines and stop some types of ammunition from being classified as “armor-piercing,” which would spare them from closer federal regulation. Tags:

thread.title: Brewers prospect Bubba Derby shielded women during Vegas shooting
thread.title_full: Brewers prospect Bubba Derby shielded women during Vegas shooting

posts.author: Zachary Ripple
posts.title: Brewers prospect Bubba Derby shielded women during Vegas shooting
posts.text:
In the tragic mass shooting in Las Vegas over the weekend, several heroes emerged as they protected others from the gunfire.
Milwaukee Brewers minor leaguer Bubba Derby was among those, selflessly blocking two young women he had met at the Route 91 Harvest Festival with his own body as bullets rained down, according to a TMZ report. 
“I turned and looked at my aunt, who was behind me,” Derby said in a video interview as he recounted the horrifying events of the weekend. “And I remember looking at her eyes and it was that look of, ‘Are we about to die? Is this it for us?’”
Pitcher Bubba Derby, now a minor leaguer with the Brewers, used his body to protect others from the bullets during the Las Vegas attack. (Jonathan Bachman/AP) Derby, 23, went on to explain that he tried to shield the two young women he had met by covering them with his body, as his brother did the same for his girlfriend.
Las Vegas massacre reminds that firearms are the No. 1 threat 
“You could hear the bullets ricocheting off the ground,” he said.
Bubba Derby says he could hear bullets flying and bouncing off the ground and stage. (Screen Grab via Sun Herald) While Derby was thankful that he and others made it out safely, he still couldn’t shake off the horrible feeling he was left with given the number of deaths and serious injuries.
“It’s tragic, man. It hurts. My heart hurts,” he said “My stomach is constantly turning. It’s part of the feeling of a traumatic experience, the feeling of guilt, of not knowing why you were able to get out alive, get out uninjured.”
Remembering the victims of the Las Vegas mass shooting Derby concluded by saying that while the deaths and injuries were tragic and horrifying, he did see beautiful acts of heroism, such as bystanders and law enforcement officials rushing back into fire and risking their own lives to protect others.

thread.title: Jets release tight end Will Tye
thread.title_full: Jets release tight end Will Tye

posts.author: DANIEL POPPER
posts.title: Jets release tight end Will Tye
posts.text:
The Jets waived tight end Will Tye on Tuesday, the team announced. They also released running back and returner Marcus Murphy from the practice squad.
Gang Green claimed Tye off waivers in early September after he was released by the Giants. Tye played 29 games for Big Blue in 2015 and 2016. He caught four passes on six targets for 38 yards in three games this season for the Jets. He was inactive for this weekend's win over the Jaguars.
Tye joined the Jets as insurance before the regular season with Austin Seferian-Jenkins set to serve a two-game suspension and both Eric Tomlinson (elbow) and rookie Jordan Leggett (knee) battling injuries.
But Seferian-Jenkins rejoined the roster before a Week 3 win over the Dolphins, and Tomlinson returned from his injury to play 29 snaps Sunday against Jacksonville. Neal Sterling, a Belmar, N.J. native who the Jets signed Sept. 6, was active over Tye on Sunday.
Tye's release clears a roster spot for WR Jalin Marshall, who served a four-game suspension to begin the season for violating the league's performance-enhancing drug policy.
Tags: nfl new york jets will tye nfl transactions Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: Tom Petty’s daughter pays tribute with emotional Instagram posts
thread.title_full: Tom Petty’s daughter pays tribute with emotional Instagram posts

posts.author: PETER SBLENDORIO
posts.title: Tom Petty’s daughter pays tribute with emotional Instagram posts
posts.text:
Tom Petty's daughter celebrated her father's life and fondly remembered their moments together in a series of emotional Instagram photos posted before and after the rock icon's death.
AnnaKim Violette Petty began sharing throwback photos showing her with the Rock and Roll Hall of Famer on Monday, hours before the rocker's longtime manager confirmed he had died later that evening.
"We are all a mirror of divine love," she wrote in one post of her and her dad.
Remembering the iconic life and career of Tom Petty She continued to upload posts of Petty — including one refuting early reports that he had died — and continued to share images of her father after the "Free Fallin'" singer's death was announced.
Tom Petty wished he hadn't used Confederate flag on 1985 tour 
A pair of heartbreaking photos showed AnnaKim with tears in her eyes, including one she posted Tuesday afternoon.
"The amount of pain you feel will one day be the amount of joy you experience," she wrote , before thanking her friends, the hospital and her father's fans for the support.

thread.title: Fantasy Football: Week 5 Waiver Wire Pickups
thread.title_full: Fantasy Football: Week 5 Waiver Wire Pickups

posts.author: JAKE CIELY
posts.title: Fantasy Football: Week 5 Waiver Wire Pickups
posts.text:
ROTOEXPERTS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 4:23 PM 
The 2017 RotoExperts Xclusive Edge In-Season Fantasy Football Package is here! It gives you access to all of our Premium content throughout the 2017 Fantasy Football season right up to your Fantasy Super Bowl. Enter promocode nydailynews at checkout for a special discount. 
This article appears courtesy of RotoExperts.com. 
As mentioned last week, Fantasy Football Week 5 waiver wire pickups are going to be more quick-hitting to get you in, our and on the way to your waivers. 
Quick note: I'm moving to dollars out of a 100-dollar budget going forward. 
Percentages at this time of the year are tougher given you're estimating remaining budgets. Additionally, you know your league best. If it's an aggressive league, you may have to spend more or vice versa, and we're going to use $5 increments (mostly); you can tweak from there. Week 5 Waiver Wire Pickups: QBs — Quarterback Streamers 
Carson Palmer, ARI (63%) - Even after getting picked off three times in Week 1, Palmer still has at least 17 points in each game with 21-plus in the last three. Palmer has thrown for at least 325 yards in those three games and faces the woeful Eagles pass defense. 
Eli Manning, NYG (59%) - Since switching things up after Week 2, Manning had 47 and 49 attempts the last two weeks with 654 yards, five touchdowns and 30.3/30.6 Fantasy points. The Chargers are a bit tougher matchup wise, but Manning should have a good week. Giants quarterback Eli Manning. (Joe Robbins/Getty Images) 
Andy Dalton, CIN (46%) - Continuing with the adjustment theme, since Bill Lazor became the offensive coordinator, Dalton has 498 yards, six touchdowns and 51.6 Fantasy points in two games. The Bengals host the Bills this week. 
Deshaun Watson, HOU (34%) - Watson isn't going to be Top 5 quarterback all year, but the rushing potential is up there with Tyrod Taylor, and he's clicked in the passing game the past two weeks with 584 yards and six touchdowns. 
Tyrod Taylor, BUF (45%) - Taylor has been up-and-down this year, and heading to Cincinnati isn't easy. DON'T: 
Brian Hoyer, SF (8%) - Sure, he's facing the Colts pass defense, but Hoyer isn't working with much and has only thrown for touchdowns in one game. There's potential, sure, but you have to be desperate. Week 5 Waiver Wire Pickups: RBs 
LAST CHANCE: Wendell Smallwood, PHI; D'Onta Foreman, HOU (59%, 28%) - Sure, LeGarrette Blount came up huge, but this is the same running back that ticked you off by literally doing nothing in Week 2. 
Smallwood fills the Darren Sproles roll and more, and is the running back I trust more. Foreman isn't going to hit 60 percent for a while, but Foreman needs to be owned everywhere given his ability and better production in tough-yardage situations. 
FAB Dollars: $30 
Latavius Murray, Jerick McKinnon, MIN (17%, 3%) - The Dalvin Cook injury is a team-killer both for the Vikings and Fantasy owners. It's painful to see especially for Cook with how good he is and was playing. Nevertheless, we need to consider the backup options, although, neither is overly exciting. Murray's value hinged on the power of the Raiders offense and the high number of scoring opportunities. McKinnon hasn't done much with his increased touches in the past besides show that he can be an explosive complement option. Murray is the better option and will be the lead running back, but McKinnon has some PPR appeal and caught 35-of-39 targets over the final eight games last year (Pat Shurmur took over after their seventh game). 
FAB Dollars: $30 Murray, $20 McKinnon 
Alvin Kamara, NO (46%) - It took the Saints a few years, but they finally found their new Sproles. Until Adrian Peterson retires, gets traded or is released, the only trustworthy option (even in Non-PPR) is Kamara, who's on pace for 80 receptions. 
FAB Dollars: $10-15 
Thomas Rawls, Eddie Lacy, SEA (29%, 19%) - With Chris Carson out for the season (broken ankle), we're back to Rawls and Lacy. My advice? Avoid this backfield altogether. Pete Carroll hinted at Rawls being the option, but Lacy saw the work in Week 4 with Rawls inactive. Don't forget that C.J. Prosise likely returns this week too. Oh, and then there is J.D. McKissic… more on him soon. 
FAB Dollars: $5-10, Rawls first… maybe 
Aaron Jones, Jamaal Williams, GB (11%, 10%) - Don't go overboard here for two reasons. First, Ty Montgomery might be ready for Week 5. Yea, I'm surprised too. Out for 4-6 weeks, out for 2-4 weeks, week-to-week, possibly ready for Week 5… okay? Second, Williams isn't officially out either. If he is, Jones is a decent pickup, especially if Montgomery can't return. However, take note that he was fourth on the depth chart and isn't built to be a workhorse/lead option. Jones is explosive but better in the change of pace role. 
FAB Dollars: $10-15 on Jones if Montgomery and Williams are out, $5-10 if not. Same on Williams if Montgomery out and he's okay for Week 5. 
Alex Collins, BAL (10%) - Javorius Allen isn't going anywhere as the pass-catching back, but Collins is now the lead option, which also makes Terrance West expendable. Collins is running better than when he was in Seattle, and while it's possible that it's more to do with the offensive line, he's worth an add. 
FAB Dollars: $5 
Andre Ellington, ARI (23%) - Ellington simply looks like the best option for the Cardinals, and that might just be because we're comparing him to Chris Johnson… who's toast. 
Either way, Ellington has 27 targets and 17 receptions in the three games since losing David Johnson. 
FAB Dollars: $5 in PPR 
Wayne Gallman, NYG (3%) - Due to an injury to Paul Perkins, the Giants finally started using their best running back. 
FAB Dollars: $5 
Elijah McGuire, NYJ (2%) - Bilal Powell is the top option, and Matt Forte may return and muddy this up, but as mentioned in previous "For the Future" portions, McGuire is explosive and similar to Tarik Cohen. 
FAB Dollars: $2-5 
FOR THE FUTURE: Matt Breida, SF (12%); James Conner, PIT (7%); Chris Ivory, JAX (3%); Austin Ekeler, LAC (0%) - Breida can technically fit in the "Last Chance" portion because I can't keep warning Carlos Hyde owners every week. It's also that time of year to start thinking about your backup plans for the lead options to these running backs. DON'T: 
J.D. McKissic, SEA (3%) - Rawls, Lacy and Prosise. That's all I need to say. Sure, McKissic went off Sunday night, but this backfield is a mess and then some. Week 5 Waiver Wire Pickups: WRs 
LAST CHANCE: Devin Funchess, CAR (25%) - So, Funchess is simply WR17 on the year with 68, 58 and 70 yards in the past three games. You don't want him? Fine, leave him for me everywhere… although, I already picked him up two weeks ago. 
FAB Dollars: $20 
Will Fuller, HOU (32%) - Like McGuire, if you paid attention to the "For the Future" portion, Fuller is already on your team. Nice return game, huh? Of course, Fuller isn't going to do that every week, and he's still wildly inconsistent, even with his hands. However, he's the No. 2 receiver for the Texans and emerging Watson. 
FAB Dollars: $10 
Tyler Lockett, SEA (42%) - Lockett is flashing the potential that had everyone over-hyping him last year. While Paul Richardson is going to create inconsistency between the two, Lockett's ceiling is higher and better pickup. Seahawks' Tyler Lockett. (L.G. Patterson/AP) 
FAB Dollars: $10 
John Brown, ARI (39%) - This is simple. Brown is the best receiver for the Cardinals at this point of Larry Fitzgerald's career… if he could stay healthy. 
FAB Dollars: $5 
Cooper Kupp, LAR (44%) - It's going to be hard to trust any receiver for the Rams, even Sammy Watkins, but Kupp could end up being the most consistent as Jared Goff's most sure-handed option. 
FAB Dollars: $5 
Zay Jones, BUF (15%) - With Jordan Matthews out, Jones is the top option for the Bills. Well, that might actually be Charles Clay, but Jones can be similar to Kupp now. 
FAB Dollars: $5 
Geronimo Allison, GB (13%) - If Davante Adams misses time, double Allison's FAB amount. Even if Adams returns this week, Allison is a wide receiver handcuff of sorts with WR4 value and a ceiling for more any time Jordy Nelson, Adams or Randall Cobb misses time. He actually fills the Adams role better than Cobb's. 
FAB Dollars: $5 
Taylor Gabriel, ATL (22%) - The Falcons have their bye at an opportune time with Julio Jones and Mohamed Sanu injured. It appears Jones should return after the bye, but Sanu will miss 2-4 weeks. Gabriel gets a value and consistency boost with either receiver out. 
FAB Dollars: $5 
Ricardo Louis, CLE (0%) - We had to take that chance on Rishard Higgins, and unfortunately, not every waiver wire pickup pans out. Louis has 15 targets in the last two games, and Higgins didn't have a single one last week despite being on the field more than Kenny Britt. Hue Jackson also said Britt would have been benched if not for injuries at the position. 
FAB Dollars: $2-3 
FOR THE FUTURE: John Ross, CIN (6%) - Ross could return in Week 5 and finally get on track, and we shouldn't forget about his potential and ability. Giovani Bernard is the Bengals second leading receiver with Tyler Kroft jumping all the way to third after basically one big game. The Bengals need Ross. DON'T: 
Adam Humphries, TB (6%) - We've seen this before, and at best, Humphries is the fourth option behind Mike Evans, DeSean Jackson and Cameron Brate. Week 5 Waiver Wire Pickups: TEs 
LAST CHANCE: Jared Cook, OAK (55%) - I'm so happy I don't have to write about Cook anymore, although I'm conflicted by the pain of having to recommend him once again. Hey, I've railed against him in the past for showing up 3-4 times a season and getting owners excited for nothing. Starting Cook is just an accident waiting to happen. 
But alas, 25 targets in four games is hard to ignore… although, EJ Manuel adds a level of uncertainty. 
FAB Dollars: $5 
Evan Engram, NYG (46%) - I'd grab Engram over Cook, as I'll echo my pre-draft assessment: he's a wide receiver masquerading as a tight end. Engram has at least 40 yards in each game with 30 targets and 19 receptions already. 
FAB Dollars: $5-10 
Austin Seferian-Jenkins, NYJ (7%) - The Jets - surprisingly not tanking for 0-16 - need weapons, and Seferian-Jenkins is showing everyone the ability he has. That ability has never been a question, just his inability to avoid off-field issues. Jets tight end Austin Seferian-Jenkins. (Al Bello/Getty Images) 
FAB Dollars: $2-5 
Ben Watson, BAL (24%) - Just call him "Ravens tight end." The Ravens tight end is always Fantasy worthy. 
FAB Dollars: $2-5 
Cameron Brate, TB (50%) - O.J. Howard is the tight end of the future, but for now, Brate is still the lead option between the two. 
FAB Dollars: $2-3 Week 5 Buy Low and Sell High 
Quick note: Splitting the Buy Low into two sections Buy Low 
Matt Ryan - We knew about the regression; he's still better than this 
Marcus Mariota - He's a QB1 
Jay Ajayi - Could qualify for both categories with that knee, but talent hasn't left him 
Joe Mixon - Needs to read the field better and can develop with continued work 
DeMarco Murray - More inconsistent than last year but more touchdowns are coming 
Christian McCaffrey - The Panthers have to be smarter than this and get him more touches, plus… Jonathan Stewart (below) 
Demaryius Thomas - Too talented to not turn it around 
Amari Cooper - Despite my disdain for the hype he receives, still much better than this 
Golden Tate - Remember how slow he started last year or what he did in Week 1? 
Jimmy Graham - If healthy, easily Top 10 tight end 
Buy Low - Could be a Bust this Year, but Potential Reward 
Ben Roethlisberger - Still avoid on road and wait until Week 7, if possible 
Melvin Gordon - Like Ajayi with the knee but even more concern with YPT and touchdown dependent 
Marshawn Lynch - Latavius Murray didn't need 200 carries or 800 rushing yards to score 12 times and near RB1 status last year 
Isaiah Crowell - DeShone Kizer is killing the offense (yes, I'm doing a told-ya-so) but if a change comes 
Mark Ingram - Maybe the Saints move on from Peterson, or he does from them 
Martavis Bryant - See: Roethlisberger 
Jamison Crowder - Was Kirk Cousins' boy last year. Maybe they can rekindle the romance? 
Eric Ebron - Might remember what those things at the end of his arms are for Sell High 
Cam Newton - He doesn't face the Patriots again 
LeGarrette Blount - See: Smallwood 
Jonathan Stewart - Injury prone, really that simple 
Ameer Abdullah - Only if someone thinking Top 15-ish happening - getting no use inside the 10 
Chris Hogan - Fifteen receptions, four touchdowns - I know it's the Patriots, but… 
Larry Fitzgerald - Love him, but fades in the second half, Brown is back (for now) and volume dependent 
Sammy Watkins - If even can after last week, but schedule gets brutal after the Cowboys 
Coby Fleener - Already quieted down, and now Willie Snead returns Tags:

thread.title: New York, divest from fossil fuel companies
thread.title_full: New York, divest from fossil fuel companies

posts.author: Bill McKibben
posts.title: New York, divest from fossil fuel companies
posts.text:
New York, divest pensions from the fossil fuel companies that are accelerating global warming New York, divest from fossil fuel companies NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 4:19 PM 
Forget the bizarre tweets and insults from the White House, or the images of the President touring San Juan: What’s happened in Puerto Rico will change life there for many years after all the news has faded from your feed. 
Early estimates put the economic damage from Hurricane Maria at $30 billion, a third of the island’s annual economic output. Eighty percent of its crops have been destroyed — “there is no agriculture on Puerto Rico, and there won’t be for at least another year,” said one official. It may be a year before power returns, and even that won’t solve the deeper problems. As one official said, the devastation had set back the island “20 or 30 years” — that is, an entire human generation’s worth of progress lost in a few hours. 
The response from New Yorkers has been generous, which makes sense because of the close ties between these two parts of our nation. Gov. Cuomo set up a statewide collection program for aid, gathering the donations in the Javits Center, where Jet Blue has offered to fly them to San Juan. Two members of Congress — Nydia Velasquez and Jose Serrano — were in the first Congressional delegation ashore on Puerto Rico. Mayor De Blasio immediately ordered the public schools to prepare for an influx of students coming from the island. 
“It’s the sheer breadth and magnitude of this that’s so shocking,” Hizzoner insisted. “I mean its just total. Our folks have said, very clearly, there’s endless need.” 
But there is one curious missing piece: as New York scrambles to help, it continues to invest billions of dollars in the fossil fuel companies that caused — and may have covered up — the global warming that makes such events more devastating. 
Make no mistake, Maria is precisely what climate change looks like. September 2017 saw more hurricane activity in the Atlantic than in any month since record-keeping began in 1851. Of all the Category 5 storms to hit U.S. territory, a quarter have come this year. 
The deluges in the Puerto Rican mountains may have set new global records for most rain in an hour; when they finally cleared, Puerto Ricans without air-conditioning or even fans faced a record-breaking heat wave. The island has spent the last year trying to deal with an outbreak of Zika virus, a classic climate-change disease. Imagine what the mosquitoes are like today. 
These are precisely the kind of effects climate scientists have predicted. Warm air holds more water vapor than cold; hence, bigger rains. Hurricanes draw their strength from the ocean’s heat; hence, higher winds. As we learned during Sandy, the higher ocean can surge farther inland. 
And we are learning more every day about how the oil companies knew all this was coming. Great investigative reporting from places like the Columbia Journalism School have shown that, for instance, Exxon knew everything there was to know about climate change 40 years ago. But instead of telling the rest of us, they spent a fortune covering it up, purchasing the politicians who would make sure change came slowly if at all. 
New York’s courageous attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, has been in the forefront of chasing Exxon and its ilk, uncovering many of the documents that make clear their complicity. And some municipalities have risen to the challenge: San Francisco and Oakland announced last month that they were suing oil companies for the damages caused by ongoing climate havoc. 
But not New York City. So far, the Big Apple is content to keep investing its money in these companies. Its pension funds have billions sunk in the stock of the corporations who’ve done, and keep doing, the damage. This is not only maddening in any moral sense, it’s crazy economically: These sectors have been among the weakest parts of the economy for years, underperforming other investments. If New York had divested when campaigners started asking after Sandy, its retirees would be on much more solid financial ground. 
But better late than never. On Oct. 28, thousands of New Yorkers will march across the Brooklyn Bridge into the parts of the Lower East Side still rebuilding from Sandy. They’re demanding the city commit to 100% renewables, and get people back in their homes who are still adrift long after the storm. 
But the #Sandy5 effort also demands divestment, and it knows who is accountable. New York’s elected officials — the borough presidents, the public advocate, the comptroller and the mayor — along with city unions all have a say in where pension money gets invested. They should speak with conviction and force. It’s one more way to express our solidarity with people in Puerto Rico. We can’t take back Maria, but we can make sure we’re not funding the next one. 
McKibben is the founder of the global grassroots climate campaign 350.org and author of the forthcoming book “Radio Free Vermont.” Join the Conversation:

thread.title: SEE IT: Boy can't stop squeaking after swallowing pet toy
thread.title_full: SEE IT: Boy can't stop squeaking after swallowing pet toy

posts.author: ARIEL SCOTTI
posts.title: SEE IT: Boy can't stop squeaking after swallowing pet toy
posts.text:
NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 4:15 PM 
An unidentified boy in Tucuman, Argentina, accidentally swallowed a piece of a pet toy and then couldn't stop making squeaking sounds. 
In a video recorded by his emergency room doctor, Dr. Santiago Gomez Zuviria, the unnamed 8-year-old child opens his mouth and begins to squeak nonstop. After administering an anesthetic, Zuviria was able to remove the noisy culprit from his throat. An unidentified boy in Tucuman, Argentina, accidentally swallowed a piece of a pet toy and then couldn't stop making squeaking sounds. (Facebook) 
"The whistle was stuck between the larynx and the pharynx," Zuviria told HuffPost . "His mother was more scared than he was. It was a tragi-comic situation to be honest. I never seen or heard about a case like this in my life." 
In a Facebook post that has received more than nine million views, Zuviria shared his video of the boy and his squeaky predicament in order to warn parents about swallowing and choking hazards. The child has since recovered. 
"Moral," the post read, "Beware of what children play (with)." Tags:

thread.title: Yankee playoff game will have more security, NYPD counter-snipers
thread.title_full: Yankee playoff game will have more security, NYPD counter-snipers

posts.author: ROCCO PARASCANDOLA
posts.title: Yankee playoff game will have more security, NYPD counter-snipers
posts.text:
With security this tight, let’s hope the Yanks can still steal home.
Tuesday night’s playoff game against the Twins will kick off amid a heightened police presence, complete with helicopters and NYPD counter-snipers who will ring the Bronx stadium, officials said.
Chief of Department Carlos Gomez said sharpshooters from the Emergency Services Unit will provide an extra layer of security for the 50,000 fans expected to watch the Bronx Bombers take on Minnesota two days after a gunman killed 59 and injured more than 500 at a Las Vegas concert.
“We routinely utilize counter-sniper teams and observation teams at many of our large events,” Gomez said. “They're perched on rooftops, balconies or windows up in the buildings.”
Las Vegas gunman recorded his deadly rampage inside hotel room 
Gomez said the officers will “serve as extra sets of eyes.”
Police helicopters will likely be overhead, or close enough to respond within minutes.
Mass shooting at Mandalay Bay Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas Other big-ticket events — concerts, the U.S. Open, and the New Year’s Eve ball-drop among them — are similarly policed.
Gomez said the Vegas massacre will be analyzed so the NYPD can “see what else we can do to make these events safer.”
Mass shooting at Mandalay Bay concert in Las Vegas kills 59 
One new development: cops who train hotel staff to watch for trouble will now include a primer on what gun cases look like.
“We don’t focus just on the security people, but also the key housekeeping staff,” said Deputy Commissioner John Miller, who heads the Counterterrorism and Intelligence Bureau. “Those are the people who are in and out of the rooms, who have the best observation abilities to spot something suspicious."
Miller said hotel workers are trained to recognize chemicals and other items that can be used to make explosives, as well as suspicious behavior by guests.
“Everyone knows what a rifle looks like, (but) what does a gun case look like, as opposed to a golf bag or regular luggage?” Miller said.
Tags: mlb new york yankees nypd

thread.title: Serial bus thief with Asperger's offered 'bizarre' plea deal
thread.title_full: Serial bus thief with Asperger's offered 'bizarre' plea deal

posts.author: CHRISTINA CARREGA
posts.title: Serial bus thief with Asperger's offered 'bizarre' plea deal
posts.text:
Notorious public transportation thief Darius McCollum’s latest caper, a joyride on a stolen bus, may be the one that puts him on the road to better mental health.
Brooklyn prosecutors offered him the opportunity to plead guilty for reasons of insanity. If he agrees, a panel of doctors will determine his fitness and place him in a mental institution.
Prosecutors have made several plea offers to McCollum, all involving prison time, since his November 2015 arrest for jumping behind the wheel of the empty bus and taking it out for a spin — for 36 hours.
But McCollum has rejected the offers, ranging from 31/2 to 10 years, which would have shipped him to an upstate prison.
Serial bus thief rejects plea deal, wants mental health care 
The transit thief’s longtime attorney, Sally Butler, has lobbied for McCollum to receive court-ordered mental health treatment, instead of prison, because he’s been diagnosed with Asperger’s syndrome.
McCollum, 51, is a two-time felon whose obsession with buses and trains has resulted in a lengthy criminal record for stealing the vehicles.
Yet his particular condition didn’t qualify him for the mental health treatment .
If McCollum accepts the offer the prosecutor made Tuesday, the judge will conduct a hearing in which a panel of doctors will determine McCollum’s mental fitness.
Daily News to launch 2017 Hometown Heroes in Education Awards 
“The panel will determine if he’s either mentally ill and dangerous, mentally ill and not dangerous or not mentally ill,” Assistant District Attorney Christopher Myco explained to the judge.
Butler requested an adjournment in order for McCollum to review the offer.
“This is not a traditional plea,” the attorney said.
Darius McCollum, with his attorney Sally Butler, at State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on March 21, 2016.  (Jesse Ward/for New York Daily News) If McCollum takes his chances with a jury and is convicted, he faces five to 15 years in prison for the top count of grand larceny.
School bus driver looking for sleeping kids finds dozing raccoons 
After Tuesday’s brief appearance in Brooklyn Supreme Court, McCollum may have some cause for happiness — and relief — after almost 30 arrests.
“Doctors concluded the defendant did lack the substantial capacity to know or appreciate the consequences of his actions by reason of insanity or autism spectrum disorder,” Myco read in court from a portion of the report the prosecution’s expert prepared.
“This doesn’t happen,” Butler said outside of court. “That’s what’s so bizarre about it — usually I’m the one begging the court to say somebody has a mental defect or is not responsible.”
In addition to grand larceny, McCollum faces charges of criminal impersonation, operating a motor vehicle without a license, criminal possession of stolen property and unauthorized use of a motor vehicle.
Schumer calls for bus safety reform in wake of fatal Queens crash 
He will have to say on Oct. 18 whether he will accept the offer or go to trial on Dec. 4.
In 2016, McCollum became the subject of a critically acclaimed documentary film, “Off the Rails,” which was directed by Adam Irving.
“I’m just a train buff — that’s all there is to it,” McCollum said in the documentary.
His 30 arrests include commandeering trains and buses, strolling onto restricted property — and even impersonating Metropolitan Transportation Authority workers while decked out in their uniform and gear.
McCollum filed a $15 million lawsuit last year in Brooklyn Federal Court under the Americans with Disabilities Act for not allegedly receiving proper mental health treatment while in jail.
Tags: mental health mta

thread.title: Woman says she thought baby she cut out of slain friend was hers
thread.title_full: Woman says she thought baby she cut out of slain friend was hers

posts.author: ESHA RAY, LEONARD GREENE
posts.title: Woman says she thought baby she cut out of slain friend was hers
posts.text:
A Bronx woman accused of killing her childhood friend and slicing her baby from her womb told jurors Tuesday that she actually thought the infant was hers.
Ashleigh Wade, 24, who is accused of performing a crude caesarean section on Angelikque Sutton after plunging a knife into her last November, testified that she ripped the baby out of Sutton’s stomach because “she couldn’t have any more children die so I had to save her.”
“I thought that girl was mine,” Wade said under questioning from her attorney Amy Attias.
Angelikque Sutton (Facebook) “Before I spoke to detectives, I thought the baby was mine. But I knew something was wrong because I didn’t remember her coming out of me. I didn’t remember taking off my pants.”
Bronx woman accused of killing pregnant pal seeks therapist 
Then Attias asked her if she killed her friend to steal her baby.
“No,” Wade replied.
Under cross-examination, Wade said that after ripping the child from Sutton’s womb, Wade testified that she thought the baby like her friend, had been killed in the gruesome attack.
“I was just upset that the baby was dead,” Wade said. “When the baby started screaming and crying I felt happy.”
Photo of murdered pregnant woman makes juror pass out 
Wade also accused detectives of forcing her to make false statements in her initial interview after her arrest.
“They were calling me a liar and that I was crazy if I turned it in like that,” she said, referring to the original statement she gave police.
“They said it didn’t sound right, it sounded crazy and I didn’t want to sound crazy.”
In her account, Wade also wrote that she wanted the baby to be hers so badly that she let it “cloud her judgment.” Under oath, she testified that was also wrong.
Woman who killed pregnant pal needed help in surrendering 
“I didn’t let it cloud my judgement because I believed it was real,” she said “The detectives told me to write that.”
The baby, now 22 months old, survived. Relatives named her Jenasis.
Cops said Wade tried to convince them that she gave birth to the child herself Nov. 20, 2015, saying, “It’s my baby,” as Sutton lay dying in a pool of blood.
Later, Wade — who said she had lost a baby of her own — claimed to cops that she knifed Sutton in self-defense.
Woman who killed pregnant friend plotted slay so baby would live 
Police said Sutton was stabbed up to 20 times.
“I sat there thinking about my child that died and thought that I couldn’t have any more children die so I rescued the baby,” Wade wrote in her statement.
Wade is accused of faking a pregnancy for months before murdering Sutton.
Prosecutors said Wade and Sutton, 22, reconnected through Facebook, but when Sutton went to visit Wade at her Monticello Ave. apartment, she was greeted with a knife.
Last week, a juror passed out when prosecutors revealed autopsy photos of Sutton’s mutilated body.
Tags: new york murders crimes against children wakefield

thread.title: Thousands of Hurricane Maria evacuees arrive in South Florida
thread.title_full: Thousands of Hurricane Maria evacuees arrive in South Florida

posts.author: ELIZABETH ELIZALDE
posts.title: Thousands of Hurricane Maria evacuees arrive in South Florida
posts.text:
Thousands of Hurricane Maria evacuees arrive in South Florida on a cruise ship Thousands of Hurricane Maria evacuees arrive in South Florida NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   4:05 PM 
Thousands of evacuees from Puerto Rico and other islands devastated by Hurricane Maria arrived at Fort Lauderdale’s Port Everglades Tuesday to relieved family members worried about their status. 
The Royal Caribbean’s Adventure of the Sea carried more than 3,800 evacuees and arrived at the port in the morning. The ship had canceled a Sept. 30 cruise to deliver food, water, and medical supplies to Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands of St. Croix and St. Thomas before picking up evacuees and heading to Florida. Family and friends welcome evacuees from islands affected by Hurricane Maria on Tuesday. (Jesus Aranguren/AP) 
Wanda Collazo was anxiously waiting for her 78-year-old mother Marta Collazo at the terminal. She managed to communicate with her two brothers in Puerto Rico and worked to help get their mother onto the cruise ship to South Florida. 
Though she was reunited with her daughter, Marta Collazo couldn’t help but think about her sons back home. 
Trump blames Puerto Rico for throwing budget ‘out of whack’ 
“I have two sons still there, and they are having a hard time. It looks like an atomic bomb fell there — it’s destroyed,” she told The Miami Herald. “But when I saw (my daughter) it was like my heart was going to come out of my chest.” 
She told the paper she plans to stay in Florida until the power on the island has restored. Hurricane Maria strikes Puerto Rico after pummeling Caribbean 
Waleska Rosich, another evacuee from Puerto Rico, told Local10 she was "so glad" and "very happy” she had reached land. 
“Finally, I have him home,” Migdalia Rivera told WSVN-TV when she welcomed her son Michael and his family. "It’s been a long battle to get them here.” 
Trump arrives in a Puerto Rico still struggling for survival 
Many evacuees were grateful for Royal Caribbean and its warm service. 
"They reassured us that once we reached Florida, that everything would be all right with us,” evacuee Carmen Boynes told the TV station, adding that she was treated with "kindness" while on the ship. Ingrid Fernandez, of Puerto Rico, breaks down in tears as her daughter, Ingrid Vazquez, comforts her after she arrived at Port Everglades in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. on Tuesday. (Emily Michot/TNS) 
Laura Berrios and her two children — ages 3 and 8 — were also among those evacuees who arrived waiting to be reunited with their family. She told the Sun Sentinel she decided to flee her storm-ravaged island of Puerto Rico because of her kids’ safety. 
“There is no power and although we had some water, it's not potable because the treatment plants are not working,” Berrios told the newspaper, adding that her mother-in-law was going to pick her and her kids up to drive them to Tennessee to stay with family. 
Adventures of the Sea is scheduled to head back to San Juan on Saturday with hundreds of supplies, according to the Herald. Tags:

thread.title: Human tears and saliva can generate electricity: study
thread.title_full: Human tears and saliva can generate electricity: study

posts.author: ARIEL SCOTTI
posts.title: Human tears and saliva can generate electricity: study
posts.text:
A special protein secreted by specific human fluids can create power.
A new way to harvest electricity has been discovered by scientists: human bodily secretions. Lysozyme, a special protein that generates electricity when pressure is applied, can be used as a new source of fuel for bodily implanted devices, like the kind that administer medications, according to new research published in the journal Applied Physics Letters .
It's found in tears, saliva, milk, mucus, and egg whites and in its crystalized form, can produce an electrical charge, researchers from the University of Limerick in Ireland found. When the protein was pressed between two thin glass slides, it produced piezoelectricity, a form of energy that occurs as a product of stress and pressure.
"While piezoelectricity is used all around us, the capacity to generate electricity from this particular protein had not been explored," researcher Aimee Stapleton told the journal . "However, because it is a biological material, it is non-toxic so it could have many innovative applications such as electroactive anti-microbial coatings for medical implants."
Online friendships matter as much as in-person for teens: study 
The discovery opens the door for potential devices to be at least partially created out of something the body is already familiar with. These implantable piezoelectric devices will be controlled and powered by lysozyme sensors in the body. They'll more flexible and biodegradable, too.
"This is a new approach," lead researcher Tofail Syed said. "We also imagine that lysozyme may be employed as an antimicrobial additive/coating to implants," the team explained.

thread.title: Man accused of killing girlfriend demonstrates shooting in court
thread.title_full: Man accused of killing girlfriend demonstrates shooting in court

posts.author: DAVID BOROFF
posts.title: Man accused of killing girlfriend demonstrates shooting in court
posts.text:
Man accused of killing girlfriend uses prop gun to demonstrate fatal shooting in court Man accused of killing girlfriend demonstrates shooting in court NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 4:01 PM 
A Maine man accused of killing his ex-girlfriend before leading police on the longest manhunt in state history used a prop gun in court to demonstrate how she died. 
Robert Burton testified during in his Bangor trial on Tuesday that he fatally shot 37-year-old Stephanie Gebo in self-defense in June of 2015 after he was shot in the shoulder with the same gun. 
"She put the gun underneath my chin so hard that I saw stars," Burton said as he stood next to a mattress while holding the toy gun, according to the Bangor Daily News . "She told me she was going to kill me and get away with it." 
Burton said he put his hand on the gun and tried to keep her from shooting him. He claims she lost her balance and the gun went behind her back. He said the gun went off twice as she fell toward him, according to the Bangor Daily News. 
A medical examiner says Ginn Gebo was shot in the back, and prosecutors argue that Burton acted out of jealousy. They had broken up in May of 2015, but got back together the following month, Burton testified earlier this week. 
The gun has not been recovered. Robert Burton (c.) appears in court during his murder trial in Maine. (WCSH6) 
Burton said he heard about possible relationships Gebo may have had with other men. 
"I got more and more agitated during the day,” Burton testified, according to the newspaper . “I decided I’d bind her wrists and ankles with duct tape and make her tell the truth about other men." 
Kim Wall stabbed 15 times after boarding submarine for interview 
However, Burton said he was calmer by the time he went to her house and "forgot the duct tape was there." 
Burton had led police on a 68-day manhunt after Gebo had been found dead. He had previously rejected a plea deal that came with a 60-year sentence. 
With News Wire Services

thread.title: NBA All-Star Game to ditch East vs. West format in 2018
thread.title_full: NBA All-Star Game to ditch East vs. West format in 2018

posts.author: Fran Kilinski
posts.title: NBA All-Star Game to ditch East vs. West format in 2018
posts.text:
So much for East versus West.
The NBA announced in a press release Tuesday afternoon that the game will be played without conferences in 2018. The teams will instead be picked playground-style, by "captains," or the leading vote-getters from the East and the West.
The agreement reached between the league and the Players Association will make next year's All-Star Game the first of it's kind to be divvied up without the East and West coast players separated by conference.
“I’m thrilled with what the players and the league have done to improve the All-Star Game, which has been a priority for all of us,” said Houston Rockets guard Chris Paul, the NBPA's president. “We’re looking forward to putting on an entertaining show in L.A.”
Noah, Knicks react to NBA’s ‘standing’ for anthem mandate 
Along with the new format of teams, another change to All-Star Weekend was announced: the teams will play for charity, selecting a local or national organization to support.
With an influx of superstar powers moving to the Western Conference this offseason, the move will likely bring parity to what might've been an otherwise lopsided game. The new rules mean it's still possible we could see Carmelo Anthony and LeBron James on the same All-Star team next year.
The voting process will stay the same, with 12 players from each conference earning a chance to play in the game. The voters will still keep the same privileges as well, with fans making up 50% of voting for the starters, and current players (25%) and media (25%) making up the rest. The coaches who clinch the best record in their respective conferences will earn the right to coach the All-Star Game. The league's coaches also maintain their voting privileges for the game's 14 reserve players.
Fan voting will begin on Christmas Day.
NBA memo warns teams to stand during national anthem ‘OR ELSE’ 
“We’re excited about the new All-Star format and appreciate the players’ willingness to try something new,” said NBA President of League Operations Byron Spruell.
More details about how All-Star captains can draft their teams are expected to be released at a later date.
Tags: nba nba all-star game Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: Grace Jones 'devastated' after her mother's death on Monday
thread.title_full: Grace Jones 'devastated' after her mother's death on Monday

posts.title: Grace Jones 'devastated' after her mother's death on Monday
posts.text:
Model, singer and former Bond girl Grace Jones is "devastated" following the death of her beloved mother Marjorie Jones on Monday, according to sources familiar with the family.
The 69-year-old star, who released the song “I’m Crying (Mother’s Tears)” in 2008, kept a bedside vigil with her mother in Los Angeles after Marjorie had a massive stroke in mid-September, we’re told.
Business associates revealed that Grace is mourning the loss, but was happy to have been with her mom until the very end.
Despite doctors’ best efforts, including reviving Marjorie from a coma, she passed away peacefully at the Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center, according to our insiders. She was 90-years-old.
Grace Jones is seen here with her mother Marjorie. (Ron Galella/WireImage) Marjorie was born in Spanish Town, Jamaica, but moved to New York City when her daughter hit the big time and secured a record deal with Island Records in 1977.
In her later years. Marjorie lived in Syracuse, where she worked with the Apostolic Church of Jesus Christ.
She is survived by sons Randolph, Chris, Maxwell and Cor, as well as daughters Janet, Ruth, Pamela and Grace.
“Grace joined the rest of the family the moment she heard Marjorie had a severe stroke just a few weeks ago,” one source revealed. “She was hopeful that her mum was going to pull through after she came out of a coma. Sadly, Marjorie couldn't make a full recovery and passed away on Monday with her family by her side.”
Controversial artist Grace Jones lost her supportive mother on Monday. (Kevin Winter/Getty Images for FYF) 
Grace's estranged father, Bishop Jones died on May 7, 2008. He was also a musician and played with Nat King Cole, but sometimes found himself at odds with his daughter’s rock star lifestyle. However, Marjorie always supported Grace's career choices — even singing on songs “Williams’ Blood” and “My Jamaican Guy.”
Jones' rep declined to comment.
With James Desborough 
Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: Kim Wall stabbed 15 times after boarding submarine for interview
thread.title_full: Kim Wall stabbed 15 times after boarding submarine for interview

posts.author: MEGAN CERULLO
posts.title: Kim Wall stabbed 15 times after boarding submarine for interview
posts.text:
Swedish journalist Kim Wall was stabbed 15 times after she boarded Danish inventor Peter Madsen’s homemade submarine for an interview in August, a Copenhagen court heard Monday.
Madsen, 46, has been charged with murdering Wall , whose headless, dismembered torso was found floating in waters off of Copenhagen on Aug. 21, 10 days after she boarded the vessel.
Her cause of death has not yet been determined, but prosecutor Jakob Buch-Jepsen told a court that the multiple knife wounds had been inflicted “at the time of death or shortly afterwards,” the Guardian reported.
Madsen’s computer also contained material featuring women being tortured and killed, Buch-Jepsen said.
Inventor charged with killing Kim Wall says sub door hit her head 
Madsen, who has denied killing Wall, participated in the hearing via video conference.
He said he was “not the only person” with access to the computer in his workshop, and denied that the gruesome material belonged to him.
Danish inventor Peder Madsen has been charged with Kim Wall's murder. (SCANPIX DENMARK/REUTERS) Madsen’s lawyer Betina Hald Engmark said the court had heard “nothing that supports Kim Wall being killed by my client.”
Madsen previously alleged that Wall was killed in a “terrible accident” aboard the ship. He said she was hit by a 155-pound hatch in the submarine’s tower.
Sub searched for secret chambers after reporter's death 
He said that after the disaster, he used a metal weight to sink her body.
Buch-Jepsen, however, said that Madsen killed Wall at an unknown time between Aug. 10 and 11, and dismembered her body before sinking it.
An autopsy found that her missing limbs were cut off after her death.
“Our suspicion hasn’t changed, it has been strengthened since September 5,” Buch-Jepsen said.
Danish inventor Peter Madsen denies murding journalist Kim Wall 
Wall's body was stabbed 15 times at or shortly after the time of death, prosecutors said. (Jens Noergaard Larsen/EPA) Madsen’s detention was extended until Oct. 31.
An investigation into Wall’s death is ongoing.
With News Wire Services 
Tags: sweden denmark Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: Las Vegas shooting survivor watched as life-loving boyfriend died
thread.title_full: Las Vegas shooting survivor watched as life-loving boyfriend died

posts.author: MOLLY CRANE-NEWMAN
posts.title: Las Vegas shooting survivor watched as life-loving boyfriend died
posts.text:
Since Sunday, Bobby Eardley was hit with shrapnel fleeing the Las Vegas concert massacre, watched his boyfriend die before his eyes in the shooting, and spent the first night of the rest of his life without the love of his life by his side.
“He’s with his children right now, in solitude,” his mother Joyce Eardley told the Daily News Tuesday. “He’s home, which we feel is a tender mercy.”
Mourners attend a candlelight vigil at the corner of Sahara Avenue and Las Vegas Boulevard for the victims of Sunday night's mass shooting. (Drew Angerer/Getty Images) Bobby Eardley, 28, lives with his three children in St. George, Utah.
“He loved life,” Joyce Eardley, 64, said through tears of her son’s slain boyfriend, Cameron Robinson, 28, who she said was like a second father to her three young grandchildren.
A glimpse at Las Vegas shooting survivors' wide-ranging injuries 
“He loved people and to serve people — he was a character, he had us all laughing. We could be in the dumps and then he’d have us all in laughter,” she said. “A great loss of a great man.”
Robinson worked as a management analyst for the City of Las Vegas, according to his LinkedIn page. He commuted over 100 miles to his job each day from the couple’s St. George home.
Remembering the victims of the Las Vegas mass shooting The city worker was shot in the neck on Sunday when gunman Stephen Paddock unleashed a roaring cascade of bullets upon him and other country music concertgoers from his room on the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay Hotel, Robinson’s sister Meghan Ervin told the Las Vegas Review-Journal.
Eardley, 28, suffered shrapnel wounds to his lower back during the bloodshed. But it’s the mental wounds that will leave the deepest scars.
SEE IT: Security video emerges of Las Vegas gunman's 2011 mishap 
“He will heal outside — it’ll take a long time inside,” Eardley’s mother said.
As the hours passed following the massacre which left 59 dead and 527 injured, tributes to Robinson poured in on social media.
Robinson worked as a management analyst for the City of Las Vegas, according to his LinkedIn page. (Facebook) “I woke up, well I didn't sleep and if I did then I am still in this nightmare,” Ervin posted on Facebook Monday.
“Today to go say goodbye to you! I was never supposed to say goodbye to you, little brother … you were supposed to take over the world.”
House won't consider gun silencer bill after Vegas shooting 
A GoFundMe page has been set up to help raise money for Robinson's funeral.
Tags: las vegas las vegas shooting nevada gun violence mass murder Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: Bronx school stabber plays hooky from scheduled court appearance
thread.title_full: Bronx school stabber plays hooky from scheduled court appearance

posts.author: ESHA RAY, THOMAS TRACY
posts.title: Bronx school stabber plays hooky from scheduled court appearance
posts.text:
A Bronx high schooler accused of stabbing two younger teens during a classroom brawl — killing one — skipped a court appearance Tuesday, opting not to face a courtroom packed with furious relatives of the victims.
Abel Cedeno remained in an upstairs holding cell at Bronx Criminal Court while his attorney, Deborah Rush, waived his appearance during a brief court hearing.
The bisexual teen faces a murder charge in the death of Matthew McCree, 15, after the teen threw broken pencil shards and wadded paper at him during a history class at the Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation on Sept. 27.
On Tuesday, several members of Matthew’s family, all wearing shirts emblazoned with photographs of the slain teen, sat in the gallery awaiting Cedeno’s first court appearance since he was ordered held without bail last week.
Family to sue over student who was stabbed by bullied classmate 
So many people showed up that onlookers under 18 were ordered to leave the courtroom.
Matthew McCree, 15, was stabbed to death on Sept. 27. (Facebook) About a half-dozen court officers watched over the group, which quietly voiced disapproval when Cedeno failed to show.
“I will be waiving my client’s appearance,” Rush told Bronx Criminal Court Judge Julio Rodriguez.
Matthew’s relatives, especially his mom, Louna Dennis, will be back, family attorney Sanford Rubenstein said.
Bronx stabbing victim awoke from coma, learns best friend is dead 
“(Louna) will be back every time this case is called in court,” he said. “He cannot hide forever.”
Fatal stabbing at Bronx school Cedeno is also accused of attacking Matthew’s best friend, 16-year-old Ariane LaBoy, stabbing him in the chest when he came to Matthew’s defense. He faces attempted murder charges in the attack on Ariane.
The bloodshed played out in front of a classroom full of students. The airborne assault last week was the first time the two boys had bothered Cedeno, who ordered the switchblade online two weeks earlier.
Ariane was in a coma for two days following the attack and is now on the mend.
Knife found in Bronx classroom where teen stabbed classmate 
Both families plan to sue the city for not putting in metal detectors and taking other measures to better protect students, including Cedeno, who was a victim of bullying, Rubenstein said.
Attorney Sanford Rubenstein (l.) and McCree's mother Louna Dennis at a press conference on Oct. 3. (Marcus Santos/New York Daily News) “The mayor had a press conference trying to tell the public everything is OK,” Rubenstein said. “Well everything is not OK and the fact that I have a mother standing with me right here who lost her son to violence in the schools demonstrates that.”
In a jailhouse interview Friday, Cedeno said he was being constantly harassed for being bisexual and “just snapped” when he lunged at Matthew and Ariane, who had not tormented him before that day.
“I didn’t mean to kill him. I wanted to scare him,” Cedeno said about killing Matthew. 
Tags: new york public schools new york murders teen violence crimes against children new york assaults

thread.title: Yahoo says all 3 billion user accounts were affected in 2013 hack
thread.title_full: Yahoo says all 3 billion user accounts were affected in 2013 hack

posts.author: MEGAN CERULLO
posts.title: Yahoo says all 3 billion user accounts were affected in 2013 hack
posts.text:
Yahoo says all 3 billion user accounts were affected in 2013 hack Yahoo says all 3 billion user accounts were affected in 2013 hack Yahoo said all three billion of its user accounts were affected in a 2013 data breach. (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated: Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 4:58 PM 
Yahoo tripled its estimate of the number of accounts exposed in an August 2013 hack Tuesday. 
The company revealed that all 3 billion of its user accounts were affected, after it said in an earlier estimate that only 1 billion user accounts had been exposed. 
Yahoo said the revised figure was based on "recently obtained new intelligence" from outside forensic experts. 
An investigation shows that the stolen information did not include passwords in clear text, payment card data, or bank account information, according to Yahoo. 
Verizon closes Yahoo deal, Marissa Mayer steps down 
Yahoo first announced the theft in December 2016, six months after Verizon agreed to acquire the internet company. 
In its announcement Tuesday, Yahoo said that it would provide notice to the additional users affected by the breach. Tags:

thread.title: N.Y. will sue to block Trump tax reform plan if it passes: Cuomo
thread.title_full: N.Y. will sue to block Trump tax reform plan if it passes: Cuomo

posts.author: ERIN DURKIN
posts.title: N.Y. will sue to block Trump tax reform plan if it passes: Cuomo
posts.text:
New York State will sue to block President Trump’s plan to stop taxpayers from deducting state and local taxes if it passes, Gov. Cuomo said Tuesday.
Trump’s sweeping tax reform plan includes a proposal that would end the deduction, which Cuomo says would amount to a tax hike for many New Yorkers who itemize their taxes.
“We believe the new federal tax plan, if it goes through, is double taxation, and we will sue the federal government if they do that,” Cuomo said at a press conference at his Midtown office where he decried multiple “federal assaults on the state of New York,” which also include health care cuts.
“We’re not going to allow this state to be attacked and assaulted grossly and unfairly,” Cuomo said. “We will sue on the deductibility provision if it stays in at the end of the day.”
N.Y. sent D.C. $41B more than state received in services in 2016 
An analysis by Cuomo’s office predicted that in New York City, the 1.1 million residents who claim the deduction would see an average tax increase of $7,134.
Statewide, the change would result in an average $5,298 tax increase for the 3.3 million taxpayers who claim the deduction on their federal tax returns. In total, the impact would add up to $17.5 billion statewide.
The state has also threatened to sue over a variety of other controversial Trump proposals. (Drew Angerer/Getty Images) People who take the standard deduction would not be affected.
“It is an attempt by the federal government, purposeful or coincidental, to make New York and several other states actually less competitive for businesses and people,” Cuomo said. “If you raise our taxes, you make New York less competitive.”
Cuomo slams Trump’s tax reform plan as ‘devastating for New York' 
The state has also threatened to sue over a variety of other controversial Trump proposals, including the repeal of Obamacare which ultimately failed and Trump’s move to end protections for young immigrants brought to the country illegally as children.
Tags: andrew cuomo donald trump lawsuits taxes and spending trump tax plan

thread.title: O'Neill says detectives will ‘pay’ if they sexually abused teen
thread.title_full: O'Neill says detectives will ‘pay’ if they sexually abused teen

posts.author: ROCCO PARASCANDOLA
posts.title: O'Neill says detectives will ‘pay’ if they sexually abused teen
posts.text:
Two Brooklyn detectives accused of sexually attacking a teen after cuffing her for a drug charge will “pay the price” if the allegations are true, NYPD Commissioner James O’Neill said Tuesday in his first public comments about the investigation.
“Not all 36,000 cops deserve to wear their shield around their neck,” O’Neill said. “If these two detectives did something wrong, then they’ll pay the price.”
Brooklyn South Narcotics detectives Richard Hall and Eddie Martins have been placed on desk duty and stripped of their guns and shields since the 18-year-old victim made the stunning allegation.
The teen revisited the scene with her family and lawyer Tuesday.
Teen claims NYPD cops raped her after arrest on drug charge 
An 18-year-old woman, who is not being named, has accused two detectives of sexually assaulting her. (Facebook) “They just wanted to go back to basically recreate what happened," her lawyer, Michael David, said. “She took it very hard. She broke down. The dad was very upset, extremely upset what happened to his daughter.”
She said the detectives approached her and two friends in a Bath Beach park the night of Sept. 14, handcuffed her after finding marijuana and an anxiety drug in a bag next to her, then drove her to a secluded spot near the 60th Precinct stationhouse in Coney Island.
One of the detectives raped her and both forced her to perform a sex act, according to her account.
The teen was in a Bath Beach park Sept. 14 when the officers handcuffed her after finding marijuana and an anxiety drug in a bag next to her, then drove her to a secluded spot near the 60th Precinct stationhouse in Coney Island. (Gardiner Anderson/for New York Daily News) One of the detectives accused her of “scratching her top” and ordered her to take off her bra, David said.
Brooklyn teen IDs one of the NYPD cops accused in sex attack 
“He saw her nipple ring,” David said. The cop pointed it out to his partner, and the duo told her, “You're going to get a desk appearance ticket, sit in the precinct for three hours, so this is what you can do for us."
“If this case turns out that it actually happened, again, it goes to the trust we’ve been trying to build over the last three years,” O’Neill said. “I’d be extremely disappointed.”
The Brooklyn District Attorney’s office is investigating the incident but thus far no charges have been filed. (rafalkrakow/rafalkrakow) The detectives said the sex was consensual.
David refuted that Tuesday.
“She's not a tough girl, she's a very soft girl. They just took advantage of her,” he said.
Tags: nypd police under investigation sex crimes brighton beach coney island
