posts.title: 30 concertgoers hid in freezer during Las Vegas shooting
posts.text:
SEE IT: Musician describes hiding in freezer with 30 other people during Las Vegas shooting 30 concertgoers hid in freezer during Las Vegas shooting NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Tuesday, October 3, 2017, 11:20 AM 
As gunfire erupted at the Route 91 Harvest Music Festival in Las Vegas, a group of about 30 people packed into a freezer to escape the carnage. 
Musician Bryan Hopkins, a singer for the group Elvis Monroe, said he was trying to lead people to a nearby fence but couldn't make it because the gunfire wouldn't subside. 
"We see an ice chest — it's a trailer —and we open up the doors and just start helping people up inside the trailer, which happened to be a freezer," he told CNN . "There must have been, I don't know, 23 to 30 of us inside this freezer." Stephen Paddock killed at least 59 people during a shooting Sunday night in Las Vegas. (Facebook) 
While concertgoers were enjoying an outdoor Jason Aldean concert on the Las Vegas Strip Sunday night, 64-year-old Stephen Paddock opened fire on the crowd from the balcony of his hotel room at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino.

thread.title: A glimpse at Las Vegas shooting survivors' wide-ranging injuries
thread.title_full: A glimpse at Las Vegas shooting survivors' wide-ranging injuries

posts.author: EDGAR SANDOVAL, GRAHAM RAYMAN
posts.title: A glimpse at Las Vegas shooting survivors' wide-ranging injuries
posts.text:
The bullets did not discriminate.
Two teachers, a high school teen, a casino employee and a social worker were among the hundreds who found themselves in hospital beds Tuesday — wounded, but alive, after Stephen Paddock’s deadly rampage on the Las Vegas strip.
Paddock’s attack on an outdoor country music concert killed 58 people and injured 527. He shot himself before police could breach the door of his room at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino.
Christina Kitcat, 30, of Calabasas, California, lay in the hospital Tuesday with a bullet wound in her chest. She was unconscious and required open heart surgery, according to her friend since first grade, Casey Napolitano.
These are the victims of the Las Vegas massacre 
“Her boyfriend got her to safety and to the hospital,” she told the Daily News. “She’s getting a lot of help. I was just with her last Saturday at a pool party. She's the sweetest girl I know. I couldn't believe it.”
Dr. Douglas R. Fraser cared for patients at the University Medical Center’s trauma unit UMC Trauma Center in Las Vegas.
Nick Campbell, 16, of Henderson, Nevada, was injured during the Las Vegas rampage after he jumped onto his girlfriend and saved her life. (GoFundMe) He said from the start it was obvious the shooter used a large caliber gun that tore into the victims in ways he hasn't seen in a long time.
"We had over 104 patients seen. Over 30 had critical injuries,” he said. “Over a dozen needed different operations from orthopedics, to chest, cardiovascular surgery, abdominal surgery. We have a lot of patients requiring chest tubes.”
MAP: Mass shootings in the United States since 2013 
Fraser said the gunshot wounds were large, with smashed bone and soft tissue. Doctors had to use the chest tubes to drain internal bleeding, and had to resect holes in bowels and intestines.
"It was an extremely sad event,” he said. “There's a few that remain very critical.”
Nick Campbell, 16, of Henderson, Nevada, was enjoying the concert with his 15-year-old girlfriend when Paddock opened fire from a 32nd floor window of his suite.
Nick jumped on his girlfriend, saving her life, but a bullet went through one of his arms and smashed into his torso, breaking several ribs and bruising a lung.
House won't consider gun silencer bill after Vegas shooting 
Remembering the victims of the Las Vegas mass shooting “He was faced with a life or death situation but Nick’s first instinct was to jump on his girlfriend and save her life,” three of his friends wrote on Gofundme.
“Nick Campbell is the definition of a real life hero and took a bullet for his girlfriend in order to protect her.”
The page had raised $16,302 for him by lunchtime Tuesday.
Mandalay Bay employee Billy King, a dad of four, took a bullet through the upper left side of his chest, according to a Gofundme post by his friend Melly Allen, containing graphic pictures of his injuries.
NRA silent following Las Vegas shooting 
“Billy was shot while shielding his wife Kim King when the shooter opened fire on the crowd of concertgoers below,” Allen wrote.
“Kim attributes her life to the selfless act of Billy and his quick thinking.”
Billy King, a Mandalay Bay employee and father of four, was injured in the shooting. King was shielding his wife, Kim, when Stephen Paddock opened fire. (GoFundMe) The Gofundme page raised $4,425 by Tuesday at noon.
Zack Mesker, 22, of San Marcos, California, and his girlfriend were running away from the gunfire, when a bullet slammed into his pelvis.
Las Vegas gunman sent $100G to Philippines days before massacre 
Antoinette Moore, a family friend, said on Gofundme he was in the intensive care unit.
“His injuries are internal as well as external,” Moore wrote.
“Zack is my childhood friend as well as my neighbor. His family is my second family and they are in a time of need.”
The page had collected more than $9,000.
Mean Girls Day brings cast together to support Las Vegas victims 
Zack Mesker, 22, of San Marcos, California, and his girlfriend were running away from the gunfire, when a bullet slammed into his pelvis. (GoFundMe) Mom Lisa Lewan and her son Matt, of Cypress, California, were injured but survived. Matt Lewan was shot in the shoulder and was still in the intensive care unit at a Las Vegas hospital.
The bullet tore through an artery, according to his sister, Ashley Lewan, who posted a Gofundme page that has raised nearly $5,000 so far.
“He had a vein removed from his leg to replace the damaged vein in his chest and his internal bleeding caused his lungs to fill with blood,” she wrote. “This has been helped with chest tubes. He is awake and talking, but still in a lot of pain.”
Mom Lisa was treated and released.
GoFundMe for Las Vegas massacre victims raises more than $3.2M 
California teacher Frank Bignami was shot in one wrist, but his wife Autumn, also a teacher, fared worse, according to a friend’s post on Gofundme.
She was hit in the face and back and underwent night-long surgery.
A bullet tore through Matt Lewan's artery, according to his sister, Ashley, who posted a Gofundme page that has raised nearly $5,000 so far. (GoFundMe) Just before 5 p.m., a friend posted a text that said, “Just got off the phone with Frank. They are waiting for the bleeding to stop before they do the oral surgery.”
“It’s going to be a long road,” the friend added. “Frank sounded tired, but also sounded very thankful that Autumn is alive.”
Injured twin sisters recall how they survived Las Vegas shooting 
People had donated $25,273 of the $48,000 goal by late Tuesday morning.
Social worker Jeanine Ruggiero suffered a collapsed lung and broken ribs. (GoFundMe) Social worker Jeanine Ruggiero suffered a collapsed lung and broken ribs, according to friend Cindy Brown on Gofundme. She was conscious and awaiting surgery.
Ruggiero is a full-time student in the San Jose State Master’s of Social Work online program and was currently interning in the University of California, San Francisco’s emergency department.
“For those who know Jeannine personally, know that she is always one of the first friends to offer a listening ear or provide support during hard times,” Brown wrote. “After all that she has done for others, please help us in showing her love and support.”
Vegas gunman possibly used add-on to make rifle almost automatic 
The Gofundme Brown created raised more than $8,000.
Rachel Sheppard was in critical condition, according to friend Steven Joseph on Gofundme.
Police officers stand at the scene Sunday of a shooting on the Las Vegas strip. (John Locher/AP) “Her status is very serious and life threatening,” he wrote. “She is hands down one of the (most) coolest genuine person I have ever known.”
The fund created by Joseph had raised more than $11,000 by Tuesday at noon.
30 concertgoers hid in freezer during Las Vegas shooting 
Tiffani Huizar was celebrating her 18th birthday on Sunday, dancing to country music in the front row of the Highway 91 festival.
Moments later, the Santa Ana teen was running for her life toward the airport holding her bleeding stomach, recalled her uncle Rick Leon, 67.
Huizar has since had two stomach surgeries and family are trying to transfer her to a hospital close to home.
“She was toward the front with her two sisters. Everybody laid down. She was the only one who stood up and got shot,” he said. “She got up and ran. All she remembers is falling back, but she didn’t know she was shot. She started running when she noticed all the blood. She ran toward the airport. Someone, a civilian, brought her here. She doesn’t remember how.”
“After she got shot, she was thinking of running back to find her sister, but she couldn’t,” he said of her older twin siblings. “They didn’t get hurt. They are with her right now. Her mother was here with her, but she was at the hotel. When she heard, she couldn’t get to her. It was on lockdown. It was hard for her.”
“They had to remove some of her intestine,” Leon recalled as he walked out of the hospital.
“I’m relieved she’s doing well. She’s in pain. It looks like she’s gonna’ be ok. She’ll be all right. Many others can’t say the same.”
But she’s not without scars, he said.
“She hadn’t talked about it," Leon said. "She gets startled easily with noise. Any noise, she panics. She’s going to need therapy.”
He can’t understand how can someone have so much hate.
“He went crazy. How can someone have so much hate? I’m not too keen on those type of guns," Leon said. "They are made for one thing. War.”
With Denis Slattery 
Tags: las vegas las vegas shooting nevada gun violence mass murder crimes against children

thread.title: Parents need school safety information, and soon
thread.title_full: Parents need school safety information, and soon

posts.author: Alyssa Katz
posts.title: Parents need school safety information, and soon
posts.text:
Parents need school safety information, and soon Parents need school safety information, and soon NEW YORK DAILY NEWS  15 PM 
No textbook instructs a mayor or schools chancellor on what to do when teenage bullying bursts beyond controllable bounds into the kind of violence that left one Bronx teen dead and another jailed facing murder charges. 
Mayor de Blasio and Chancellor Carmen Fariña acted on the right impulse, promptly holding a “community conversation on school safety” Monday and inviting parent leaders from across the city to weigh in. 
But that one smart first move doesn’t make up for their reticence until now to keep parents informed about what goes on behind school walls, or damaging ripple effects of that cone of silence. 
At the Monday town hall, for more than an hour, de Blasio and Fariña took questions from moms and dads by turns anxious, aggrieved and unassured that the public schools their children attend have the means or methods to keep bullying or violence out of classrooms, lunchrooms and halls. 
De Blasio drove down his habitual crisis-moment rut, deflecting responsibility while promising progress: “Last year was the safest on record, but we have more to do and we have to do it together.” 
Safest by the city’s own tally of assaults, arrests and summonses, yes — but the state’s inventory of violent incidents shows an increase, possibly due to increasingly consistent reporting by schools to the state. 
Troublingly, bullying and harassment were also reported more frequently in the 2015-16 school year than the one before. 
Fariña recapped measures that her school principals, deans and counselors are taking toward constructive measures to preempt bullying and disturbances, like restorative justice circles where kids can make amends with one another and defuse beefs, quiet spots where stressed-out students can throw themselves on cushions, and workshops teaching young people responsibility for their actions. 
Of such emotional lessons emerge mature and thoughtful young people. One day, should her successors continue the work now begun and invest in the sheer number of counselors necessary to do the painstaking anti-conflict work child by child, this city may well look back on the achievement as Fariña’s signature legacy. 
But not if she can’t convince parents here and now that schools are on the right path to safety and order. 
The confidence problem goes deeper than Fariña’s off-kilter assurance during the town hall meeting that what looks like a wild classroom can in fact be a place where “interactive learning” goes on. 
Deepening the disconnect, the mayor and chancellor are asking parents to choose their children’s schools, and choose to keep them there, with next to no substantive information about those schools’ safety records. That’s too much to expect, in an era when constituents rightly expect real-time information a la the NYPD’s Compstat. 
Few parents know they can go to the state Education Department’s website to look up reports on violent and disruptive incidents, as well as instances of cyber-bullying or harassment, and fewer still have the time for a deep dive through the spreadsheets — which in any case lag by two years. 
Similarly, families have to hunt in the recesses of the city Department of Education’s website for School Safety Agent Excel files listing NYPD arrests and summonses, and get no clue on such crucial stats as 911 calls made or weapons confiscated. 
Instead, DOE serves up subjective school-climate survey results from students, teachers and parents to tell the story on each school’s safety, alongside detailed stats on test scores, attendance, demographics and other vital signs on academic performance. 
To judge from the unaddressed downward spiral of safety-survey results at Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation, the scene of the deadly attack — and to judge again from Fariña’s new directive to her superintendents to review their schools’ own survey results and address trouble spots — the officials in charge haven’t been taking the survey results on violence, bullying and disorder seriously enough. 
And why would they? The forces that should be holding principals and saccountable can’t. For starters, there’s no way for parents to compare survey results between schools to see how they stack up against one another. Armed with knowledge, parents can demand change. 
De Blasio, a former school board member, understands this. He acknowledged to a mom Monday that the schools need to get better information to parents, faster. As the mayor put it: “We have to make sure the accountability mechanism is working.” 
For that accounting to actually result in safer schools where learning thrives, de Blasio and Fariña must err on the side of delivering more information to parents, not less — with all due consideration to student-privacy laws and the integrity of criminal proceedings. 
If they’re worried parents will pull kids from unsafe schools en masse, as a school safety official at the forum suggested could ensue: That’s a risk they will have to take. 
No matter how many programs and comfy cushions Fariña puts in place, the measure of her anti-violence efforts’ success will be consistent and detailed safety stats that every family can readily see on schools’ DOE profile page as they shop around — moving in an indisputably positive direction. 
akatz@nydailynews.com

organizations.name: urban assembly school for wildlife conservation

thread.title: Most moisturizers are lying about being allergen-free
thread.title_full: Most moisturizers are lying about being allergen-free

posts.author: CONSTANCE GIBBS
posts.title: Most moisturizers are lying about being allergen-free
posts.text:
Many moisturizers are greasing your palms — most products that claim to be fragrance-free and hypoallergenic fail to live up to the claim.
Researchers at Northwestern University analyzed the top-selling moisturizers sold by Target, Amazon and Walmart and found that 45% of products that claimed to be “fragrance-free” contained fragrance and 83% of products that were supposed to be “hypoallergenic” contained a potential allergen.
The study analyzed 174 lotions, creams, oils, butter and ointments to determine if what the label says matched the actual product. Turns out, a lot of the products are not correctly labeled and only 12% (21) of products that claimed to be fragrance-free and hypoallergenic actually were.
The study warned that many of the phrases used on moisturizing products, like “dermatologist recommended,” “noncomedogenic” and “hypoallergenic,” are “marketing tools with minimal to no regulatory oversight or substantiation.”
Human tears and saliva can generate electricity: study 
Products that claim to be “dermatologist-recommended,” the study also said, have no regulation to back up these determinations. Lead author Dr. Steve Xu, a dermatologist at Northwestern's Feinberg School of Medicine, told NPR that those labels don’t mean much. "It could be three dermatologists, or a thousand," he said.
To top it off, many of the products with these labels, “dermatologist recommended” and “phthalate-free,” were priced slightly higher than products without them.
The study authors warned consumers and dermatologists that products which say they are organic or hypoallergenic do not always mean they are, because of the lack of regulation, and dermatologists should be careful when giving recommendations.
Tags: featured lifestyle health studies Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: Kim Cattrall offers dig at Sarah Jessica Parker amid 'SATC' drama
thread.title_full: Kim Cattrall offers dig at Sarah Jessica Parker amid 'SATC' drama

posts.author: RACHEL DESANTIS
posts.title: Kim Cattrall offers dig at Sarah Jessica Parker amid 'SATC' drama
posts.text:
"Sex and the City" star Kim Cattrall has swapped her cosmopolitan for some tea.
The 61-year-old actress had some harsh words for former co-star Sarah Jessica Parker Tuesday, just one week after rumors swirled that Cattrall's diva behavior was to blame for the axing of a potential third movie sequel.
"At this very moment, it's quite extraordinary to get any kind of negative press about something that I've been saying for almost a year of 'no' that I'm demanding or a diva," Cattrall told Piers Morgan on his British show "Life Stories," according to DailyMailTV . "And this is really where I take to task the people from 'Sex and the City' and specifically Sarah Jessica Parker, in that I think she could have been nicer."
"I really think she could have been nicer. I don't know what her issue is. I never have," Cattrall said.
Sarah Jessica Parker: No third 'Sex and the City' movie 
There has been no love lost over the years between the actresses, who portrayed Samantha Jones and Carrie Bradshaw on the hit HBO show, respectively.
Cattrall said her co-star Sarah Jessica Parker “could have been nicer.” (Mike Marsland/Mike Marsland/WireImage) Rumors of a rift between the two have swirled for years, and though the show has been off the air for more than a decade, the drama resurfaced this week when Parker confirmed once and for all that a third movie sequel was a no-go.
"It's over … we're not doing it," she told Extra. "I'm disappointed. We had this beautiful, funny, heartbreaking, joyful, very relatable script and story. It's not just disappointing that we don't get to tell the story and have that experience, but more so that for the audience that has been so vocal in wanting another movie."
Parker appeared to take the high road and avoided any mention of her former co-star, but her official confirmation came after DailyMailTV claimed that Cattrall was behind the stalling of the film, which was reportedly set for production in New York City this fall.
Sarah Jessica Parker shuts down Kim Cattrall feud rumors 
The outlet claimed the actress wanted the film's producers to back her other film projects, and after they refused, she put a halt to production.
Carrie Bradshaw's most ridiculous outfits from 'Sex and the City' But Cattrall denied this to Morgan, and instead said she had simply wrapped up that chapter of her life and had no interest in revisiting it.
"This isn't about more money, this is not about more scenes," she said. "It's not about any of those things. This is about a clear decision, an empowered decision in my life to end one chapter and start another. I'm 61. It's now."
Parker's reps declined comment on Cattrall's latest dig, but for what it's worth, Parker dismissed any claims of resentment last year to Howard Stern.
Sarah Jessica Parker trolled by Russian government 
"Was every day perfect? Were people always desperately, hopefully in love with each other? No," she said. "But this is a family of people who needed each other, relied upon each other and loved each other."
Tags: sarah jessica parker kim cattrall sex and the city movies Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet

thread.title: Scammer mortgage broker cheated woman out of $90G
thread.title_full: Scammer mortgage broker cheated woman out of $90G

posts.author: CHRISTINA CARREGA
posts.title: Scammer mortgage broker cheated woman out of $90G
posts.text:
A desperate Brooklyn woman gave almost $100,000 to a scam mortgage broker who promised to save her home — but cost her everything instead, prosecutors said Tuesday.
The 56-year-old homeowner was in fear of losing her East New York home when — unknown to the woman — her son took out a mortgage that defaulted, Assistant District Attorney Joseph DiBenedetto said in Brooklyn Supreme Court.
The owner’s tenant recommended she hire a Queens man, Ravin Lakhram, who claimed he could get her monthly mortgage payments of approximately $2,600 reduced to $1,567.
“When the victim in this case hired the defendant to help save her house, she had no idea he was allegedly a heartless crook who was pocketing her hard-earned cash, even though he knew his scam would eventually cost her dearly,” acting Brooklyn District Attorney Eric Gonzalez said.
NYC landlord hit with indictment in $5M mortgage fraud scheme 
From June 25, 2010, to Dec. 31, 2015, the homeowner gave Lakhram the lower mortgage payments, in cash. But instead of helping her, Lakhram, who once worked as a mortgage broker, helped himself to her money, prosecutors said.
Lakhram, 45, allegedly pocketed more than $90,000 and the woman’s house went into foreclosure.
“Are these people living on the streets?” asked Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice Danny Chun.
“The mother sleeps on a friend’s couch and the son lives out of state with a friend,” DiBenedetto responded.
Francisco Moya blasted as a fraud over 'questionable residency' 
The prosecutor requested bail of $150,000 because Lakhram has a 2001 grand larceny conviction and subsequent probation violations.
The judge thought the request was too low and set bond at $250,000.
If convicted, Lakhram faces up to 15 years in prison for second- and third-degree grand larceny.
Tags: fraud east new york brooklyn real estate Send a Letter to the Editor Join the Conversation: facebook Tweet
